Paulo G. Alcazaren (Paulo Gonzalez Alcazaren) is an urban designer, landscape architect, writer, and photographer. He was born in Argao, Cebu on 25 Jul 1955. He is the son of Juan Alcazaren Jr and Rolinda Gonzalez. He is the father of filmmaker Juan Manuel “Whammy” Alcazaren and Julian Ignacio Alcazar and the elder brother of filmmakers Juan and Miguel Alcazaren. He is married to broadcast journalist Twink Macaraig. He attended Don Bosco Technical Institute in Mandaluyong City from elementary to high school. He earned bachelor of science degrees in architecture and landscape architecture from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. He received his master’s degree in urban design from the National University of Singapore garnering the Singapore Institute of Architect’s book prize for best graduate student in the program.

Alcazaren has taught and lectured extensively. He was a cultural heritage lecturer at the Department of Sociology of Ateneo de Manila University in 2002 and an assistant professor at the College of Architecture of UP Diliman from 2002 to 2005.

After working for several architects as well as landscape architects and National Artist Ildefonso P. Santos, he set up the design firm PDAA Partners in 1982. He expanded the practice to Singapore in 1989, where he served as managing director through most of the 1990s. Over the last 30 years, the firm has been involved in over 200 urban design, planning or landscape architecture projects in 14 countries. He is currently head of PGAA Creative Design, Manila, which is affiliated with offices in Singapore and India.

Alcazaren is a past president and fellow of the Philippine Association of Landscape Architects. He is also an honorary fellow of the Philippine Institute of Architects. He is a founding member of the board of the Heritage Conservation Society, and a trustee of the Nayong Pilipino Foundation and Escuela Taller Intramuros. Some of his projects in the Philippines include designing the Esplanade in Iloilo City; the Pasig City Civic Center; and renovations of Roxas Blvd, Baywalk, the Rizal Park Independence Plaza, and key sections of Intramuros in Manila. Others include large resorts, hotel sites, and mixed-use developments in Luzon and the Visayas.

Alcazaren contributed essays on Philippine architecture to Sanghaya (NCCA Yearbook), 2001, and the CD book Arkitekturang Pilipino (Philippine Architecture), 2003. He was a contributing author to Malacañan Palace: The Official Illustrated History, 2005, and the principal author of Lungsod Iskwater: The Evolution of Informality as a Dominant Pattern in Philippine Cities, 2010. Other books he edited, wrote, or photographed for include Parks for a Nation: 50 Years of NPDC and the Rizal Park, 2013, and The Philippine Arena: A Monument to an Enduring Faith, 2014. He also contributed to a number of local and international architectural magazines starting with Design and Architecture magazine in 1989 and was the editor in chief of BluPrint Magazine from 2002 to 2012. His photographs of architecturally significant structures have been published in local and international publications. He has also exhibited his photography in three exhibits at local galleries and museums. He has curated three more exhibits over the last 10 years on the subjects of Manila’s and Quezon City’s urban histories, as well as an interactive exhibit on Manila’s heritage plazas.

In 2000, he was awarded the Alab ng Haraya by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts for his series of articles on Philippine culture. The following year, the Professional Regulation Commission awarded him the Outstanding Professional of the Year in landscape architecture. He was also awarded several times in Singapore for his work as a landscape architect. In 2015, he received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for architecture from the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Edgar Allan M. Sembrano

Emilio Alvero (Emilio Vera Alvero) was a painter and sculptor. He was born in Quiapo, Manila on 8 Feb 1886. He died in 1955. He married Rosa Sevilla, writer and founder of the Instituto de Mujeres. Among the couple’s children was Aurelio Alvero, a poet and renowned art collector who wrote his poetry and art criticism under the nom de plume “Magtanggol Asa.” Emilio Alvero finished his basic education at the Quiapo Parochial School. He studied painting privately under Lorenzo Guerrero, sculpture under Romualdo de Jesus, and scenographic painting under Cesare Alberoni. He was a contemporary of Fernando Amorsolo and Alejandro Cawed at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts.

As a painter, Alvero is known for his realistic still lifes. In Excursion, Alvero’s subject matter is boiled rice rendered so realistically, complete with spilled vinegar rolling down a banana leaf. Alvero’s Table Delicacies, 1928, is outstanding not only because of the realism of the dish of tuna, the cantaloupe, and the basket of vegetables in the background, but also because the composition consists of mostly oval shapes which are echoed in the oval shape of the painting itself and the concave glass cover of the painting. At least six other still life paintings by this artist are preserved, one remarkable for its portrayal of makopa and balimbing, another a rich person’s setting of sumptuous dishes laid out on a realistically depicted crocheted table mantel.

Alvero also painted other scenes. A Nipa Hut, which is outstanding for its realistic capturing of the rugged materials of the house, is in the Lourdes V. Ongpin collection. He also depicted the Catafalque of Jose Mabesa in Hongkong in oil, also found in the same collection.

Alvero is also known to have designed houses, such as that of Dr Santiago Barcelona in San Juan, Manila.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar

Pablo Antonio (Pablo Sebero Antonio) was an architect. He is a National Artist for architecture. He was born in Binondo, Manila on 25 Jan 1902. He died on 14 Jun 1975. His father, Apolonio Antonio, was a maestro de obras (master builder) who dabbled in painting and sculpture; his mother, Trinidad Sebero, died when he was very young. He and his wife Marina have two sons, Ramon and Luis, who are architects and interior designers. Antonio worked as a draftsman for the Bureau of Public Works while attending high school at night. After taking a correspondence course in architecture and structural engineering, he took formal courses in architecture at Mapua Institute of Technology but soon dropped out due to the pressure of work. Antonio resigned from the bureau and worked as a draftsman and construction foreman for the Mapua Arevalo Siochi Construction Company, later called the Santa Clara Construction Co. In 1927, one of the company’s owners sent Antonio on a scholarship to the University of London where he finished the five-year architectural course in three years. He returned to Manila, passed the government examinations, and became a registered architect in 1932. Widespread recognition of his gifts led to his appointment as architect of various institutions and corporations, among them Far Eastern University (FEU), Philippine National Bank, and Manila Railroad Co.

In 1933, he completed his first major work, the Ideal Theater on Rizal Ave, Manila. He subsequently designed the FEU Building on Quezon Blvd, the Boulevard-Alhambra (now Bel-Air) Apartments on Dewey (now Roxas) Blvd, the Ramon Roces Publications Building, and the White Cross Preventorium. Antonio’s works after World War II include the Manila Polo Club, the Capitan Luis Gonzaga Building on Rizal Ave and Carriedo, the FEU Administration and Science Buildings, and the Galaxy Theater on Rizal Ave.

Antonio’s buildings represented a new direction in Philippine architecture. They were characterized by clean lines, plain surfaces, and bold rectangular masses—a striking departure from the traditionalist and academic style prevailing at the time. Moreover, Antonio regarded every design project as unique and imparted to every building he created a distinctive form and character, avoiding anything that might be seen as a trademark. He used wood, stone, and reinforced concrete to create refinement, warmth, and virility.

While the FEU Building combines formal symmetry with a robust sturdiness, the Ramon Roces Publications Building is irregular in plan, asymmetrical in its facade, and characterized by movement and diverse forms. Like many architects of his time, Antonio used the sunbreak, but departed from the general pattern. In the Capitan Luis Gonzaga Building, horizontal slabs project from ceiling and windowsill height, while vertical fins of half-story height are staggered, creating a contrast between continuous horizontal planes, and broken vertical planes. Antonio considered the Manila Polo Club one of his best works. The sprawling building, sheltered by hip roofs and using wood and stone with great visual impact, is both festive and virile in character. The woodwork on the ceiling of the social lounge is like a huge abstract sculpture.

Antonio was a member of the Board of Examiners for Architects, 1936-37, president of the Philippine Institute of Architects (PIA), 1941-44, and member of the Quezon City Capitol Site on City Planning, 1946-47. He was named Architect of the Year by PIA in 1952 and given the National Award of Merit for Architecture in 1954 by the Philippine Republic. In 1956, he was listed in Asia’s Who’s Who, a Hong Kong publication. In 1971, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila. In 1972, he was conferred the Republic Cultural Heritage Award. In 1976, he was posthumously named National Artist for architecture. A book titled The Architectural Legacy of Pablo S. Antonio, 1902-1975, edited by Sylvia Roces Montilla, was launched in 2013.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Luis Araneta (Luis Maria Zaragoza Araneta) was an architect. He was born in Manila on 9 Jul 1916. He died in San Francisco, California, USA on 22 Apr 1984. He was the 13th of 14 children of Gregorio Araneta and Carmen Zaragoza, he graduated with a bachelor of science degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas in 1939. He worked briefly with Andres Luna de San Pedro, then established his own office.

His major works include the Times Theater on Quezon Blvd, Manila, 1941; Manila Doctors’ Hospital on United Nations Ave, 1956; Makati Medical Center, Makati, 1965; Santa Catalina College, Legarda, Manila; and the Botica Boie Building (no longer standing), Escolta, Manila. Araneta designed a large number of upper-class residences, which are noted for their airy elegance and expansive flowing space.

Araneta was president of the Philippine Institute of Architects, 1954-55; honorary president of the League of City and Town Planners of the Philippines; member of the Philippine Institute of Environmental Planners; and technical adviser of the Committee for Parks Development. He was Commissioner of the Philippine Participation in the 1958 Brussels World’s Fair and in the 1960 Seattle World’s Fair. He was the president and director of a number of corporations, and was active in the Manila, Philippine, and International Jaycee (Junior Chamber) organizations, and the Operations Brotherhood International.

A patron of the arts, Araneta was a member of the Bayanihan Folk Arts Association, Filipiniana Book Guild, Art Association of the Philippines, and Manila Symphony Society. He started collecting paintings while still an architecture student. The first two major works he acquired were by Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo. Even while imprisoned at Fort Santiago during World War II for underground activities, he continued acquiring major works with the help of a friend, Alfonso Ongpin. Over the years he built a fine collection of Lunas, Hidalgos, Amorsolos, and other Philippine masterpieces. In the late 1940s, he began collecting santos, and had the first extensive collection of this type of art. Named the Pagrel collection, after his children, the Araneta collection of colonial sculpture, painting, and church furnishings is housed in the San Agustin Museum.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Arcadio Arellano (Arcadio de Guzman Arellano) was an architect. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 13 Nov 1872. He died on 12 Apr 1920. He was the third of 15 children of Bartola de Guzman and Luis Arellano, a builder who was an assistant to Juan Hervas , the Spanish consulting architect of the city of Manila in the late 19th century. He was married to Amalia Ocampo with whom he had nine children. His son Otilio became an architect, and is the father of visual artist Agnes Arellano. He was the older brother of Juan Arellano , architect and painter.

He studied at Ateneo Municipal where he received a bachelor’s degree in 1892, and at the Escuela de Artes y Oficios, where he completed the courses for perito mercantil (bookkeeping) and maestro de obras (master builder) in 1895. Subsequently, he opened his own architectural and surveying firm. As captain in the Engineering Corps of Emilio Aguinaldo’s revolutionary army, he supervised the repair of the convento of the Barasoain Church in 1898 for Aguinaldo’s government. In 1901, he was appointed consulting architect to Gov-Gen William Howard Taft. He also served on the committee that drafted the building code of Manila.

Arellano worked in the revivalist style but was not averse to innovation. Among the residences he designed were those of Gregorio Araneta on R. Hidalgo St, Ariston Bautista Lin on Barbosa, the Hidalgos on Plaza del Carmen, and the Carmelos on Azcarraga (now C. M. Recto). The Hidalgo house contained neo-Gothic touches whereas the Bautista Lin house, following what was then a contemporary trend, incorporated art nouveau motifs to match the set of Vienna Sezession furniture around which the house was designed. In some of his works Arellano also used native plant forms as decorative motifs. Commercial buildings he designed included Roman Ongpin’s bazaar, El 82, on Plaza Calderon de la Barca, which had such renaissance features as oval dormer windows and a four-column porch with a pediment and balustrade; the Hotel de Francia and the Carmelo and Bauermann Building on Azcarraga. With his younger brother Juan, he designed the Gota de Leche Building on Lepanto (now S. H. Loyola) and the Casino Español on Taft Ave. In 1966, he was posthumously given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text:
Juan Arellano (Juan de Guzman Arellano ) was an architect and painter. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 25 Apr 1888. He died on 5 Dec 1960. He was the son of Luis Arellano and Bartola de Guzman. He married Natividad de Ocampo, a singer, with whom he had a son, Oscar, an architect. When he was 12, his father died and his elder brother Arcadio, an architect, took care of him and his schooling. As a boy, he studied painting under Lorenzo Guerrero and Fabian de la Rosa and took lessons in sculpture. In 1906, he studied architecture at the Drexel Institute in Philadelphia. After traveling through Europe, he did postgraduate work in architecture at the University of Pennsylvania and attended the Beaux Arts School in New York. When he returned to the Philippines, he worked with his brother Arcadio on such projects as the Gota de Leche Building on Lepanto St and the old Casino Español on Taft Ave. He became assistant architect, then supervising architect, and finally consulting architect for the Bureau of Public Works.

Arellano influenced the development of Filipino architecture in his time, not only in its neoclassic phase but also the art deco and later nativist phases. Like many architects trained in the United States in the early 20th century, he came under the influence of the Paris Ecole des Beaux Arts and promoted the neoclassic style. This can be seen in his major works, which include the Legislative Building (presently the National Museum of the Philippines main office and Museum of Fine Arts), completed in 1926; the Post Office Building, 1931; and the Villamor Hall at the University of the Philippines (UP) campus on Taft Ave. In contrast, the Metropolitan Theater , 1931, combines art deco and local forms, such as bamboo stalks and mangoes. These four buildings were destroyed during World War II and rebuilt according to the original plans.

In the early 1930s, Arellano designed government buildings for Banaue, Ifugao, and Glan, Cotabato, making use of local architectural forms. He prepared plans for the landscaping of some sections of Manila, particularly Padre Burgos Ave, Harrison Park, the North and South Port Areas, Dewey Blvd, and the Malacañan grounds. He made the master plan for the UP Diliman campus. In the design of some major buildings, he used native forms like the salakot and the nipa hut roof.

Arellano was also a painter. Most of his paintings were landscapes showing the influence of Impressionism and Fauvism. Other paintings reveal his interest in architecture and landscaping of parks and gardens. He also did a number of highly sensitive portraits, which combine psychological insight and a sense of design. In 1967, Arellano was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila posthumously.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III and Alice G. Guillermo

text:
Otilio A. Arellano (Otilio Ocampo Arellano) was an architect. He was born in Quiapo, Manila on 9 Feb 1916. He died on 14 May 1981. His parents are Arcadio Arellano and Amalia Ocampo. He is the nephew of architect Juan Arellano. He married Liwayway Almario. They had five children, one of whom is visual artist Agnes Arellano. At 17, he began working as draftsman and salesman for Findley Engineering and Construction Company Inc. He was head draftsman in the office of his uncle Juan Arellano in 1937-39. After graduating with a bachelor’s degree in architecture from Mapua Institute of Technology in 1940, he began his private practice. In 1966, he formed the firm Otilio Arellano and Associates. Arellano was president of the Philippine Institute of Architects, the United Architects of the Philippines, and the United Technological Organizations of the Philippines. In 1961, he was named honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects.

Arellano also served as officer in various capacities in the Lions Club. He founded the Philippine Youth Welfare Coordinating Council and was its president, 1956-81. He was president of the Philippine Mental Health Association, and founder and vice-chair of the Board of Trustees of the Rizal Youth Development Foundation. Arellano was a pioneer in serving out-of-school youth. He believed that an architect should also be a “builder of men.”

Arellano was notable for employing native motifs in a number of his works. As chief architect of the 1953 Philippine International Fair, he designed, among other structures, the entry arch Gateway to the East, using the form of the mandala. His design for the Philippine Pavilion in the 1964 New York World’s Fair was inspired by the salakot. As consulting architect of the FILOIL Refinery Corporation, he designed service stations using the Maranao panolong (protruding beam-end) as a motif. In 1978, he supervised the restoration of the Metropolitan Theater, designed by Juan Arellano in 1931 and destroyed in World War II.

In his 40 years of practice, he designed government buildings, industrial buildings, commercial office buildings, banks, movie houses, shopping centers, and residences. A list of selected works includes the National Bureau of Investigation Building on Taft Ave; the Sining Kayumanggi at the Mehan Gardens; the Palacio del Gobernador in Intramuros; the Philippine School of Business Administration on Aurora Blvd, Quezon City; the Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation Building on Buendia Ave, Makati; and the San Juan Municipal Center on N. Domingo St, San Juan.

In 1970, Arellano was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila. He died in 1981, together with his wife Liwayway and daughter Felicitas, in a fire that burned their residence in San Juan, Metro Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

A list of selected works includes the National Bureau of Investigation Building on Taft Ave; the Sining Kayumanggi at the Mehan Gardens; the Palacio del Gobernador in Intramuros; the Philippine School of Business Administration on Aurora Blvd, Quezon City; the Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation Building on Buendia Ave, Makati; and the San Juan Municipal Center on N. Domingo St, San Juan.

In 1970, Arellano was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila. He died in 1981, together with his wife Liwayway and daughter Felicitas, in a fire that burned their residence in San Juan, Metro Manila.
Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Carlos Arguelles (Carlos Corcuera Arguelles) was an architect. He was born in Manila on 15 Sep 1917. He died on 19 Aug 2008. His parents are Tomas F. Arguelles, an architect, and Benedicta Corcuera. He married Remedios de la Rama. After finishing high school in San Beda in 1935, he studied at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), finishing a bachelor’s degree in architecture in 1939. He served for a year as reserve officer in the United States Army, then studied architecture at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), earning another bachelor’s degree. He began working for a master’s degree, but with the outbreak of World War II, he entered active service in the United States Army. In 1945, he resumed studies at MIT and received a master’s degree in 1946. From 1946 to 1949 he worked as a designer in architecture offices in California: Kauffman, Lippincott and Eggers; Kistner, Curtis and Wright; and Welton Becket and Associates. Becket was one of the architects who designed the Jai-Alai Building, completed in 1940.

In 1949, he returned to Manila and was engaged as a junior associate of Gines Rivera, collaborating with him on the design of the Ateneo de Manila campus at Loyola Heights. In 1952, he established his own office, C.D. Arguelles and Associates. He taught at the UST School of Architecture, 1949-59, and served as dean, 1954-59. He was a member of the Philippine Institute of Architects, which elected him president, 1958; fellow, 1966; and chancellor of the College of Fellows, 1988. He was active in the Philippine Institute of Architects, and an honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects. He was an officer of the Automobile Association of the Philippines.

His major works include the Philamlife Building and the Manila Hilton (now Manila Pavilion) Hotel on United Nations Ave, Manila; the Holiday Inn on Roxas Blvd; the Philippine National Bank on Escolta; the Urdaneta Apartments, Tuscany Apartments, Development Bank of the Philippines in Makati; and the Chronicle Broadcasting Network Studios in Quezon City. His buildings are notable for having employed the latest technological developments, such as heat-resistant glass, metal sun-baffles, interior systems, and acoustical design. He also designed the 600-unit Philamlife Homes in Quezon City, a planned community for middle-income families, with several types of standard units. The project was designed along organic lines, following the contours of the site, with spacious areas for common use.

Arguelles received the city of Manila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award and the Papal Award Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice in 1998, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines Centennial Honors for the Arts in 1999. In 2011, UST conferred on him the Thomasian Centennial Award.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from Rene B. Javellana

Tomas Arguelles (Tomas Fernandez Arguelles) was a surveyor and architect. He was born in Manila on 7 Mar 1860. He died on 7 Dec 1950. The son of Norberto Arguelles and Petronila Fernandez, he studied at Colegio de San Juan de Letran and Ateneo de Manila. He received his certificates as land surveyor and assessor in 1881. He then worked for the Street Car Company from 1884 to 1892, and the Manila Railroad Company from 1892 to 1896. As a commander in the Philippine Revolutionary Army, he served in the corps of engineers. From 1902 to 1907 he was Manila city councilor, member of the committee for the revision of tax assessment, and honorary commissioner to the Saint Louis Exposition. In 1917, he was again elected city councilor.

Automatically licensed to practice architecture under the Engineers and Architects Law of 1921, he became a senior partner in the firm Arguelles and Magsaysay, and later formed an architectural partnership with Fernando Ocampo. He was elected fellow of the Philippine Institute of Architects in 1950. Arguelles was a member of the Board of Directors of the Academia de Arquitectura y Agrimensura de Filipinas founded in 1902, the first professional organization of architects, engineers, and surveyors in the Philippines.

His works include the Elizalde (Ynchausti) Building on Muelle de la Industria, Manila, and the pre-World War II Heacock’s Building on the Escolta.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Vicente Belloc was a builder. He was born in Valencia, Spain on 26 Aug 1807. He died in Nagcarlan, Laguna on 17 Oct 1877. A Franciscan friar, he left Spain in 1827 as part of the 70th Franciscan mission under Fr Miguel Angel de Barcelas, OFM. In 1832, he was assigned to Pandacan as parish priest, then to Nagcarlan in 1834. He was elected as a representative of the ruling body of the Franciscan order in 1849 and 1870. Although stricken with paralysis in 1872, he asked to remain in Nagcarlan as coadjutor, while a new parish priest took his place. He remained in Nagcarlan until his death.

Belloc left a number of enduring structures in Nagcarlan. In 1874 he renovated the church built in 1752 by changing the woodwork and painting and embellishing it. Not much later, he repaired the choir loft and rested it on three arches of finely cut stone. He laid a new tile floor on the central aisle, nave, sanctuary, and baptistry. In 1859, he and Nagcarlan’s gobernadorcillo (mayor), Juan Pompa, supervised the construction of a casa real (town hall) of stone. The cemetery of Nagcarlan is his best-known work, with a quadrilateral brick wall surrounding the mortuary of brick and stone. The chapel has an underground crypt painted in pleasing designs.  Written by René B. Javellana

Ched Berenguer-Topacio (Mercedes Reyes Berenguer-Topacio) is an architect and interior designer. She was born in Manila on 24 Sep 1929. The daughter of Adolfo Berenguer and Simplicia Reyes, she is married to architect Hector Topacio. She is an architecture graduate of the University of Santo Tomas (UST), 1951, and holds a degree from the New York School of Interior Design, 1953. After her studies in the United States, she became art director and head of the interior design department of Aguinaldo’s Echague in Manila. In 1954, she and seven others founded the Philippine Institute of Interior Designers, of which she became president. The first formal course in interior design in the Philippines was set up with her assistance in 1956 at UST. She and her husband soon established their own firm, Berenguer-Topacio. Aside from designing interiors, they also produced high-quality furniture exported to the United States.

Berenguer-Topacio’s projects include the interiors of hotels, sports clubs, banks, condominiums, department stores, shopping centers, restaurants, hospitals, and residences. While the bulk of her work is in Metro Manila, she has undertaken commissions in San Francisco, Honolulu, Guam, Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur, and Kuwait.

In 1987 and 1988, the Resources Council of America Inc gave Berenguer-Topacio the Roscoe Award for furniture she had designed and manufactured. In 1990, the National Foundation of Contemporary Art in Paris, France, gave her an award of distinction for her Petal Chaise, a lounging chair made of finely woven rattan and wrought iron. In 2008, UST conferred on her the Outstanding Thomasian Alumni Award for interior design.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Julian Bermejo also known as El Padre Capitan was a builder and military architect. He was born in Pardillo, Spain on 1777 or 1778. He died in Cebu on 30 Apr 1851. The son of Matias and Manuela Bermejo, Julian entered the Augustinian novitiate at age 15. He pronounced his vows in the order in 1793, left Cadiz with 20 other Augustinians in 1796, and arrived in Manila most likely on 11 Mar 1797. His first assignment was as parish priest of Boljoon, succeeding Fr Manuel Cordero on 19 Oct 1802. Promotion to higher offices in the order followed: prior of the Cebu Convent of Santo Niño in 1825, president of the chapter of 1829, prior of Bacolor, Pampanga, in 1833, and provincial in 1837-39. But it is as builder and military commander that Bermejo is better known.

Arriving in Boljoon, Bermejo found the church still unfinished, a replacement for an earlier church destroyed by slave raiders in 1782. He completed the church but judged the palisade surrounding the church inadequate. So he surrounded the church complex with a stone wall and a bulwark or strong house, facing the sea. From then on, he initiated the fortification of other churches in southern Cebu and devised a system of communication called telegrafo, based on a network of watchtowers and signal flags and flares, bells and drums. The linchpin of his system was a tower on the hill immediately north of the Boljoon complex. When Bermejo was done, he had constructed a string of towers along the shores of southern Cebu from Carcar to Tañon, later Santander.

He organized militias consisting of sentinels, who manned the towers day and night and watched the seas with their telescopes ready to warn the townspeople of an impending raiding party. He also prepared seaborne fleets ready to repel the raiders and a volunteer army for land defense. So effective was Bermejo that after a sea battle in 1815 off Sumilon Island, offshore between Oslob and Santander, no raiders attacked southern Cebu thereafter.

In 1827, Bermejo joined an expedition to Bohol, under Cebu’s alcalde mayor (governor) Don Jose Lazaro Cairo, to reintegrate the remnants of Dagohoy’s rebel camps to lowland society.  Written by René B. Javellana

Daniel Burnham (Daniel Hudson Burnham) was an architect and city planner. He was born in Henderson, New York, USA on 4 Sep 1846. He died in Heidelberg, Germany on 1 Jun 1912. He was educated in Chicago and Waltman, Massachusetts, where he graduated from high school. Failing admissions tests to Harvard and Yale, and leaving an aborted political career, he worked as a draftsman for the architectural firm of William Le Baron Jenney. From there he apprenticed with the Chicago firm Carter, Drake and Wright. There he met John Wellborn Root, 1850-91, and in 1873 their partnership began, eventually developing into a leading architectural firm. Burnham & Root emphasized steel-frame construction, which made the skyscraper possible. Their complementary personalities suited this partnership. Root was quiet, weak at people skills but had a sharp mechanical mind. He was well-versed in physics and an astute draftsman. Burnham was good at dealing with people and he dreamt big. A much quoted saying of his was: “Make no little plans; they have no magic to stir men’s blood.” The firm designed many landmark buildings in Chicago, New York, Washington DC, and London. Work on the Columbian Exposition or Chicago World’s Fair, 1893, and his designs for Washington DC, Cleveland, San Francisco, and Chicago established Burnham’s reputation as a city planner.

The Columbian Exposition, where he worked closely with landscape architect Fredrick Law Olmstead, and where other architects were commissioned to design buildings concretized Burnham’s vision of the “City Beautiful,” which followed French Beaux Arts design principles that favored neoclassical architecture, characterized by symmetry, balance, and splendor. The area chosen for the exposition was a 630-acre property on Jackson Park. This largely undeveloped land gave Burnham the blank canvas on which to build his vision of well-planned city come true. The Columbian Exposition was called the “White City” because its building were finished in white stucco and illuminated by electrical lights at night. The Columbian exposition would mark Burnham’s other works and city plans.

As president of the American Institute of Architects in 1894, he established close friendships with high government officials, including Pres Theodore Roosevelt. He recommended a young friend ambitious for a foreign assignment, William Cameron Forbes, whom Roosevelt appointed to the Philippines in 1904.

Forbes sought to improve infrastructure in the Philippines and listened to William Howard Taft, then secretary of war, who suggested that a landscape architect help design Baguio, “a new city 5,000 feet above the sea, which will be to the Philippines what Simla is to India” (Klassen 1987, 187). Consulted by Forbes, Burnham volunteered to go; he stayed in the Philippines for about six weeks in 1904. He proposed a grand plan for Manila involving a gridiron street pattern with diagonal thoroughfares converging at rotundas of various sizes to connect the outlying towns and districts bordering Manila. He planned for plenty of open spaces, greenery, and fountains. Government buildings would be the focus of the city, and he chose the sites for the Manila Hotel, Army and Navy Club, Philippine General Hospital, and apparently the Post Office. For the design of Baguio, he proposed to site government buildings on the ridge surrounding a central meadow, known in the local Ibaloy language as kafagway, however cautioning that monumental hilltop constructions be avoided so as not to mar the beautiful landscape.

Neither in Manila nor in Baguio was Burnham’s recommendations strictly followed, but he left his mark on the Philippine landscape. A park is named after him in Baguio.

In 1910, he was appointed chairperson of the National Commission on the Fine Arts by American president Taft. At the time of his death, Burnham headed one of the largest architectural offices in the United States.  Written by René B. Javellana

Ed Calma (Eduardo Gongon Calma) is an architect and interior designer. He was born in Manila on 13 Oct 1963. He is the son of architect Lor Calma and Estella Gongon. One of his five siblings is also an architect. He studied at Pratt Institute, New York, from 1983 to 1988 where he obtained a bachelor of arts in architecture. He spent the year 1985 in Rome under Pratt International Studies conjointly with the University of Rome, Italy. He went on further studies from 1993 to 1994 at Columbia University, New York, where he obtained a master’s degree in advanced architectural design. In between his studies, he worked for the architectural firm of Carlos Zapata and Peter Pran.

At Pratt, Calma’s mentors encouraged him to look for sources of inspiration outside architecture and create new definitions of space. Returning to the Philippines in 1997, he worked with his father’s architectural firm, Lor Calma and Associates, which not only designed buildings but also built furniture and through Lor founded the Philippine School of Interior Design. Ed has since become design principal, architect, and interior designer of the company. Like his father, Ed is committed to modernism but his works break away from the modernist mold by drawing inspiration not from the box, which characterized early modernism in the Philippines, but from nature and from letting space and location influence the design. The term “postmodern” might be aptly applied to his designs. While Lor’s works used local material, Ed’s works use new materials like structural glass and metal, and stones like travertine and onyx, which are increasingly available because of the global market.

Ed’s two iconic buildings are the De La Salle University–College of Saint Benilde’s School of Design and Arts (CSB-SDA), established in 1995, and the Mind Museum, completed in 2011. Both buildings are designed from inside out—that is, the interior spaces defined what the skin or exterior looks like. The 14-story CSB-SDA has the theater jutting out of the facade to serve as canopy for the lower floor. The facade is not a straight line but is angled, with the center pushing forward. The interior is whitewashed and sheeted in glass, which allows light in and opens to a view of the surroundings. The Mind Museum is described as “amorphic” or formless. It has no clear facade. As an organic form with multiple entrances, it can be viewed from anywhere. The cell was the inspiration for a building. Its design was allowed to evolve through interaction with the site and the environment.

Ed Calma Architecture, the professional name of the company Ed runs, has been involved in many projects, some of which have been built while others have yet to be realized. The projects include resorts like Bantayan Resort, Lio Resort, Samal Island Hotel; infrastructures like Serendra Bridge, Lighthouse; office buildings like CLIPP Center, MDI Building, Landco Pacific Building; residential design; interior design like the Mind Museum, De Gallego Apartment; commercial/retail design like Z Bar, Univers, R12; education architecture like DLSU CSB-SDA and Henry Sy Innovation Center; museum and exhibitions like Expo Japan 2005, Expo Hannover 2000, Expo Zaragosa 2008; and master plans like those for Liberty, Azotea, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Ed’s works have been featured in a number of books—namely, Peter Pran of Ellerbe Becket: Recent Works, 1991; Raul A. Barreneche, Tropical Modern, 2006; Sunil Sethi’s Inside Asia, 2004; The Phaidon Atlas of Contemporary World Architecture, 2004; Peter C. Pran, Christian Norberg-Schulz, and Daniel Libeskind’s An Architecture of Poetic Movement, 1999; Elizabeth Reyes and Chester Ong’s Tropical Living: Contemporary Dream Houses in the Philippines, 2000; Elizabeth Reyes, Paulo Alcazaren, and Chester Ong’s 25 Tropical Houses in the Philippines, 2005; and Robert Powell’s The Urban Asian House: Living in Tropical Cities, 1997, and The New Asian House, 2001.

Ed won numerous awards beginning in 1988 with the American Institute of Architects (AIA) National Design Award / Exhibition–National Academy of Design, New York, and Excellence in Design Award, Pratt Institute; 1991 AIA New York Chapter Design Award / Exhibition–Jewish Museum, New York; 1993 Young Architects Award, Progressive Architecture Awards; and 2002 Ten Outstanding Young Men award in the field of architecture, held at the Malacañan Ceremonial Hall.

He won the gold medal for the Philippine Pavilion at EXPO 2005, Aichi, Japan; the UNI Award (Architecture), 2006; Best Kitchen Design, International Category, Sub-Zero Kitchen Design Contest, 2006-7; and the Gold Medal for Design in EXPO 2008 in Zaragoza, Spain. In 2008-9, he received the International Award and the First Place Award for Contemporary Kitchen Design in the Overall Sub-Zero and Wolfe Kitchen Design Contest.  Written by René B. Javellana

Pran, Christian Norberg-Schulz, and Daniel Libeskind’s An Architecture of Poetic Movement, 1999; Elizabeth Reyes and Chester Ong’s Tropical Living: Contemporary Dream Houses in the Philippines, 2000; Elizabeth Reyes, Paulo Alcazaren, and Chester Ong’s 25 Tropical Houses in the Philippines, 2005; and Robert Powell’s The Urban Asian House: Living in Tropical Cities, 1997, and The New Asian House, 2001.

Ed won numerous awards beginning in 1988 with the American Institute of Architects (AIA) National Design Award / Exhibition–National Academy of Design, New York, and Excellence in Design Award, Pratt Institute; 1991 AIA New York Chapter Design Award / Exhibition–Jewish Museum, New York; 1993 Young Architects Award, Progressive Architecture Awards; and 2002 Ten Outstanding Young Men award in the field of architecture, held at the Malacañan Ceremonial Hall.

He won the gold medal for the Philippine Pavilion at EXPO 2005, Aichi, Japan; the UNI Award (Architecture), 2006; Best Kitchen Design, International Category, Sub-Zero Kitchen Design Contest, 2006-7; and the Gold Medal for Design in EXPO 2008 in Zaragoza, Spain. In 2008-9, he received the International Award and the First Place Award for Contemporary Kitchen Design in the Overall Sub-Zero and Wolfe Kitchen Design Contest.

Lor Calma (Lorenzo Licad Calma) is an architect and interior designer. He was born in Arayat, Pampanga on 4 Mar 1928. His parents are Gregorio Calma and Felisa Licad. His wife is Estella Gongon; they have five children, two of whom are architects. He holds a bachelor’s degree in architecture from Mapua Institute of Technology, 1954. Since 1956 he has been engaged in interior design, furniture design and manufacturing, and architectural design. He heads the firm Lor L. Calma Designs Associates Inc. Calma is founding member and past president of the Philippine Institute of Interior Designers. He was a member of the first specialty board for interior designers of the Professional Regulation Commission.

Calma’s projects include the interiors of banks, offices, hotels, restaurants, clubhouses, resorts, and residences. He designed and executed the interiors of the Development Bank of the Philippines, Buendia, Makati; Philippine National Bank, Escolta, Manila; Development Academy of the Philippines, Tagaytay City; Silahis Hotel, Roxas Blvd, Manila; Midtown Ramada Hotel, Pedro Gil, Manila; Puerto Azul Hotel and Beach Resort, Ternate, Cavite; and Benguet Center, Mandaluyong, Metro Manila. His style is modern, inspired by the Bauhaus style, using chromium, glass, and leather. In the 1980s, he went into the postmodern style, which tends toward revivalist and romantic motifs.

Partnering with his son Ed, Calma’s architectural firm has pushed the boundaries of design with deconstructed architecture pieces like the DLSU–Saint Benilde’s School of Art and Design on Singalong St and the Mind Museum at the Fort in Bonifacio Global City. These works are designed inside out, with the exterior hinting at what may lie within. For Saint Benilde’s, Calma designed the theater as a structure that juts beyond the facade and serves as a canopy for the lower floor. The Mind Museum is more organic. In 2009, his exhibit titled Architect Lor Calma: Paintings and Sculptures was held at the Ayala Museum, Greenbelt Art Park, Makati. His sculpture Transformation combines three forms of stacked laminated glass, 5-10 m tall, that represent Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. In 2012, Calma—Lor and Ed—An Exhibit of New Works, was mounted at LRI Design Plaza, Makati City.

In 1985, Calma received an award from the Philippine Institute of Interior Designers as founding member and for his achievement as architect, interior designer, and furniture designer. In 1988, he was conferred the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award as outstanding interior designer, by the city of Manila. Other awards include the Gintong Ama Award for Arts and Culture, 1993; Lifetime Award for Interior Design and Architecture, 1997; Hall of Fame, Philippine Institute of Interior Design, 2006; and Most Outstanding Kapampangan in Arts and Architecture, 2010.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Cesar Canchela (Cesar Canchela Villareal) was an architect. He was born in Manila on 16 Jun 1924. He died on 3 Jun 2008. The son of Tomas Canchela and Consolacion Villareal, both of Malinao, Albay, he finished high school at De La Salle College in 1941. During World War II, he served in the anti-Japanese guerrilla forces in Albay, attaining the rank of battalion adjutant at the age of 19. In 1949, he graduated with a bachelor’s degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas. He taught in the Manuel L. Quezon University School of Architecture, 1949-54. In 1954, he established his own architectural firm.

Canchela is one of the founders and incorporators of the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP) and served as its president. He is a fellow at the UAP and was chancellor of the College of Fellows.

His works include hospitals, banks, public markets, commercial office buildings, government buildings, department stores, school buildings, industrial buildings, condominiums, apartment buildings, and more than 100 residences. For the National Housing Authority, Canchela designed a 1,664-unit low-cost housing project in Vitas, Tondo, Manila. Using prefabricated concrete units stacked economically, construction was rapid, producing four dwelling units in one working day.

Canchela received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1992, the Outstanding Architect of the Year award from the Professional Regulation Commission in 1988, and the Likha Award and Gold Medal from the UAP in 1995.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Alejandro Caudal (Alejandro Yelab Caudal) was an interior decorator. He was born in Antipolo, Rizal on 3 May 1889. He died in Manila on 21 Feb 1951. He was the son of Estanislao Caudal and Hipolita A. Yelab. He married Trinidad Lerma. They have 12 children, one of whom, Celia, is an architect. Caudal was a product of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts, where his contemporaries included Fernando Amorsolo and Emilio Alvero. He was well known as a decorator for fiestas, religious services, and social events. Until the early 1950s, decorations for Malacañan Palace receptions were installed by him. He was often engaged to decorate some of the Intramuros churches for Holy Week, patronal feasts, and weddings. He decorated the altar for the 33rd International Eucharistic Congress held at the Luneta in 1937, and designed the altar of the Malolos Cathedral.

He built a number of houses and designed the furniture for them, among them the Jacinto residence in Bustos, Bulacan; the Luis Santos house in Malolos, Bulacan; the Lopa residence in Pasay; the Lerma house in New Manila, Quezon City; and the Bernardo Tiongco house in Pandacan, Manila. He designed sets for opera, collected antiques, and painted. In his later years, he served as superintendent of buildings and grounds at Centro Escolar University.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

article_title: CBCP Episcopal Commission for Cultural Heritage of the Church (ECCHC)
text:
The CBCP Episcopal Commission for the Cultural Heritage of the Church (ECCHC), formerly known as the Permanent Committee for the Cultural Heritage of the Church (PCCHC), was established by the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) during its 73rd general assembly on 8 Jul 1996 (CBCP 1996). One of the 30 or so working bodies serving the permanent assembly of the Philippine Catholic episcopacy and the individual bishops in their respective sees, the PCCHC was under the Department of Doctrine and Religious Affairs for purposes of administration and coordination (CBCP 2000).

Initially, the CBCP Episcopal Commission on Culture issued a mandate to address emerging issues and concerns related to the pastoral care of the Church’s tangible cultural heritage. This concern came to a focus when CBCP created the PCCHC, inspired by the establishment by Pope John Paul II in 1988 of the Pontifical Commission for Preserving the Artistic and Historic Patrimony of the Church attached to the Congregation for the Clergy, a department in the Roman Curia (John Paul II 1988). The pope later renamed it as the Pontifical Commission for the Cultural Heritage of the Church and made it an autonomous department with its own president and staff, maintaining periodic contact with the Pontifical Council for Culture (John Paul II 1993). PCCHC became a consultative body and an independent working entity within the CBCP with its own chairperson (always a bishop) and an executive secretary (a priest). It is internally organized with an executive board of four bishop-members and an advisory board of appointed lay experts drawn from the multidisciplinary sciences of cultural heritage studies.

The PCCHC’s defined mandate is to preside over the guardianship of the historical and artistic patrimony of the local church in the Philippines. It exercises this mandate by promoting the ecclesiastical cultural heritage as an invaluable aid to evangelization and catechesis, fomenting research on and understanding of the ecclesiastical cultural properties, initiating and sustaining collaboration between the CBCP and parallel government agencies and nongovernment institutions involved in the care, conservation, and appreciation of the ecclesiastical cultural patrimony, and undertaking projects in different ecclesiastical territories in the country upon invitation or authorization of and collaboration with the diocesan bishops concerned (CBCP 2000). PCCHC also liaises with the Holy See’s Pontifical Commission for the Cultural Heritage of the Church (Benedict XVI 2000) to assure “a harmonization of objectives and fruitful and reciprocal collaboration” (John Paul II 1993).

The presence of PCCHC as an institutional legation of the CBCP in the National Committee on Monuments and Sites of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts led to the preparation and realization of the Holy See–Republic of the Philippines Agreement on the Cultural Heritage of the Catholic Church in the Philippines, an international accord entered into by the Vatican and the Philippines in 2007, and made effective the following year by which the two sovereign entities commit to cooperate for the conservation of identified tangible cultural heritage resources of the Church in the Philippines (Papal Secretariat 2007).

One of the Permanent Committee’s enduring activities is its biennial National Convention of Church Cultural Heritage Practitioners first held in the Diocese of Tagbilaran, Bohol, in 1999. Serving as a venue for continuing education in this specialized pastoral field, the said convention gathers all administrators, curators, and workers of church heritage all over the Philippine Catholic Church once every two years. Proceedings of the biennial national conventions are published in Pintacasi, the annual journal devoted to the study of the cultural heritage of the Catholic Church in the Philippines.

Among the projects completed by the PCCHC is the writing of a handbook for the proper documentation of church property and the restoration of heritage buildings following the methods of construction appropriate to the building and its construction. The PCCHC has been active in collaborating with the National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP) and the National Museum of the Philippines in documenting and restoring church-related buildings. With NHCP assistance, it worked on the restoration of the Balilihan watchtower / bell tower in Bohol. When a number of the churches listed by the National Museum as national cultural treasures were damaged by the earthquake of Oct 2013 and by typhoon Yolanda in Nov of the same year, the PCCHC worked with the appropriate government agencies to protect the damaged properties and through the parishes gathered volunteers to help in the recovery, sorting, and documentation of pieces of the damaged churches.

A number of problems may be considered obstacles to the proper preservation and protection of church heritage. For one, the legal owner of church property in the Philippines is the territorial bishop. Therefore, the PCCHC, being a national body, does not have absolute control over any church property. A bishop can decide against all objections to do what he thinks best. This has happened in many places where the bishop, through the parish priest, authorized the construction of new buildings that marred the original layout of a colonial-period church. In some cases, the timely intervention of heritage and civic groups and exposure to media, more than the PCCHC, succeeded in stopping such ill-advised initiatives. Moreover, some parish priests have also been instrumental in defacing heritage structures for lack of knowledge about the value of heritage structures. Ironically, some have even resorted to selling church artifacts to raise funds for the maintenance of their heritage sites.

The full protection of such heritage structures faces multiple difficulties and requires multiple solutions. Among these are lack of funds for the maintenance of heritage structures and the lack of formal training or ongoing professional education in matters of culture, art, and heritage conservation among the clergy. Furthermore, the handbook on documentation and conservation of PCCHC is not well known.  Written by Milán Ted D. Torralba

Cesar Concio (Cesar Homero Rosales Concio) was an architect. He was born in Pateros, Rizal on 30 Nov 1907. He died on 27 Apr 2003. His parents were Feliciano Concio and Matea Rosales. His wife was Dr Salud Manalo Concio. They had three children, one of whom, Augusto Horacio, is an architect. Concio finished a bachelor of science in civil engineering at the University of the Philippines (UP), 1928, and architecture at Mapua Institute of Technology, with highest honors, 1932. In 1933, he placed first in the government examination for architects.

While studying, he worked as a draftsman for Andres Luna de San Pedro and was later promoted to apprentice construction supervisor, draftsman-designer, and construction inspector. He was also engaged by Mapua as laboratory and teaching assistant. As a Philippine government pensionado, he pursued further studies in architecture, town planning, and housing at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology where he received his master of arts in 1940.

He worked with the Department of Public Works, 1940-45. In 1945, he formed a partnership with Jesus Bondoc. He headed the Department of Architecture of Mapua, 1946-53, and became its first dean. When the Capital City Planning Commission was created in 1948, with Juan Arellano as general manager, he was appointed executive secretary. He is also a former president of the Philippine Institute of Architects.

His works include UP Diliman’s Palma and Melchor Halls, Protestant Chapel and Fellowship Center; the UP College of Forestry Building in Los Baños; the Insular Life Building in Makati; Ramona Apartments on Adriatico St, Manila; the Union Church of Manila; the Children’s Memorial Hospital (now Fe del Mundo Medical Center) in Quezon City; the Mother of Perpetual Help Church in Baclaran; and several buildings for Silliman University. His works are characterized by a rational approach to design, resulting in logically arranged spaces, neatness of form, and successful adaptation to climate.

In 1969, Concio was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

William Coscolluela (William Vargas Coscolluela) is an architect. He was born in Iloilo City on 27 Jul 1933. His parents are Jose Coscolluela and Juanita Vargas, and he is married to Maria Concepcion Lo. In 1957, Coscolluela graduated from Mapua Institute of Technology with an architecture degree and the Mapua president’s gold medal. After working with Cesar Concio, he set up his own firm. He is a member of the Philippine Institute of Architects and the American Institute of Architects. His early projects were mostly residences. Since the 1970s he has produced 16 high-rise buildings, ranging in height from 14 to 32 stories. His works include office buildings, apartment buildings and condominiums, school buildings, hotels, sports and country clubs, beach resorts, malls, and factories. A registered architect both in the Philippines and in Los Angeles, California, USA, he has designed buildings in Palau, New Guinea, China, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, and the United States.

Among Coscolluela’s major works in Metro Manila are Robinsons Commercial Complex in Quezon City, including a 30-story hotel and a 30-story office building; the 26-story Ayala Twin Towers in Makati; the Alexandra, a complex of 11 buildings in Pasig; the 32-story One Beverly Place in Greenhills, San Juan; the 30-story Wack Wack Twin Towers; the 24-story Skyland Plaza Twin Towers in Makati; the Atrium, Makati; the 256-unit Galeria de Magallanes, Makati; the 400-unit Alabang 400 in Muntinlupa; the Quezon City Sports Club; Ateneo de Manila University’s creativity hub the Areté; the Centro Escolar University complex in Malolos, Bulacan; the Magellan Hotel and Resort complex in Cebu City; the Metro Iloilo Convention Center at Mandurriao, Iloilo; and SM City malls in Quezon City and Cebu.

Partnering with his twin sons, Gary and Gil, his architectural firm is pushing forward the adoption of environmentally sound and sensitive architecture. Coscolluela redesigned SM North EDSA, which has a rooftop garden. The firm designed SM Aura, the redevelopment of the old Iloilo Airport at Mandurriao, and the Zuellig Building in Makati, the first building in the Philippines given a platinum certification, the highest rating for a “green building,” by the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design or LEED, 2013.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

article.value: Among Coscolluela’s major works in Metro Manila are Robinsons Commercial Complex in Quezon City, including a 30-story hotel and a 30-story office building; the 26-story Ayala Twin Towers in Makati; the Alexandra, a complex of 11 buildings in Pasig; the 32-story One Beverly Place in Greenhills, San Juan; the 30-story Wack Wack Twin Towers; the 24-story Skyland Plaza Twin Towers in Makati; the Atrium, Makati; the 256-unit Galeria de Magallanes, Makati; the 400-unit Alabang 400 in Muntinlupa; the Quezon City Sports Club; Ateneo de Manila University’s creativity hub the Areté; the Centro Escolar University complex in Malolos, Bulacan; the Magellan Hotel and Resort complex in Cebu City; the Metro Iloilo Convention Center at Mandurriao, Iloilo; and SM City malls in Quezon City and Cebu.

Partnering with his twin sons, Gary and Gil, his architectural firm is pushing forward the adoption of environmentally sound and sensitive architecture. Coscolluela redesigned SM North EDSA, which has a rooftop garden. The firm designed SM Aura, the redevelopment of the old Iloilo Airport at Mandurriao, and the Zuellig Building in Makati, the first building in the Philippines given a platinum certification, the highest rating for a “green building,” by the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design or LEED, 2013.
Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

text:
Alicia Coseteng (Alicia Guanco Marquez Lim-Coseteng) was a writer, educator, diplomat, and cultural worker. She was born in Iloilo City on 1 Apr 1931. She died in Manila on 22 Jun 2001. She was the daughter of Jose Asensi Marquez Lim and Judith Siguenza Guanco. She was married to Emerson Tan Coseteng. She finished AB English at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1954, MA English at Cornell University in 1957, and MA Communications at Stanford University in 1967. She studied the colonial art of Mexico under a scholarship from the Mexican government. She taught at the University of the Philippines Diliman, 1958-79, and was principal of the Diliman Preparatory School, 1987-2000. She was president of the Diliman Educational Corporation, 1969-2000; chairman of the San Leonardo Charcoal Briquetting Corporation, 1980-2000; chairman and director of the Diliman Holding Inc and Asia-Pacific Training Institute, 1994-98; and chief of mission, Class II Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to Mexico for the Department of Foreign Affairs, 2000-01. She also served as chairman of the Mass Communication Committee of the UNESCO National Commission, 1965-82; secretary-general, UNESCO National Commission, 1982-83; and chairman of the graduate studies program of the College of Mass Communication, UP Diliman, 1973-79. She was a member of the Association Internationale des Critiques d’Art based in Paris, France.

 

As a writer and art critic, Coseteng was the art columnist for The Manila Chronicle, 1960-61; editorial staff writer for art and cultural editor at the weekly Graphic Magazine, 1965-66; and feature writer in the 1960s for The Manila Times, The Manila Daily Bulletin, and Manila Chronicle Magazine. Her solo-authored books include Spanish Churches in the Philippines, 1971; Folk Media in the Philippines, 1975; and The Philippine Senate, 1997. As editor, she published Philippine Modern Art and Its Critics, 1972. As co-author, she contributed chapters to A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces, 1986, and Art Philippines, 1992. Her research interests included colonial churches in the Philippines, art critical discourses in the Philippines, Philippine folk media and family planning, and teaching humanities in the Philippines. Coseteng’s interests lay primarily in establishing the criollonature of Philippine art. Her fascination with Mexican folk art and its influence on Philippine crafts and culture during the Spanish colonial period was a leitmotif that strung together many of her writings, chiefly Spanish Churches in the Philippines. In addition, her art criticism hewed closely to the formalist method in vogue in the late 1950s to mid-1970s, privileging Philippine expressionists and abstractionists in her critical writings.

 

She received the Outstanding Book Award from the National Academy of Sciences and Technology in 1999 for her work The Philippine Senate. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya and Reuben Ramas Cañete

text:
The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is the leading institution in the country that plans and implements programs for the development and promotion of the arts—music, dance, theater, visual, literary, cinematic, and broadcast arts. Since 1969 when it was created by Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, it has sponsored programs and activities such as festivals, exhibitions, competitions, and publications to preserve, promote, and enhance the artistic and cultural heritage of the Filipino people, and to develop audiences that will appreciate and support artistic and cultural work. It is home to nine resident companies that present regular seasons of productions, workshops, and outreach performances: Ballet Philippines, Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, Philippine Ballet Theatre, Philippine Madrigal Singers, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Tanghalang Pilipino, and UST Symphony Orchestra.

Sitting on a 60-hectare complex on Roxas Boulevard in Pasay City, the CCP is part of a vast international network of arts and culture organizations that provide exchange opportunities between Filipino artists and artists from all over the world. This network also brings in performances and exhibitions that allow local audiences to experience arts and cultures from elsewhere. These organizations include the Association of Asia Pacific Performing Arts Center, the Conseil International des Organisations de Festivals de Folklore et d’Arts Traditionnels, the World Dance Alliance, the International Theater Institute, the Asian Theater Alliance, the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, and the ASEAN–Korea Traditional Music Orchestra.

The CCP is composed of several departments that promote arts education, direct outreach and exchange programs all over the country, mount productions and exhibitions, manage cultural holdings, and develop its assets. In its first two decades the CCP focused on what were later perceived as elitist performing arts—theater, ballet, opera, and similar shows—a bias that was shaped by its first board of trustees chair, then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos. Following the successful EDSA revolt against Marcos and his martial rule and the subsequent change in the country’s leadership, the CCP expanded its scope to include literature, film, and broadcast arts, among others. It also reoriented its direction to emphasize original Filipino artistic and cultural expressions rooted in the Philippines and the participation of the regions in the definition of a national culture.

Music. The CCP is home to the country’s premier symphonic orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). Established in 1973, the PPO (then known as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra) initially accompanied local and foreign performing artists at the CCP. It later evolved as one of the best music ensembles in the Asia-Pacific region, premiering works by Filipino and foreign composers, and promoting music appreciation throughout the country. Past conductors and musical directors of the PPO include Luis Valencia, Oscar Yatco, Ruggero Barbieri, Olivier Ochanine, and Yoshikazu Fukumura.Among the internationally renowned conductors who have performed with the PPO are Mendi Rodan, Piero Gamba, Enrique Batis, Sebastian Bereau, and Nicholas Koch. Some of the world’s best Filipino and foreign artists have also performed with the PPO, including Van Cliburn, Renata Tebaldi, Judith Engel, Anthony Camden, David Benoit, Cecile Licad, Raul Sunico, and Lea Salonga. The PPO is now on its 34th concert season. It has toured in Europe, Asia, and more recently, the United States, when it performed for the first time at the Carnegie Hall. Aside from its regular concert seasons at the CCP, the PPO also participates in the CCP Outreach Program by performing in public spaces and conducting workshops in the provinces.

Another resident company of the CCP is the Philippine Madrigal Singers. Organized in 1963 by Andrea O. Veneracion, later National Artist for music, the choir is composed of students, teachers, and alumni from the various colleges of the University of the Philippines. Performing a wide repertoire of various styles and forms, the ensemble has consistently won all the top prizes in most of the world’s prestigious choral competitions. The choir also maintains an active outreach and concert schedule every year and is regarded as one of the country’s most active ambassadors of goodwill and one of the world’s most traveled choirs.

The UST Symphony Orchestra is also a resident performing group of the CCP. It holds regular concerts at the CCP and participates in the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program. It also serves as a pool for additional players as the needs of the PPO dictate.

In 1987, the CCP launched the Filipino Artists Series (FAS), a monthly program featuring solo performances of acclaimed and emerging Filipino musical artists. Among those featured in the FAS were bass baritone Jonathan Zaens; flutist Antonio Maigue; cellist Wilfredo Pasamba; pianists Corazon Kabayao, Mariel Illusorio, Peter Porticos, and Rene Dalandan; violinists Gilopez Kabayao, Gina Medina, and Denise Huang; and sopranos Clarissa Ocampo and Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro. FAS was discontinued in 2009 but was later revived in 2012 as the Special Concert Series. Some of the performing artists in this series are pianist Charisse Baldoria, soprano Katrina Saporsantos, cellist Antoni Josef Inacay, trumpet player Raymond de Leon, percussionist Aimee Mina dela Cruz, and flutist Sarah Mae Gabuyo.

The CCP also embarked on the production of Filipino operas as well as Western operas that were adapted to a Philippine setting. In 1970, it partnered with the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines in producing El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the operatic adaptation of Jose Rizal’s novel, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon and libretto by Guillermo Tolentino. De Leon and Tolentino’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), first staged at the FEU Auditorium in 1957, was also restaged at the CCP in 1974, with Don David as Ibarra, Ruby Salazar as Maria Clara, Jimmy Melendres as Padre Damaso, and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa. In 1984, the CCP and Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines commissioned Francisco Feliciano to create the three-act opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), with libretto by Cuyugan-Asensio. In 1987, the CCP partnered with Music Theater Foundation in another restaging of Noli… this time with Nolyn Cabahug as Ibarra, Andion Fernandez as Maria Clara, and Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa (alternating with Luz Morete). Rolando Tinio’s Philippine adaptation of La Traviata and La Boheme were also produced by and staged at the CCP in 1991 and 1992, respectively. Two major opera productions of the CCP in the 21st century were Spoliarium , 2003, and Madame Butterfly, 2012. Spoliarium was inspired by Juan Luna ’s life and masterpiece, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, and co-produced by the CCP with the Opera Guild of the Philippines and Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines. Madame Butterfly was a co-production of the CCP and MusicArtes, Inc, with director Anton Juan giving local flavor to Puccini’s famous opera.

The CCP is also the organizer and main proponent of major music festivals including the biennial Andrea Veneracion International Choral Festival and the CCP International Jazz Festival which was merged with the Orchestra and Symphonic Band Festival, and the annual Flute/Woodwind Festival. It has also been actively supporting the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) since its inception in 1973. The CCP Arts Education Department also organizes masterclasses of renowned musical artists as well as yearly workshops in rondalla music, choral music, and band music.

Dance. The CCP has four resident dance companies: Ballet Philippines (BP), which is based at the CCP Main Building, and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFC) which are all based outside the CCP.

Since its founding in 1969, BP has performed over 400 works at the CCP, ranging from full-length classical ballets to modern dance and neo-ethnic pieces, under its founding artistic director Alice Reyes, later National Artist for Dance, and after her, Denisa Reyes, Cecile Sicangco, Noordin Jumalon, Alden Lugnasin, Augustus Damian III, Alan Hineline, Max Luna III, and Paul Morales. The company has also collaborated with prominent foreign and local choreographers, dancers, librettists, actors, and set, costume, and lighting designers. Notable productions of BP include Amada, Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), Rama, Hari, Tales of the Manuvu, Te Deum, For the Gods, Encantada (Enchantress), and La Revolucion Filipina (The Filipino Revolution). It has also produced some of the country’s top ballet dancers who have undergone training at BP’s official school, the CCP Dance School. BP also stages the yearly Neo-Filipino, a dance showcase featuring the latest works of the best and leading choreographers in the country.

Founded in 1987 by artistic directors of different ballet companies, PBT has become one of the country’s leading dance companies specializing in classical ballet. PBT’s regular performance season at the CCP consists of such classics as Romeo and Juliet , Carmen, The Nutcracker, Cinderella, Carmina Burana, and Swan Lake. PBT has been managed by a series of artistic directors, all belonging to the PBT Council, namely, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Julie Borromeo, Eddie Elejar, Gener Caringal, and Ronilo Jaynario.

The Bayanihan, under choreographer Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, later National Artist for Dance, and later, under executive director Susie Benitez and dance director-choreographer Ferdinand Jose, and the ROFG under artistic director Ramon Obusan, later National Artist for dance, and later, under Dulce Obusan, have been acclaimed nationally and worldwide for their continuing efforts to research, perform, preserve, and perpetuate Philippine folk music and dance traditions. Both companies participate in CCP’s outreach programs by conducting folk dance workshops around the country.

Dance-related festivals organized or initiated by the CCP include the Pang-alay, which featured different Philippine folk dance groups; the Fiesta Folkloriada, an annual festival of folk dance groups all over the world where the Bayanihan is an active participant; the biennial CCP Ballet Festival where various ballet schools in the country gather and perform classical, modern, and neo-ethnic works; and Dance.MNL: The Philippine Dance Festival which was held for the first time in 2016. Dance.MNL is also intended to be a biennial festival which aims to unite and celebrate the Filipino dance community.

The CCP has also given grants or financial assistance to local dance groups which represented the Philippines in international competitions or festivals. Among the grantees were the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Dureza Ballet School, Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance, and St Anne’s Dance and Music Studio in 1988; Dance Theater Philippines, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, St Anne Dance Theater Company (Taguig), La Salle Dance Troupe, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Odon Sabarre and the People’s Center School of Dance, and Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center in 1989; Dance Concert Company and Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in 1990; and Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement, Chameleon Dance Company, Araullo University Dance Troupe, and Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe in 1991.

In 2014, the CCP launched its first ever Ballet Competition held at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino. The biennial competition has a Junior and Senior category and requires contestants to perform both classical and contemporary pieces.

Theater. The CCP, in partnership with the NCCA, has organized the National Theater Festival (NTF), a quinquennial event that gathers theater artists, practitioners, scholars, and enthusiasts from all over the country in a 10-day celebration of the latest achievements in Philippine theater. The NTF, which started in 1992 and was last held in 2012, usually includes performances from various theater groups, a conference, exhibits, and film screenings.

During the first NTF, production and festival grants, as well as six workshop and one research grant, were given to the nine participating regional theater groups. These are Adela Community Organization of Silay City, Negros Occidental; the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc.-UHAY of Malolos, Bulacan; Cebu Central Colleges Theater Workshop Company and University of San Carlos Theater Guild of Cebu City; Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo City; Komedya ng San Dionisio of Paranaque; Kulturang Atin Foundation Inc., and Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao City; and the Salidummay Music Theater Company and Tadec Group of Baguio City. Production grants were also given to seven Metro Manila-based groups, namely Bulwagang Gantimpala, Dulaang UP, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, and Tanghalang Pilipino. Many other groups have availed of these grants in subsequent CCP National Theater Festivals.

The CCP has also supported theater groups outside Metro Manila through its Outreach and Exchange Unit. It provided financial assistance to deserving applicants for the touring of produced local productions to different sites within the region. Theater companies that received touring grants are: in 1988, the Dula Agus Ensemble of Butuan City, Salidummay of the Cordillera, and Teatro Amakan of Iloilo; in 1989, the Sining Pananadem in Marawi City, Dance Theater of Tacloban City, and Susi ng Tayabas in Quezon; in 1991, Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna and the Adela Community Organization from Silay City, Negros Occidental; in 1992, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble of the Mindanao State University and the Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao; in 2014, the community-based theater guild in Sorsogon, Teatro Ambahanon and Kabpapagariya Ensemble of General Santos City, the Youth Advocates thru Theater Arts in Dumaguete City, the Integrated Performing Arts Guild in Iligan City, and the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble in Marawi City; and in 2015, Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc. of Malolos City, Artista Sillimania of Dumaguete City, Kuntaw Mindanao of Davao del Norte, and Kaliwat Performing Arts Collective of Davao City. Meanwhile, production venue and full grants were given to Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, UP Playwrights Theater, Telon, Sining Silangan, Philippine Drama Company, UP Repertory Company, Teatro Santa Ana, and Teatro Umalohokan.

In 1994, the CCP Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts awarded playwriting fellowships to four writers, giving them cash grants to develop their full-length plays. The fellows chosen were JB Capino for his play Los Indios Bravos (The Brave Natives), Dennis Marasigan for Aves de Rapina (Birds of Prey), V. E. Carmelo Nadera for Hermano Puli, and Bebot Rodil for Datu Matu.

Prior to its reorganization after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the CCP was the home of two local theater companies: Teatro Pilipino, under artistic director Rolando Tinio, and Bulwagang Gantimpala Theater, under artistic director Tony Espejo. Teatro Pilipino, the first resident theater company of the CCP from 1976-86, staged Filipino translations of plays by William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, August Strindberg, and Tennessee Williams, as well as a few Filipino works like Francisco Baltazar’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Bienvenido M. Noriega’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), and Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason).

Bulwagang Gantimpala started out as the production arm of the winning works from the CCP Literary and Playwriting Contest. It staged original Filipino works like Jomar Fleras’s adaptation of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, titled Kanser (Cancer), Bonifacio Ilagan’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), Rene O. Villanueva’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), and Noriega’s Bongbong at Kris (Bongbong and Kris). In 1987, it became an independent theater company and has since moved its office elsewhere.

Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) is now the resident drama company of the CCP. Established in 1987, TP has staged more than 150 productions and is now on its 30th season. Its founding artistic director was Nonon Padilla who directed the company for 17 years until he was replaced by Herbie Go, Dennis Marasigan, and Nanding Josef. Its repertoire consists of original works by Filipino playwrights, restagings of Filipino sarsuwela, and translations and adaptations of foreign plays. TP maintains a stable of professional actors known as the Tanghalang Pilipino Actors’ Company. The company regularly conducts acting workshops and has also toured some of its productions in various provinces.

TP has also partnered with the CCP, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and the Writer’s Bloc, Inc. in producing the highly successful Virgin Labfest, a laboratory festival of new, unproduced, and untested one-act plays by amateur and veteran playwrights. This yearly project which started in 2005 has now become one of the most anticipated theater events in the country and has also produced a canon of acclaimed works.

In 2011, the CCP and the NCCA organized the first Monodrama Festival, a four-day event featuring monologues and one-actor performances. In 2013, the CCP produced Triple Threats, a series of concerts featuring the stalwarts of Philippine musical theater. Among the artists who have performed for this series are Nonie Buencamino, Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, Audie Gemora, and Bituin Escalante. The series has also featured composers Rony Fortich and Vincent de Jesus in 2015 and ensemble players in 2016.

Visual Arts.
