The CCP through its Visual Arts and Museum Division (VAMD) implements and manages the year-round contemporary art, design, and festival-related exhibitions at the various venues at the CCP. These exhibitions provide a showcase for current directions, trends, and movements in Philippine contemporary art, including the fields of architecture, sculpture, photography, digital art, and the allied arts. Aside from managing exhibit venues, providing curatorial assistance, and organizing forums, lectures, and talkback sessions with artists and designers, the VAMD also coordinates with the visual arts community on the activities and concerns of the visual artists all over the country.

The VAMD has organized and presented exhibits featuring artworks of notable Filipino artists among them: Fernando Amorsolo, Victorio Edades, Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, H. R. Ocampo, Vicente Manansala, Fernando Zobel, Lee Aguinaldo, Constancio Bernardo, Jose Joya, Napoleon Abueva, Roberto Chabet, Arturo Luz, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Ang Kiukok, Justiniano Nuyda, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Romulo Olazo, Ray Albano, Nonon Padilla, Prudencio Lamarroza, Impy Pilapil, Ileana Lee, Danilo Dalena, Onib Olmedo, Jaime de Guzman, Julie Lluch, Solomon Saprid, Ben Maramag, Bencab, Tony Velasquez, Mars Ravelo, Francisco Coching, Roberto Feleo, Kidlat Tahimik, Mark Justiniani, Karen Flores, Claude Tayag, and Agnes Arellano. The VAMD has also presented exhibits of artists’ groups such as the Social Realists, Kasibulan Women Artists, Paete artists, Black Artists of Asia, Abstract Expressionists, Figurative Expressionists, Mabini Art Movement, Salingpusa, Baguio Arts Guild, VIVA Excon, and artists from various schools like the University of the Philippines, University of Santo Tomas, and the Philippine High School for the Arts.

The VAMD also gives recognition to Filipino artists through the 13 Artists Awards. Started by former CCP museum director Roberto Chabet in 1970, the 13 Artists Awards later became a biennial award under the management of Ray Albano, and a triennial award in 2009. The award is given to artists who take “the chance and risk to restructure, restrengthen, and renew art making and art thinking.” Since 2009, the recognition has been given to more than 170 artists in the fields of painting, sculpture, mixed and multi-media, and installation art. The most recent awarding was held in 2018 and the recipients were Zeus Bascon, Bea Camacho, Cian Dayrit, Janos Dela Cruz, Carlo Gabuco, Dina Gadia, Guerrero Habulan, Eisa Jocson, Doktor Karayom, Raffy Napay, Archie Oclos, Lynyrd Paras, and Shireen Seno. The awarding usually coincides with a month-long exhibition of the awardees’ works.

Literature. The Literary Arts division of the CCP, now known as the Intertextual Division (ID), undertakes activities that deal with literary text, performance text, and hypertext. Among its accomplishments is the publication of ANI (Harvest), a literary journal which is now on its 39th edition. The journal features short stories, essays, and poems in Filipino, English, and other Philippine languages. It also took care of other CCP special publications like Himala y Balagtas and Himalay Rizal.

In previous years, the CCP sponsored literary contests and awarded writing grants to writers in Filipino, English, and the major regional languages. It began sponsoring a playwriting contest in 1969 in both English and Filipino. The first winners of the CCP Playwriting Contest were: In Frailty’s Grace by Elsa V. Martinez, first prize; And the Day But One by Jose Ma. Hernandez, second; and The Onyx Wolf by Virginia Moreno, third; Tabak at Tanikala (Bolo and Chain) by Dionisio S. Salazar; Status Quo by Angel R. Makiling, and Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss the Sword) by Cipriano V. Ilagan, honorable mention.

A verse writing category was added in 1973. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Interior), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for "Doktrinang Anakpawis" (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The following categories were added in 1974: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel, won by Benjamin P. Pascual for “Utos ng Hari” (King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age). A biography category was added in 1979. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980 in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize when the award for the category was resumed in 1984 for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).

A new category—criticism—was added in 1984. In the English division, an Appreciation Award was shared among Nick Nicolas Jr for “Theater, Films and Others: A Compendium of Critical Reviews,” Wilhelmina Q. Ramas for “Sugbuanon Theater: From Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar,” and Soledad S. Reyes for “Criticism and Ideology.” In the Filipino division, the grand prize in criticism was given to Virgilio S. Almario for “Taludtod at Talinghaga: Mga Sangkap ng Katutubong Pagtula” (Verses and Metaphor: The Elements of Folk Poetry).

In 1987, the annual literary contest was transformed into the Gawad CCP Para sa Panatikan under the supervision of the CCP’s Coordinating Center for Literature. The contest dropped the English category in favor of an all-Filipino rule. The categories were poetry, short story, one-act play, three-act play, dance libretto (one-act dance drama), and the full-length musical drama.

The winners in the poetry category that year were Fidel D. Rillo for “Musa Insurekta” (Insurgent Muse), first prize; Teo Antonio for “Cespora Personata at Iba Pang Pagbubulay-bulay” (Cespora Personata and Other Ruminations), second prize; and Danton Remoto for “Kuwaderno” (Notebook), third prize. In the short story category, the winners were Reynaldo Duque for “Ang Gamugamo sa Lampara ni Julio Madarang” (The Firefly About Julio Madarang’s Lamp), first prize; Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez for “Kulas,” second prize; and Tomas F. Agulto for “Ang Walang Lubay na Istasyon ng Pag-asa at Paghahanap” (The Eternal Station of Hope and Searching), third prize. The critical essay category on the different arts was instituted a year later.

The winning poems and stories in the Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan have also been published in ANI, while the critical works have appeared in Kultura, the CCP magazine for critical essays. The Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan was discontinued in 1990.

The CCP has also given grants to writers who applied for writing grants for drama in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in the performing arts. Grantees in drama are Reynaldo Duque, 1988, and Jose A. Bragado, 1989, for Ilocano; Ruperto Alaura, 1988, RobertoVillanueva, 1989, and Leonilo Estimo, 1993, for Cebuano; Carlos Ojeda Aureus, 1992, for Bicolano; Julian Jagudilla, 1989 and 1990, and Jose Galiza and Eugenio de Pablo, 1991, for Hiligaynon/Karay-a; and Rene O. Villanueva, 1988, and Ariel N. Valerio, 1993, for Filipino.

In 2015, the ID spearheaded the biennial event called Performatura 2015, Performing Literatures, a three-day intertextual festival held in various venues at the CCP. The event included conversations with National Artists; Chromatext Rebooted, an exhibit merging text and visual arts; performance poetry featuring young poets; and workshops on the poetic joust balagtasan, speech choir, and ventriloquism.

Film. The Media Arts Division is the main implementor of the CCP’s year-round film, broadcast, and emerging media events, which include screenings, productions, festivals, awards, workshops, and fora. It also coordinates with all sectors of the film community—both local and international, independent and mainstream, contemporary and classic.

In 1987, the CCP started to give recognition to Filipino alternative films and video. Known as the Gawad CCP Para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Bidyo or Gawad Alternatibo, this is considered the longest-running independent film competition of its kind in the Asian region. Gawad Alternatibo annually cites the best efforts of Pinoy filmmakers in four categories: Animation, Experimental, Documentary, and Short Feature. Each winner receives a cash prize and a certificate. Special citations are also awarded to the best work from the regions, as well as works on/for/by children. Many of today’s outstanding filmmakers and media practitioners are awardees of Gawad Alternatibo.

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival is one of the CCP’s most important cinema-related undertakings every year. Established in 2004, the festival has given birth to some of Philippine cinema’s contemporary masterpieces and is regarded as one of the most prestigious independent film competitions in the country, and a much awaited cultural event as well. Some of today’s acclaimed filmmakers have launched their careers via the annual festival and competition, including Kanakan Balintagos aka Aureaus Solito, Lawrence Fajardo, Chris Martinez, Jun Robles Lana, Alvin B. Yapan, Francis Pasion, and Eduardo Roy Jr. Simultaneous film-related events are also held during the festival, including the Cinemalaya Film Congress, a two-day conference that looks at all aspects of independent filmmaking and distribution; the Cinemalaya Sine Taktakan, a forum with the year’s batch of new Cinemalaya filmmakers; exhibitions that include Tributes to Past Indie Mavericks of Pinoy Cinema; a Cinemalaya Kids’ Treats; World Premieres of New Digital Works (the Cinemalaya/NETPAC Prize); and a host of other activities.

The CCP also holds annual film lectures and retrospectives on Filipino filmmakers and actors, like Gerardo de Leon, Manuel Conde, Luciano B. Carlos, Mona Lisa, Jaclyn Jose, and Fernando Poe Jr, as well as foreign film artists like Akira Kurosawa, Isabelle Huppert, and Olivier Assayas.

Broadcast Arts. In recognition of the broad reach and powerful influence of radio and television, the CCP established in 1987 a Coordinating Center for Broadcast Arts which was one of the units of the then Visual, Literary, and Media Arts Department. While all these units have been replaced by the Media Arts Division, the CCP—then and now—has continued efforts to equip ordinary citizens with the skills to produce radio programs and videos that reflect their realities and that allow them to promote their sectoral interests through broadcasting. It conducts hands-on training-workshops on radio and television production and scriptwriting, accepts apprenticeships, and awards production grants. While bringing its training program to as far north as Batanes and as far south as Tawi-tawi, the CCP encourages the use of Filipino languages in the programs and videos produced by its trainees. Among those who complete the training programs and are given grants to produce their own radio programs are farmers, fisherfolk, social development and cultural workers, students, and local leaders who produce and host talk shows, historical documentaries, instructional programs, public service announcements, music shows, and dramatizations of Filipino myths and legends. Their productions are aired in cooperation with local radio stations.

The CCP produces television programs as well as videos. In 1990 it produced Pinoy Eh, a magazine show aired on ABC Channel 5. Directed by Marilou-Diaz-Abaya and hosted by Ces Quesada, it had 13 episodes on such topics as the Filipino language, music, cinema, architecture, literature, dance, rituals, ethnic groups, and places. Another television production is the 1992 13-episode drama series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) based on Jose Rizal’s novel, written and directed by National Artist for cinema Eddie Romero, starring Joel Torre and Chin-chin Gutierrez. The series is also available in DVD. The Red Carpet was a monthly program aired on Net 25 in 2009-12, featuring the shows at CCP and the cultural and artistic scene in the country. On Set, also on Net 25, 2009-12, highlighted the country’s top caliber artists such as Lea Salonga, Ryan Cayabyab, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

CCP is also on radio. Following the 1986 EDSA revolt, it produced the weekly radio magazine Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), aired on DZRV in 1986-92, then on DZRM until 1996. It featured Filipino music and theater, talked about arts and culture in the Philippines, and held the balagtasan on current socio-political issues. Among CCP’s current radio programs is the weekly Culture Carousel, which has been airing on DZFE since 1990. It features CCP music artists as well as visiting music artists and airs their performances. Another production is DiskArte (Artistic Strategy) which discusses social issues using the arts. It airs on DZRH in partnership with the Manila Broadcasting Corporation (MBC). The program was formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon (Fight Corruption) which aired on DZRH in 2004-08 until it was reformatted. It was awarded The Freedom Project 2013 Jury Prize and the People’s Choice Award by The Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom of Germany. Another CCP radio production was the children’s show Wan Dey Isang Araw (One Day), aired on DZAS in 2005-13, which tried to revive the tradition of storytelling in the Philippines. It featured stories by Luis P. Gatmaitan, Eugene Evasco, Augie Rivera, and Grace Chong.

In 1987-98, the CCP gave out the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon (CCP Awards for Television), annually to outstanding television programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and other content producers. Among the awardees were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You) and Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), the drama series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Lovingly Yours, Helen, the children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong), the talk show Pep Talk, the public affairs programs Probe Team, Public Forum, and Viewpoint, and the gag show Sic O’Clock News. In 1990-1998, the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo (CCP Awards for Radio) was given at the same time as the television awards, to outstanding radio programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and music and sound designers. The radio awards were henceforth given every two years. Among the awardees in 1990 were the documentary Parangal (Tribute), on DZRM; the drama series Drama Filipina on DZEC, the arts and culture show Filipiniana on DZLC in Lucena, the music magazine shows Yukbo sa Musika on DYMR and Salam in sa Kaliwat on DXWG, both in Cebu, and radio pioneer Francisco “Koko” Trinidad for his contribution to Philippine radio.

Other Programs. The CCP organizes various year-round arts-affiliated events, such as Pasinaya, the biggest multi-arts festival in the country. Started in 2010, Pasinaya is an annual one-day open-house festival which serves as a gathering of CCP resident companies, patrons, and the general public. Simultaneous events are held in all of CCP’s venues, with designated zones for dance, theater, music, literature, film, visual arts, children and family, variety, and the artists market. There are also crash workshops, film screenings, visual arts exhibitions, food booths, and activities for children. Some of the resident companies also perform excerpts from their upcoming shows or past productions.

Outreach and exchange programs include: KUTITAP: Isang Piging ng Kabataang Makasining, an annual three-day event for children and young people that started in 2009 and is aimed at raising their awareness of and appreciation for indigenous arts, culture, and traditions; Ugnayan sa Sining, an annual series of cultural exchanges and community tours featuring some of the country’s prominent regional cultural groups; Lakbay Sining, a national touring program which features performances from CCP resident companies or art exhibitions previously mounted at the CCP; Kaisa sa Sining, a program which links CCP to regional cultural groups in order to facilitate regional cultural development, exchanges, artistic programs, and collaborations; Lakbay Sine, a project of CCP Media Arts Division; and Lakbay Harana , a joint project of the CCP and Tribung Pilipino Foundation which aims to promote and reawaken the public’s, and especially the young generation’s, interest and appreciation for Philippine traditional music like the kundiman, balitaw, danza, and immortal Filipino love songs. The CCP through its Cultural Exchange Department also provides local tour grants for regional performing groups. It is also active in giving art therapy workshops—called Kalinga ng Sining—in provincial areas devastated by natural calamities or armed conflicts.

The CCP has occasionally engaged in film production. It produced two movies: Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero, and Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

A heritage project of the CCP is the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art. First published in 1994, the CCP Encyclopedia remains to be the most authoritative and most comprehensive sourcebook on Philippine art, with volumes on the peoples of the Philippines, architecture, visual arts, dance, music, theater, film, literature, and broadcast arts. Prior to the encyclopedia, the CCP also published beginning in 1989, 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, known collectively as Tuklas Sining. The first essays on the seven arts were compiled and published in a coffee table book with the same title in 1991. To encourage the staging of more sarsuwela, the CCP came out with the sarsuwela series which made available to scholars and performing groups the scripts and music of the classic Tagalog sarsuwela Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), and Walang Sugat (No Wounds) as performed and staged by Tanghalang Pilipino. The initial publication in 1991 included the cassette tapes and books for Paglipas ng Dilim and Dalagang Bukid, and in 1994, for Walang Sugat. The videotaped performances of Dalagang Bukid and Walang Sugat were released in DVD format in 2007.

The Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is the highest recognition awarded by the CCP to artists or groups of artists who have produced a body of outstanding works and excelled in their chosen artform. The award is also given to cultural workers who have helped in enriching Philippine art through their works in research, curatorship, and administration. The Tanging Parangal is given to individuals or organizations to honor their outstanding contributions to the development of the arts in the country.The first Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, then called by another name, was given in 1977 to Hubertus Kuhne (for cultural administration). The award was given annually from 1989 up to 1994, and thereafter every three years. The most recent conferment was in 2015 and the awardees were: Denisa Reyes for Dance; Fides Cuyugan-Asensio for Music; Antonio Mabesa for Theater; Roberto Chabet for Visual Arts; Ricardo Lee for Literature; Nora Aunor for Film and Broadcast Arts; Paulo Alcazaren for Architecture; and Ben Farrales for Design. Leoncio Deriada, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Talaandig School of Living Traditions, and The Missionary Society of St. Columban received the Tanging Parangal.

The Order of the National Artists, the highest state honor given every three years to individuals who have made significant contributions in Philippine arts, was administered by the CCP from 1972 to 1992, and after that, by the CCP and NCCA. The award is conferred by the President of the Republic of the Philippines upon the recommendation of the CCP and NCCA.Fernando Amorsolo was posthumously conferred the first National Artist Award in 1977. The award was most recently conferred in 2018to Larry Alcala (visual arts, posthumous), Resil B. Mojares and Ramon Muzones (literature), Francisco Mañosa (architecture), Ryan Cayabyab (music), and Kidlat Tahimik (film).  Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Lily Grace Tabanera, and Elmer L. Gatchalian

article.value: Sitting on a 60-hectare complex on Roxas Boulevard in Pasay City, the CCP is part of a vast international network of arts and culture organizations that provide exchange opportunities between Filipino artists and artists from all over the world. This network also brings in performances and exhibitions that allow local audiences to experience arts and cultures from elsewhere. These organizations include the Association of Asia Pacific Performing Arts Center, the Conseil International des Organisations de Festivals de Folklore et d’Arts Traditionnels, the World Dance Alliance, the International Theater Institute, the Asian Theater Alliance, the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, and the ASEAN–Korea Traditional Music Orchestra.

The CCP is composed of several departments that promote arts education, direct outreach and exchange programs all over the country, mount productions and exhibitions, manage cultural holdings, and develop its assets. In its first two decades the CCP focused on what were later perceived as elitist performing arts—theater, ballet, opera, and similar shows—a bias that was shaped by its first board of trustees chair, then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos. Following the successful EDSA revolt against Marcos and his martial rule and the subsequent change in the country’s leadership, the CCP expanded its scope to include literature, film, and broadcast arts, among others. It also reoriented its direction to emphasize original Filipino artistic and cultural expressions rooted in the Philippines and the participation of the regions in the definition of a national culture.

Music. The CCP is home to the country’s premier symphonic orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). Established in 1973, the PPO (then known as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra) initially accompanied local and foreign performing artists at the CCP. It later evolved as one of the best music ensembles in the Asia-Pacific region, premiering works by Filipino and foreign composers, and promoting music appreciation throughout the country. Past conductors and musical directors of the PPO include Luis Valencia, Oscar Yatco, Ruggero Barbieri, Olivier Ochanine, and Yoshikazu Fukumura.Among the internationally renowned conductors who have performed with the PPO are Mendi Rodan, Piero Gamba, Enrique Batis, Sebastian Bereau, and Nicholas Koch. Some of the world’s best Filipino and foreign artists have also performed with the PPO, including Van Cliburn, Renata Tebaldi, Judith Engel, Anthony Camden, David Benoit, Cecile Licad, Raul Sunico, and Lea Salonga. The PPO is now on its 34th concert season. It has toured in Europe, Asia, and more recently, the United States, when it performed for the first time at the Carnegie Hall. Aside from its regular concert seasons at the CCP, the PPO also participates in the CCP Outreach Program by performing in public spaces and conducting workshops in the provinces.

Another resident company of the CCP is the Philippine Madrigal Singers. Organized in 1963 by Andrea O. Veneracion, later National Artist for music, the choir is composed of students, teachers, and alumni from the various colleges of the University of the Philippines. Performing a wide repertoire of various styles and forms, the ensemble has consistently won all the top prizes in most of the world’s prestigious choral competitions. The choir also maintains an active outreach and concert schedule every year and is regarded as one of the country’s most active ambassadors of goodwill and one of the world’s most traveled choirs.

The UST Symphony Orchestra is also a resident performing group of the CCP. It holds regular concerts at the CCP and participates in the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program. It also serves as a pool for additional players as the needs of the PPO dictate.

In 1987, the CCP launched the Filipino Artists Series (FAS), a monthly program featuring solo performances of acclaimed and emerging Filipino musical artists. Among those featured in the FAS were bass baritone Jonathan Zaens; flutist Antonio Maigue; cellist Wilfredo Pasamba; pianists Corazon Kabayao, Mariel Illusorio, Peter Porticos, and Rene Dalandan; violinists Gilopez Kabayao, Gina Medina, and Denise Huang; and sopranos Clarissa Ocampo and Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro. FAS was discontinued in 2009 but was later revived in 2012 as the Special Concert Series. Some of the performing artists in this series are pianist Charisse Baldoria, soprano Katrina Saporsantos, cellist Antoni Josef Inacay, trumpet player Raymond de Leon, percussionist Aimee Mina dela Cruz, and flutist Sarah Mae Gabuyo.

The CCP also embarked on the production of Filipino operas as well as Western operas that were adapted to a Philippine setting. In 1970, it partnered with the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines in producing El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the operatic adaptation of Jose Rizal’s novel, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon and libretto by Guillermo Tolentino. De Leon and Tolentino’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), first staged at the FEU Auditorium in 1957, was also restaged at the CCP in 1974, with Don David as Ibarra, Ruby Salazar as Maria Clara, Jimmy Melendres as Padre Damaso, and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa. In 1984, the CCP and Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines commissioned Francisco Feliciano to create the three-act opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), with libretto by Cuyugan-Asensio. In 1987, the CCP partnered with Music Theater Foundation in another restaging of Noli… this time with Nolyn Cabahug as Ibarra, Andion Fernandez as Maria Clara, and Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa (alternating with Luz Morete). Rolando Tinio’s Philippine adaptation of La Traviata and La Boheme were also produced by and staged at the CCP in 1991 and 1992, respectively. Two major opera productions of the CCP in the 21st century were Spoliarium , 2003, and Madame Butterfly, 2012. Spoliarium was inspired by Juan Luna ’s life and masterpiece, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, and co-produced by the CCP with the Opera Guild of the Philippines and Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines. Madame Butterfly was a co-production of the CCP and MusicArtes, Inc, with director Anton Juan giving local flavor to Puccini’s famous opera.

The CCP is also the organizer and main proponent of major music festivals including the biennial Andrea Veneracion International Choral Festival and the CCP International Jazz Festival which was merged with the Orchestra and Symphonic Band Festival, and the annual Flute/Woodwind Festival. It has also been actively supporting the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) since its inception in 1973. The CCP Arts Education Department also organizes masterclasses of renowned musical artists as well as yearly workshops in rondalla music, choral music, and band music.

Dance. The CCP has four resident dance companies: Ballet Philippines (BP), which is based at the CCP Main Building, and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFC) which are all based outside the CCP.

Since its founding in 1969, BP has performed over 400 works at the CCP, ranging from full-length classical ballets to modern dance and neo-ethnic pieces, under its founding artistic director Alice Reyes, later National Artist for Dance, and after her, Denisa Reyes, Cecile Sicangco, Noordin Jumalon, Alden Lugnasin, Augustus Damian III, Alan Hineline, Max Luna III, and Paul Morales. The company has also collaborated with prominent foreign and local choreographers, dancers, librettists, actors, and set, costume, and lighting designers. Notable productions of BP include Amada, Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), Rama, Hari, Tales of the Manuvu, Te Deum, For the Gods, Encantada (Enchantress), and La Revolucion Filipina (The Filipino Revolution). It has also produced some of the country’s top ballet dancers who have undergone training at BP’s official school, the CCP Dance School. BP also stages the yearly Neo-Filipino, a dance showcase featuring the latest works of the best and leading choreographers in the country.

Founded in 1987 by artistic directors of different ballet companies, PBT has become one of the country’s leading dance companies specializing in classical ballet. PBT’s regular performance season at the CCP consists of such classics as Romeo and Juliet , Carmen, The Nutcracker, Cinderella, Carmina Burana, and Swan Lake. PBT has been managed by a series of artistic directors, all belonging to the PBT Council, namely, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Julie Borromeo, Eddie Elejar, Gener Caringal, and Ronilo Jaynario.

The Bayanihan, under choreographer Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, later National Artist for Dance, and later, under executive director Susie Benitez and dance director-choreographer Ferdinand Jose, and the ROFG under artistic director Ramon Obusan, later National Artist for dance, and later, under Dulce Obusan, have been acclaimed nationally and worldwide for their continuing efforts to research, perform, preserve, and perpetuate Philippine folk music and dance traditions. Both companies participate in CCP’s outreach programs by conducting folk dance workshops around the country.

Dance-related festivals organized or initiated by the CCP include the Pang-alay, which featured different Philippine folk dance groups; the Fiesta Folkloriada, an annual festival of folk dance groups all over the world where the Bayanihan is an active participant; the biennial CCP Ballet Festival where various ballet schools in the country gather and perform classical, modern, and neo-ethnic works; and Dance.MNL: The Philippine Dance Festival which was held for the first time in 2016. Dance.MNL is also intended to be a biennial festival which aims to unite and celebrate the Filipino dance community.

The CCP has also given grants or financial assistance to local dance groups which represented the Philippines in international competitions or festivals. Among the grantees were the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Dureza Ballet School, Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance, and St Anne’s Dance and Music Studio in 1988; Dance Theater Philippines, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, St Anne Dance Theater Company (Taguig), La Salle Dance Troupe, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Odon Sabarre and the People’s Center School of Dance, and Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center in 1989; Dance Concert Company and Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in 1990; and Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement, Chameleon Dance Company, Araullo University Dance Troupe, and Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe in 1991.

In 2014, the CCP launched its first ever Ballet Competition held at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino. The biennial competition has a Junior and Senior category and requires contestants to perform both classical and contemporary pieces.

Theater. The CCP, in partnership with the NCCA, has organized the National Theater Festival (NTF), a quinquennial event that gathers theater artists, practitioners, scholars, and enthusiasts from all over the country in a 10-day celebration of the latest achievements in Philippine theater. The NTF, which started in 1992 and was last held in 2012, usually includes performances from various theater groups, a conference, exhibits, and film screenings.

During the first NTF, production and festival grants, as well as six workshop and one research grant, were given to the nine participating regional theater groups. These are Adela Community Organization of Silay City, Negros Occidental; the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc.-UHAY of Malolos, Bulacan; Cebu Central Colleges Theater Workshop Company and University of San Carlos Theater Guild of Cebu City; Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo City; Komedya ng San Dionisio of Paranaque; Kulturang Atin Foundation Inc., and Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao City; and the Salidummay Music Theater Company and Tadec Group of Baguio City. Production grants were also given to seven Metro Manila-based groups, namely Bulwagang Gantimpala, Dulaang UP, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, and Tanghalang Pilipino. Many other groups have availed of these grants in subsequent CCP National Theater Festivals.

The CCP has also supported theater groups outside Metro Manila through its Outreach and Exchange Unit. It provided financial assistance to deserving applicants for the touring of produced local productions to different sites within the region. Theater companies that received touring grants are: in 1988, the Dula Agus Ensemble of Butuan City, Salidummay of the Cordillera, and Teatro Amakan of Iloilo; in 1989, the Sining Pananadem in Marawi City, Dance Theater of Tacloban City, and Susi ng Tayabas in Quezon; in 1991, Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna and the Adela Community Organization from Silay City, Negros Occidental; in 1992, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble of the Mindanao State University and the Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao; in 2014, the community-based theater guild in Sorsogon, Teatro Ambahanon and Kabpapagariya Ensemble of General Santos City, the Youth Advocates thru Theater Arts in Dumaguete City, the Integrated Performing Arts Guild in Iligan City, and the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble in Marawi City; and in 2015, Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc. of Malolos City, Artista Sillimania of Dumaguete City, Kuntaw Mindanao of Davao del Norte, and Kaliwat Performing Arts Collective of Davao City. Meanwhile, production venue and full grants were given to Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, UP Playwrights Theater, Telon, Sining Silangan, Philippine Drama Company, UP Repertory Company, Teatro Santa Ana, and Teatro Umalohokan.

In 1994, the CCP Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts awarded playwriting fellowships to four writers, giving them cash grants to develop their full-length plays. The fellows chosen were JB Capino for his play Los Indios Bravos (The Brave Natives), Dennis Marasigan for Aves de Rapina (Birds of Prey), V. E. Carmelo Nadera for Hermano Puli, and Bebot Rodil for Datu Matu.

Prior to its reorganization after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the CCP was the home of two local theater companies: Teatro Pilipino, under artistic director Rolando Tinio, and Bulwagang Gantimpala Theater, under artistic director Tony Espejo. Teatro Pilipino, the first resident theater company of the CCP from 1976-86, staged Filipino translations of plays by William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, August Strindberg, and Tennessee Williams, as well as a few Filipino works like Francisco Baltazar’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Bienvenido M. Noriega’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), and Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason).

Bulwagang Gantimpala started out as the production arm of the winning works from the CCP Literary and Playwriting Contest. It staged original Filipino works like Jomar Fleras’s adaptation of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, titled Kanser (Cancer), Bonifacio Ilagan’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), Rene O. Villanueva’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), and Noriega’s Bongbong at Kris (Bongbong and Kris). In 1987, it became an independent theater company and has since moved its office elsewhere.

Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) is now the resident drama company of the CCP. Established in 1987, TP has staged more than 150 productions and is now on its 30th season. Its founding artistic director was Nonon Padilla who directed the company for 17 years until he was replaced by Herbie Go, Dennis Marasigan, and Nanding Josef. Its repertoire consists of original works by Filipino playwrights, restagings of Filipino sarsuwela, and translations and adaptations of foreign plays. TP maintains a stable of professional actors known as the Tanghalang Pilipino Actors’ Company. The company regularly conducts acting workshops and has also toured some of its productions in various provinces.

TP has also partnered with the CCP, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and the Writer’s Bloc, Inc. in producing the highly successful Virgin Labfest, a laboratory festival of new, unproduced, and untested one-act plays by amateur and veteran playwrights. This yearly project which started in 2005 has now become one of the most anticipated theater events in the country and has also produced a canon of acclaimed works.

In 2011, the CCP and the NCCA organized the first Monodrama Festival, a four-day event featuring monologues and one-actor performances. In 2013, the CCP produced Triple Threats, a series of concerts featuring the stalwarts of Philippine musical theater. Among the artists who have performed for this series are Nonie Buencamino, Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, Audie Gemora, and Bituin Escalante. The series has also featured composers Rony Fortich and Vincent de Jesus in 2015 and ensemble players in 2016.

Visual Arts. The CCP through its Visual Arts and Museum Division (VAMD) implements and manages the year-round contemporary art, design, and festival-related exhibitions at the various venues at the CCP. These exhibitions provide a showcase for current directions, trends, and movements in Philippine contemporary art, including the fields of architecture, sculpture, photography, digital art, and the allied arts. Aside from managing exhibit venues, providing curatorial assistance, and organizing forums, lectures, and talkback sessions with artists and designers, the VAMD also coordinates with the visual arts community on the activities and concerns of the visual artists all over the country.

The VAMD has organized and presented exhibits featuring artworks of notable Filipino artists among them: Fernando Amorsolo, Victorio Edades, Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, H. R. Ocampo, Vicente Manansala, Fernando Zobel, Lee Aguinaldo, Constancio Bernardo, Jose Joya, Napoleon Abueva, Roberto Chabet, Arturo Luz, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Ang Kiukok, Justiniano Nuyda, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Romulo Olazo, Ray Albano, Nonon Padilla, Prudencio Lamarroza, Impy Pilapil, Ileana Lee, Danilo Dalena, Onib Olmedo, Jaime de Guzman, Julie Lluch, Solomon Saprid, Ben Maramag, Bencab, Tony Velasquez, Mars Ravelo, Francisco Coching, Roberto Feleo, Kidlat Tahimik, Mark Justiniani, Karen Flores, Claude Tayag, and Agnes Arellano. The VAMD has also presented exhibits of artists’ groups such as the Social Realists, Kasibulan Women Artists, Paete artists, Black Artists of Asia, Abstract Expressionists, Figurative Expressionists, Mabini Art Movement, Salingpusa, Baguio Arts Guild, VIVA Excon, and artists from various schools like the University of the Philippines, University of Santo Tomas, and the Philippine High School for the Arts.

The VAMD also gives recognition to Filipino artists through the 13 Artists Awards. Started by former CCP museum director Roberto Chabet in 1970, the 13 Artists Awards later became a biennial award under the management of Ray Albano, and a triennial award in 2009. The award is given to artists who take “the chance and risk to restructure, restrengthen, and renew art making and art thinking.” Since 2009, the recognition has been given to more than 170 artists in the fields of painting, sculpture, mixed and multi-media, and installation art. The most recent awarding was held in 2018 and the recipients were Zeus Bascon, Bea Camacho, Cian Dayrit, Janos Dela Cruz, Carlo Gabuco, Dina Gadia, Guerrero Habulan, Eisa Jocson, Doktor Karayom, Raffy Napay, Archie Oclos, Lynyrd Paras, and Shireen Seno. The awarding usually coincides with a month-long exhibition of the awardees’ works.

Literature. The Literary Arts division of the CCP, now known as the Intertextual Division (ID), undertakes activities that deal with literary text, performance text, and hypertext. Among its accomplishments is the publication of ANI (Harvest), a literary journal which is now on its 39th edition. The journal features short stories, essays, and poems in Filipino, English, and other Philippine languages. It also took care of other CCP special publications like Himala y Balagtas and Himalay Rizal.

In previous years, the CCP sponsored literary contests and awarded writing grants to writers in Filipino, English, and the major regional languages. It began sponsoring a playwriting contest in 1969 in both English and Filipino. The first winners of the CCP Playwriting Contest were: In Frailty’s Grace by Elsa V. Martinez, first prize; And the Day But One by Jose Ma. Hernandez, second; and The Onyx Wolf by Virginia Moreno, third; Tabak at Tanikala (Bolo and Chain) by Dionisio S. Salazar; Status Quo by Angel R. Makiling, and Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss the Sword) by Cipriano V. Ilagan, honorable mention.

A verse writing category was added in 1973. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Interior), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for "Doktrinang Anakpawis" (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The following categories were added in 1974: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel, won by Benjamin P. Pascual for “Utos ng Hari” (King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age). A biography category was added in 1979. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980 in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize when the award for the category was resumed in 1984 for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).

A new category—criticism—was added in 1984. In the English division, an Appreciation Award was shared among Nick Nicolas Jr for “Theater, Films and Others: A Compendium of Critical Reviews,” Wilhelmina Q. Ramas for “Sugbuanon Theater: From Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar,” and Soledad S. Reyes for “Criticism and Ideology.” In the Filipino division, the grand prize in criticism was given to Virgilio S. Almario for “Taludtod at Talinghaga: Mga Sangkap ng Katutubong Pagtula” (Verses and Metaphor: The Elements of Folk Poetry).

In 1987, the annual literary contest was transformed into the Gawad CCP Para sa Panatikan under the supervision of the CCP’s Coordinating Center for Literature. The contest dropped the English category in favor of an all-Filipino rule. The categories were poetry, short story, one-act play, three-act play, dance libretto (one-act dance drama), and the full-length musical drama.

The winners in the poetry category that year were Fidel D. Rillo for “Musa Insurekta” (Insurgent Muse), first prize; Teo Antonio for “Cespora Personata at Iba Pang Pagbubulay-bulay” (Cespora Personata and Other Ruminations), second prize; and Danton Remoto for “Kuwaderno” (Notebook), third prize. In the short story category, the winners were Reynaldo Duque for “Ang Gamugamo sa Lampara ni Julio Madarang” (The Firefly About Julio Madarang’s Lamp), first prize; Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez for “Kulas,” second prize; and Tomas F. Agulto for “Ang Walang Lubay na Istasyon ng Pag-asa at Paghahanap” (The Eternal Station of Hope and Searching), third prize. The critical essay category on the different arts was instituted a year later.

The winning poems and stories in the Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan have also been published in ANI, while the critical works have appeared in Kultura, the CCP magazine for critical essays. The Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan was discontinued in 1990.

The CCP has also given grants to writers who applied for writing grants for drama in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in the performing arts. Grantees in drama are Reynaldo Duque, 1988, and Jose A. Bragado, 1989, for Ilocano; Ruperto Alaura, 1988, RobertoVillanueva, 1989, and Leonilo Estimo, 1993, for Cebuano; Carlos Ojeda Aureus, 1992, for Bicolano; Julian Jagudilla, 1989 and 1990, and Jose Galiza and Eugenio de Pablo, 1991, for Hiligaynon/Karay-a; and Rene O. Villanueva, 1988, and Ariel N. Valerio, 1993, for Filipino.

In 2015, the ID spearheaded the biennial event called Performatura 2015, Performing Literatures, a three-day intertextual festival held in various venues at the CCP. The event included conversations with National Artists; Chromatext Rebooted, an exhibit merging text and visual arts; performance poetry featuring young poets; and workshops on the poetic joust balagtasan, speech choir, and ventriloquism.

Film. The Media Arts Division is the main implementor of the CCP’s year-round film, broadcast, and emerging media events, which include screenings, productions, festivals, awards, workshops, and fora. It also coordinates with all sectors of the film community—both local and international, independent and mainstream, contemporary and classic.

In 1987, the CCP started to give recognition to Filipino alternative films and video. Known as the Gawad CCP Para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Bidyo or Gawad Alternatibo, this is considered the longest-running independent film competition of its kind in the Asian region. Gawad Alternatibo annually cites the best efforts of Pinoy filmmakers in four categories: Animation, Experimental, Documentary, and Short Feature. Each winner receives a cash prize and a certificate. Special citations are also awarded to the best work from the regions, as well as works on/for/by children. Many of today’s outstanding filmmakers and media practitioners are awardees of Gawad Alternatibo.

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival is one of the CCP’s most important cinema-related undertakings every year. Established in 2004, the festival has given birth to some of Philippine cinema’s contemporary masterpieces and is regarded as one of the most prestigious independent film competitions in the country, and a much awaited cultural event as well. Some of today’s acclaimed filmmakers have launched their careers via the annual festival and competition, including Kanakan Balintagos aka Aureaus Solito, Lawrence Fajardo, Chris Martinez, Jun Robles Lana, Alvin B. Yapan, Francis Pasion, and Eduardo Roy Jr. Simultaneous film-related events are also held during the festival, including the Cinemalaya Film Congress, a two-day conference that looks at all aspects of independent filmmaking and distribution; the Cinemalaya Sine Taktakan, a forum with the year’s batch of new Cinemalaya filmmakers; exhibitions that include Tributes to Past Indie Mavericks of Pinoy Cinema; a Cinemalaya Kids’ Treats; World Premieres of New Digital Works (the Cinemalaya/NETPAC Prize); and a host of other activities.

The CCP also holds annual film lectures and retrospectives on Filipino filmmakers and actors, like Gerardo de Leon, Manuel Conde, Luciano B. Carlos, Mona Lisa, Jaclyn Jose, and Fernando Poe Jr, as well as foreign film artists like Akira Kurosawa, Isabelle Huppert, and Olivier Assayas.

Broadcast Arts. In recognition of the broad reach and powerful influence of radio and television, the CCP established in 1987 a Coordinating Center for Broadcast Arts which was one of the units of the then Visual, Literary, and Media Arts Department. While all these units have been replaced by the Media Arts Division, the CCP—then and now—has continued efforts to equip ordinary citizens with the skills to produce radio programs and videos that reflect their realities and that allow them to promote their sectoral interests through broadcasting. It conducts hands-on training-workshops on radio and television production and scriptwriting, accepts apprenticeships, and awards production grants. While bringing its training program to as far north as Batanes and as far south as Tawi-tawi, the CCP encourages the use of Filipino languages in the programs and videos produced by its trainees. Among those who complete the training programs and are given grants to produce their own radio programs are farmers, fisherfolk, social development and cultural workers, students, and local leaders who produce and host talk shows, historical documentaries, instructional programs, public service announcements, music shows, and dramatizations of Filipino myths and legends. Their productions are aired in cooperation with local radio stations.

The CCP produces television programs as well as videos. In 1990 it produced Pinoy Eh, a magazine show aired on ABC Channel 5. Directed by Marilou-Diaz-Abaya and hosted by Ces Quesada, it had 13 episodes on such topics as the Filipino language, music, cinema, architecture, literature, dance, rituals, ethnic groups, and places. Another television production is the 1992 13-episode drama series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) based on Jose Rizal’s novel, written and directed by National Artist for cinema Eddie Romero, starring Joel Torre and Chin-chin Gutierrez. The series is also available in DVD. The Red Carpet was a monthly program aired on Net 25 in 2009-12, featuring the shows at CCP and the cultural and artistic scene in the country. On Set, also on Net 25, 2009-12, highlighted the country’s top caliber artists such as Lea Salonga, Ryan Cayabyab, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

CCP is also on radio. Following the 1986 EDSA revolt, it produced the weekly radio magazine Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), aired on DZRV in 1986-92, then on DZRM until 1996. It featured Filipino music and theater, talked about arts and culture in the Philippines, and held the balagtasan on current socio-political issues. Among CCP’s current radio programs is the weekly Culture Carousel, which has been airing on DZFE since 1990. It features CCP music artists as well as visiting music artists and airs their performances. Another production is DiskArte (Artistic Strategy) which discusses social issues using the arts. It airs on DZRH in partnership with the Manila Broadcasting Corporation (MBC). The program was formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon (Fight Corruption) which aired on DZRH in 2004-08 until it was reformatted. It was awarded The Freedom Project 2013 Jury Prize and the People’s Choice Award by The Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom of Germany. Another CCP radio production was the children’s show Wan Dey Isang Araw (One Day), aired on DZAS in 2005-13, which tried to revive the tradition of storytelling in the Philippines. It featured stories by Luis P. Gatmaitan, Eugene Evasco, Augie Rivera, and Grace Chong.

In 1987-98, the CCP gave out the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon (CCP Awards for Television), annually to outstanding television programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and other content producers. Among the awardees were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You) and Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), the drama series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Lovingly Yours, Helen, the children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong), the talk show Pep Talk, the public affairs programs Probe Team, Public Forum, and Viewpoint, and the gag show Sic O’Clock News. In 1990-1998, the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo (CCP Awards for Radio) was given at the same time as the television awards, to outstanding radio programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and music and sound designers. The radio awards were henceforth given every two years. Among the awardees in 1990 were the documentary Parangal (Tribute), on DZRM; the drama series Drama Filipina on DZEC, the arts and culture show Filipiniana on DZLC in Lucena, the music magazine shows Yukbo sa Musika on DYMR and Salam in sa Kaliwat on DXWG, both in Cebu, and radio pioneer Francisco “Koko” Trinidad for his contribution to Philippine radio.

Other Programs. The CCP organizes various year-round arts-affiliated events, such as Pasinaya, the biggest multi-arts festival in the country. Started in 2010, Pasinaya is an annual one-day open-house festival which serves as a gathering of CCP resident companies, patrons, and the general public. Simultaneous events are held in all of CCP’s venues, with designated zones for dance, theater, music, literature, film, visual arts, children and family, variety, and the artists market. There are also crash workshops, film screenings, visual arts exhibitions, food booths, and activities for children. Some of the resident companies also perform excerpts from their upcoming shows or past productions.

Outreach and exchange programs include: KUTITAP: Isang Piging ng Kabataang Makasining, an annual three-day event for children and young people that started in 2009 and is aimed at raising their awareness of and appreciation for indigenous arts, culture, and traditions; Ugnayan sa Sining, an annual series of cultural exchanges and community tours featuring some of the country’s prominent regional cultural groups; Lakbay Sining, a national touring program which features performances from CCP resident companies or art exhibitions previously mounted at the CCP; Kaisa sa Sining, a program which links CCP to regional cultural groups in order to facilitate regional cultural development, exchanges, artistic programs, and collaborations; Lakbay Sine, a project of CCP Media Arts Division; and Lakbay Harana , a joint project of the CCP and Tribung Pilipino Foundation which aims to promote and reawaken the public’s, and especially the young generation’s, interest and appreciation for Philippine traditional music like the kundiman, balitaw, danza, and immortal Filipino love songs. The CCP through its Cultural Exchange Department also provides local tour grants for regional performing groups. It is also active in giving art therapy workshops—called Kalinga ng Sining—in provincial areas devastated by natural calamities or armed conflicts.
The CCP has occasionally engaged in film production. It produced two movies: Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero, and Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

A heritage project of the CCP is the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art. First published in 1994, the CCP Encyclopedia remains to be the most authoritative and most comprehensive sourcebook on Philippine art, with volumes on the peoples of the Philippines, architecture, visual arts, dance, music, theater, film, literature, and broadcast arts. Prior to the encyclopedia, the CCP also published beginning in 1989, 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, known collectively as Tuklas Sining. The first essays on the seven arts were compiled and published in a coffee table book with the same title in 1991. To encourage the staging of more sarsuwela, the CCP came out with the sarsuwela series which made available to scholars and performing groups the scripts and music of the classic Tagalog sarsuwela Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), and Walang Sugat (No Wounds) as performed and staged by Tanghalang Pilipino. The initial publication in 1991 included the cassette tapes and books for Paglipas ng Dilim and Dalagang Bukid, and in 1994, for Walang Sugat. The videotaped performances of Dalagang Bukid and Walang Sugat were released in DVD format in 2007.

The Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is the highest recognition awarded by the CCP to artists or groups of artists who have produced a body of outstanding works and excelled in their chosen artform. The award is also given to cultural workers who have helped in enriching Philippine art through their works in research, curatorship, and administration. The Tanging Parangal is given to individuals or organizations to honor their outstanding contributions to the development of the arts in the country.The first Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, then called by another name, was given in 1977 to Hubertus Kuhne (for cultural administration). The award was given annually from 1989 up to 1994, and thereafter every three years. The most recent conferment was in 2015 and the awardees were: Denisa Reyes for Dance; Fides Cuyugan-Asensio for Music; Antonio Mabesa for Theater; Roberto Chabet for Visual Arts; Ricardo Lee for Literature; Nora Aunor for Film and Broadcast Arts; Paulo Alcazaren for Architecture; and Ben Farrales for Design. Leoncio Deriada, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Talaandig School of Living Traditions, and The Missionary Society of St. Columban received the Tanging Parangal.

The Order of the National Artists, the highest state honor given every three years to individuals who have made significant contributions in Philippine arts, was administered by the CCP from 1972 to 1992, and after that, by the CCP and NCCA. The award is conferred by the President of the Republic of the Philippines upon the recommendation of the CCP and NCCA.Fernando Amorsolo was posthumously conferred the first National Artist Award in 1977. The award was most recently conferred in 2018to Larry Alcala (visual arts, posthumous), Resil B. Mojares and Ramon Muzones (literature), Francisco Mañosa (architecture), Ryan Cayabyab (music), and Kidlat Tahimik (film).
Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Lily Grace Tabanera, and Elmer L. Gatchalian

text:
Cresenciano de Castro (Cresenciano Cruz de Castro) was an architect. He was born in Guiguinto, Bulacan on 24 Nov 1927. He died on 15 Feb 1992. The son of Tomas de Castro Sr and Felisa Cruz, he studied at the University of Santo Tomas where he received his architecture degree, 1949, and at Cornell University where he finished his master’s degree, 1952.

De Castro was the consulting architect of several institutions and corporations, among them the Philippine Atomic Energy Commission, the Mindanao State University, Colgate Palmolive Philippines Inc, Shoemart Inc, and the Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter-Day Saints. He was president of the League of Philippine Architects, 1960-62, and a member of the Board of Examiners for Architects of the Professional Regulation Commission, 1975-81. De Castro was also a collector of classic cars and a sportsman. He was president of the C. C. Castro Gun Club and a member and team official of the Philippine Shooting Team, 1968-92.

Among his major projects are 30 meeting houses and various buildings for the Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter-Day Saints; Shoemart buildings in Metro Manila; Mindanao State University buildings in Marawi City; Central Luzon State University buildings in Muñoz, Nueva Ecija; the National Science Development Board complex in Taguig, Metro Manila; the Atomic Research Center complex in Quezon City; the Asian Development Bank (now Department of Foreign Affairs) on Roxas Blvd, Pasay City; various buildings for Colgate-Palmolive Philippines Inc; and the Continental Cement Corporation complex in Norzagaray, Bulacan.

He also designed buildings in Saipan, Guam; Taipei, Taiwan; Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam; and several cities in Saudi Arabia. In the 1960s, De Castro introduced the use of exposed aggregate finish, which eliminates the need to paint and repaint building exteriors. He made extensive use of posttensioning in a number of buildings to maximize clear interior space.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text:
Juan de Ciscara (Juan Ramirez de Ciscara) was a military engineer. He was born in Santiago de Chile on 17 Apr 1671. He died between 1719 and 1732. His parents were Juan de Ciscara Ybañez and Maria Candelaria Ramirez. The older De Ciscara was a military engineer who worked on the fortification of Havana in 1670. Juan followed in his father’s footsteps. His career began as a soldier in Yucatan, Mexico, where he served for a year and three months. By 1692 he had moved to Havana, but despite an official recommendation he was unable to find employment as a military engineer. Back in Mexico, he was appointed assistant engineer under Jaime Franck in 1694.

Demonstrating great competence and enthusiasm, he was promoted to the rank of captain of the infantry in 1695. He was commissioned to examine and propose plans for the fortification of the Barlovento Islands. While his work won the approval of the viceroy, De Ciscara requested to retire from military service but was denied because of lack of military engineers. After years of service, he succeeded Franck in supervising the works on the fortification of Santa Maria de Galve. He was awarded honorary rank of sargento mayor (sergeant major). Another request for retirement in 1702 due to health was granted for a period of four months after which he was called to active service. In Dec 1704, he was assigned to supervise construction at Fort San Diego in Acapulco.

The following year he was in the Philippines, the first military engineer to be sent to the islands, which needed a professional very badly. In Oct 1705, he was busy planning the fortifications of Cavite. He returned to Mexico where in 1713 he replaced Juan Bautista Mazoni as chief engineer. He returned to the Philippines in Jul 1717, accompanied by two servants: Ignacio de la Cruz, a Filipino, and Juan de Irigoyen, a Navarrese. As soon as he arrived, he checked on the progress at Fort Santiago and the walls. Very little is heard about him until a letter from Gov-Gen Fernando Valdes Tamon, addressed to the king and dated 4 Jul 1732, asked to send a military engineer, for there was no one in Manila. Presumably, De Ciscara had died.

De Ciscara worked on Fort San Pedro in Cebu and Fort Santiago in Manila and the rebuilding of Fort Pilar, whose plans he drew in 1719. He also worked on nonmilitary structures like the Manila Cathedral, the church of Nuestra Señora de Guia, the Seminario de San Clemente, and the convento (parish house) of San Juan de Dios de Manila, “of which there remain only drawings” (Luengo 2013). The Dominican provincial, Fr Pedro de Mejorada, asked him to design a chapel for Our Lady of the Rosary, which he provided without any monetary incentive.

Three drawings for the Philippines that De Ciscara made have survived: iconography of the Castle of Santiago, 1714, a proposal for the repair and rehabilitation of Fort Santiago; plan for the Cebu cathedral, 1719; and a map of the Fort of Our Lady of Pilar in Zamboanga, 1719. The plan for the Cebu cathedral is unusual for its coro baxo or bajo, a choir stall in the middle of the nave, similar to those found in Mexico.

The reconstruction of the Cebu cathedral was long delayed. Although royal approval was granted on 27 Oct 1670, the project did not progress much. With the arrival of a new bishop, Fr Miguel Bayot, the construction of the cathedral went on in earnest. Foundations were laid. But with the death of Bishop Bayot, not only was the cathedral left half done but a violent typhoon destroyed what had been built and the cathedral was left in ruins. The new bishop, Foronda, who took over the Diocese of Cebu in 1719, started a new project to build the cathedral. He sent the new plan made by De Ciscara to Manila. However, Manila considered the plan as too grand and more appropriate for a capital, and Cebu did not have the necessary expertise to work on the cathedral. By the time construction on the cathedral got under way in 1735, De Ciscara’s plan was set aside.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

 

Sources

Diaz-Trechuelo, Lourdes. 1959. Arquitectura Española en Filipinas (1565-1800). Sevilla: Escuela de Estudios Hispano-Americanos de Sevilla.

Luengo Gutierrez, Pedro. 2013. Manila, Plaza Fuerte (1762-1788). Ingenieros Militares entre Asia, America y Europa. Madrid: Ministerio de Defensa and Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cientificas.

text:
Domingo de Escondrillas was a director-inspector of public works in Cebu. He was active 1855-93. De Escondrillas was a government functionary who served the Obras Publicas or Public Works offices in Cebu in the mid-19th century. He acted both as architect designing new structures and engineer inspecting churches and public buildings. His area of responsibility included all of Cebu and the adjacent island of Bohol.

His name first appears in a project for the fortification for Tagbilaran, Bohol, in 1855. The sketch for this project is kept in the National Archives or the Records Management and Archives Office. It shows a quadrilateral two-story watchtower with a roof. Its walls have small openings for rifles. De Escondrillas made plans for Talibon church in 1858. It seems he was fond of this project because he signed “DE” over the door of sacristy. He inspected Loboc Church in 1864.

In the National Archives is a plan for Tagbilaran, signed “Tagbilaran, Domingo de Escondrillas.” He directed the construction of a church in Dumanjug, Cebu. Construction began around 1854 and finished in 1864. It was commissioned by the bishop of Cebu, Romualdo Jimeno, OP, while Filipino secular priests, Frs Matias Cabrera and Doroteo Gordinez, were parish priests.

De Escondrillas’s well-known work, considered the best and grandest church built by the Recollects, is the Church of Nuestra Señora de la Luz in Loon, Bohol. Church construction was begun in 1855 and completed in 1864. Loon Church was completely demolished by the earthquake of 15 Oct 2013.

De Escondrillas established the first printing press in Cebu in 1873, but it seems to have lasted only two years.

Another well-known work of Escondrillas is the Carcel de Cebu. This was planned as the provincial jail for Cebu. It was designed beginning 1869 and construction started ca 1871. Completed most likely in 1878, additional structures were added in 1892. The jail is presently Museo Sugbo or the Cebu Museum.

De Escondrillas designed the Church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva in Pardo, Cebu. The church was built from 1890 to 1893. The church facade has two towers flanking the central section that terminates in a pyramidal roof. A rose window pierces the facade.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
Arturo de Santos (Arturo Cabarrus de Santos) was an interior designer. He was born in Binondo, Manila ca 1915. He is the son of Felipe Ong Siaco de Santos and Concepcion Cabarrus. He studied at Ateneo de Manila and then at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he finished a medical degree. While in the United States to specialize in plastic surgery, he shifted to fine arts. At Columbia and Yale Universities, he studied painting, theater set design, and jewelry making.

Back in the Philippines, he applied his artistic training to interior design and worked on the residences of Manila’s rich and famous, including those of tycoons such as Yulo and Madrigal; political clans such as Laurel, Cojuangco, and Lopez; and several presidents of the country. Another of his designs was the residence of Felix Manalo of the Iglesia ni Cristo. De Santos also designed public spaces, such as parts of postwar Manila Hotel including the Chinese Room, the Jungle Bar, and the Champagne Room. He created the honeymoon suite around a mural by National Artist Carlos “Botong” Francisco. In the early 1960s he worked on the Ambassador, the first five-star hotel in Hong Kong, which, like the Manila Hotel, was partly owned by the Zamora family. He also conceptualized the Jewelry Room at the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the receiving room of Imelda Marcos at the Metropolitan Museum, Manila. De Santos is known for his adherence to classical rules of symmetry, his use of subdued colors and fine-quality materials, and his knowledge of art history.  Written by Ramon N. Villegas

text:
Juan de Uguccioni (Giovanni Maria de Uguccioni) was a priest-architect. He was born in Florence ca 1704. He was active 1750-65. A native of Florence, Italy, he was a secular priest who belonged to the Cajetan or Theatine Order. He descended from the Uguccioni family who were influential in Florence since the 16th century. He most likely had an education in his hometown, where classical taste persisted while the baroque was already flourishing in other Italian cities. After Florence, he went to Rome, where he may have come in contact with the baroque, although at this time there were no monumental baroque works being built yet. His architectural style, classicism with a mild touch of baroque, may be explained by his Florentine roots as modified by his Roman formation.

In 1709, the fathers of the Propaganda Fidei in Goa sent petitions to Rome asking for missionaries. All who arrived in Goa were Italians. He worked as a missionary in Bengkulu, Indonesia, where between 1709 and 1719 he assisted in building Fort York, later called Fort Marlborough, for the English. The fort did not last long because in 1719 the native population burnt it. He was in Goa by Jan 1723 where he remained until 1736. He used Goa as a base to travel elsewhere, like Borneo. While at Goa, he wrote a history of his order, Noticia das Missoes dos Clerigos Regulares na India Oriental (Report on the Missions of the Regular Clergy in East India). Architect Esteban de Rojas y Melo, who worked on the Manila Cathedral, affirms that De Uguccioni worked in Goa for three decades.

In 1750, while en route to Goa, De Uguccioni passed by the Philippines without the necessary license. He had been an engineer for the British on the coast of Malabar while serving as missionary of the Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith. His stay in the Philippines was brief and unplanned but was seen as providential, because an engineer was needed by the archbishop of Manila. Earlier, a committee assessing the ruinous state of the Manila Cathedral, which had undergone several typhoons and earthquakes, recommended that the structure be pulled down and one stronger and with better proportions be built. But there was no competent architect who could plan and supervise the rebuilding of the cathedral. Convened by Abp Juan Angel Rodriguez, OST, Abp 1731-42, the committee members who worked on the proposal for a new cathedral were Fr Joaquin Mezquita, SJ, said to be well versed in architecture; Antonio Gonzales de Quijano; and Tomas de Castro y Andrade. The petition to rebuild was sent to the king and was answered by a royal cedula requesting for plans and a budget for the cathedral.

At this point, the archbishop of Manila, Pedro Martinez Arizala, Abp 1744-55, persuaded De Uguccioni to take on the task of architect and overseer for the reconstruction of the Manila Cathedral. Corroborating the earlier assessment, De Uguccioni recommended complete demolition, but due to lack of funds, he had to build upon the remaining walls of the cathedral. He was assisted by Esteban de Rojas y Melo as obrero mayor (supervisor of construction). De Rojas, born in Llata, Peru, was ordained subdeacon in Nueva Caceres or Naga on 1 Oct 1736, and had been secretary of the bishops and member of the Cathedral canons.

De Uguccioni patterned the cathedral’s facade after the Il Gesu in Rome. Begun in 1751, the Manila Cathedral was not yet completely finished when it was inaugurated in 1760 by Abp Manuel Antonio Rojo y Viera, Arizala’s successor. De Uguccioni became the favored architect of the church and state during the reign of Abp Rojo del Rio, Abp 1758-64, who became acting governor of the Philippines in 1761. The archbishop commissioned De Uguccioni to propose repairs on Fort Santiago. In the same year he was sent to Cavite Puerto to find solutions to the flooding of the port city, built so close to the sea. Later he was asked to propose repairs for the Colegio de Santa Potenciana, organized for the education of the daughters of soldiers, and the buildings of the Seminario Conciliar de San Clemente, where De Uguccioni worked with the sangley (Chinese) stone mason Jeronimo Tongco. He worked closely with other Chinese artisans, employing Juan Ingco, master mason and carpenter, in the repair of the Hospital Real in Manila.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
Rosario Encarnacion-Tan (Rosario Santos Encarnacion-Tan), also known as Ning Encarnacion, is an architect, scholar, and designer. She was born on 27 Jan 1956. Her parents are Benjamin Cui Encarnacion and Elisa Santos Santos. She completed her primary and secondary studies at Maryknoll College. She received the Maryknoller award when she graduated from high school in 1974. From Maryknoll, she went on to study at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Architecture where she graduated with a bachelor’s degree in architecture, cum laude, in 1979. In 1980, she passed the board exams for architecture. While in college, she apprenticed with Urban Designers Associates from 1976 to 1980. Then she worked with Clemente C. Puno Construction as supervisor, 1980-84, and as project architect, 2008-10. She worked part-time with Francisco Mañosa and Partners, 1982-84. She also worked as planning department staff, researcher, writer, and design criteria formulator.

She has designed over 190 structures, mostly residences with some commercial and office buildings. Her major projects are Bantay Bata 163 Village in Norzagaray, Bulacan, 1997-2002; Faculty Center for the College of Social Sciences and Philosophy, 2003-present; and Montserrat Center, a 200-bedroom retreat center for the Benedictine Fathers. She is currently involved in nine projects, two of which have bamboo architecture in them. The current big project is an eight-level multistory building that houses classrooms, a theater, and a gym in St. Scholastica’s Academy Marikina.

Encarnacion-Tan is known for specializing in designing architecture that may be considered Filipino, based on her research of 31 years, and in particular for her breakthrough research in bamboo architecture. In the latter, she has had about 22 projects, the most important of which are the Bamboo House in Del Monte, Quezon City, 1991-97; the Center of Ecozoic Living and Learning, Cavite, 1998-2000; “The Bamboo Advantage” (that is, bamboo as a dismantable structure), 2002-03. As a work in progress, she has built a dismantable house in San Mateo, Rizal, which began in 2008. In its present form, the bamboo house is a three-story structure using bamboo posts, beams, roofing structure, as well as flooring, walls, and windows.

As a scholar of Philippine architecture and bamboo, she worked on Philippine Ancestral Houses as technical director, 1980, and Folk Architecture as writer and main researcher, 1990. She wrote the main entry on Philippine architecture in Encyclopedia of Vernacular Architecture of the World, a three-volume work published by Oxford Brookes in 1997. With Eric Caruncho, she also published a booklet, 100 Things about Building with Bamboo. She has held two nationwide lectures for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on the importance of traditional Philippine Architecture, 1988, and on art and ecology, 1989-1990.

Her advocacy of things Philippine expresses itself not just in books but in theater and events in which she is involved. From 1991 to 2001, she was executive producer of at least five major theater productions. Among these are Jammin’ on an Old Saya (GCF Productions), Ugoy-Ugoy: The Real Swing, 2001, and three others for Joey Ayala, held at major venues like the CCP Main Theater, Folk Arts Theater, Aguinaldo Theater, and the Meralco Theater. She organized 10 craft shows, called Stariray, featuring around 40 artists at a time and exhibiting mostly original Pinoy crafts.

She taught and was consultant to the College of Engineering and Architecture of St. Mary’s University, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. At this university, she was also the coordinator of the Center for Vernacular Architecture and Building Technology. She organized an international conference on “The Feasibility of Balay: A Village” on the campus of St. Mary’s University.

She received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for architecture from the city of Manila in 2010, notably for works in bamboo architecture.  Written by René B. Javellana
