text:
Espina, Perez-Espina and Associates (EPEA), an architectural group of Cebu City, began as a single proprietorship of two principals: Cristobal Bienvenido Cortes Espina (1915-95) and Filomena Perez-Espina (1917-88). Both took architecture in Mapua Institute of Technology, Manila, where Cristobal graduated in 1937 and Filomena in 1938.

After World War II, Cristobal and Filomena, who had gotten married, moved from Mandaue, Cristobal’s hometown, to Cebu City where they founded an architectural firm—Espina, Perez-Espina, Architects—at No. 135 Juana Osmeña St in 1951. The couple raised a family of eight children, four of whom became architects: Cristopher Stonewall, Filna Daphne, Omar Maxwell, and Joseph Michael. In 1976, with their children who were following careers in architecture, the family firm was renamed Architects, Espina, Perez-Espina and Associates. Eleven years later, in 1987, the family established Espina, Perez-Espina Realty Corporation, a holding company of the family’s properties. Cristopher married Mary Ann Arañas who is both an architect and a landscape architect. Mary Ann has been incorporated as the fifth principal in the new EPEA.

Associates of EPEA today are the four children of the founders—Christopher, Filna, Joseph, Omar—and the architect wife of Christopher, Mary Ann Arañas-Espina.

Cristopher Stonewall P. Espina, born 1949, architect, is married to architect Mary Ann Arañas. He graduated cum laude with a bachelor’s degree in architecture from the University of San Carlos (USC), Cebu, in 1971. He obtained a master’s degree in architecture from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1974, and a diploma in health facility planning from the Medical Architecture Research Unit, University of North London, England, 1979. He became a registered architect in 1971, a registered master plumber in 1972, and a registered environmental planner in 1995. He started teaching at the College of Architecture (CA), UP Diliman, beginning 1974 and served as dean of the college in 1999-2002.

Filna Daphne P. Espina, born 1951, is an architect, interior designer, and environmental planner. The principal architect of EPEA, she graduated cum laude with a bachelor’s degree in architecture from USC in 1972; that same year she became a registered architect. She obtained a certificate in interior design from the Philippine School of Interior Design in 1973 and a master’s degree in urban and regional planning from the University of Hawaii at Manoa in 1977. In 1985, she got a diploma in urban surveys from the International Institute of Aerial Surveys and Earth Sciences, Enschede, the Netherlands, with the grade of excellent as a Netherlands Government Scholar, 1984-85. She became a registered interior designer in 1994. She was a registered environmental planner in 1995.

Joseph Michael P. Espina, architect, civil engineer, junior geodetic engineer, and environmental planner, was born in Cebu City in 1955. He completed a bachelor’s degree in architecture, magna cum laude, at USC in 1976; a master’s degree in urban and regional planning at UP Diliman, 1979; a bachelor’s degree in civil engineering, cum laude, at USC, 1983; and a master’s degree in management, major in business management, at UP Cebu, 1990. He is a registered architect, 1976; civil engineer, 1983; junior geodetic engineer, 1983; and environmental planner, 1995. Starting 1987, he has taught at the USC College of Architecture and Fine Arts, and served as dean of the USC College of Architecture, Fine Arts, and Design (now the School of Architecture, Fine Arts and Design) starting 2010.

Mary Ann Arañas-Espina, born 1954, architect and landscape architect, graduated with a bachelor’s degree in architecture from USC in 1976 and passed the licensure exams in architecture, placing 10th among the topnotchers of 1976. She obtained a bachelor’s degree in landscape architecture from UP in 1982 and a master’s degree in landscape architecture from the University of Massachusetts in May 1987. She is associate professor at the CA, UP Diliman, and served as CA dean from 2011 to 2017.

Omar Maxwell P. Espina, architect, civil engineer, and urban planner, was born in Cebu in 1953. He got a bachelor’s degree in architecture, magna cum laude, USC, 1974; master’s degree in urban and regional planning, UP Diliman, 1977; and bachelor’s degree in civil engineering, cum laude, USC, 1983. He became a registered architect, 1974; civil engineer, 1983; and environmental planner, 1995. He has been a principal at EPEA from 1976 to the present and director at EPEA Realty from 1987 to the present.  Written by J. Mata

text:
Cristobal Espina (Cristobal Bienvenido Cortes Espina) also known as B.C. was an architect. He was born in Mandaue, Cebu on 29 Mar 1915. He died on 1995. He was the son of Luis Espina and Perpetua Cortes. His wife, the late Filomena Perez-Espina, 1917-88, was an architect. Four of their eight children are architects. He graduated with a bachelor of science degree in architecture, 1937, from the Mapua Institute of Technology. He worked under Tomas Mapua in 1937, and with the Corps of Engineers of the United States–Philippine Army, 1937-42, and 1945, in Manila, Corregidor, and Cebu. In the post-World War II years, he was an architectural designer with the H. Franco and J. L. Panis construction companies of Cebu, 1946-50. In 1951, he took first place in the government examinations for architects, founding the architectural firm Espina and Perez-Espina Associates as a single proprietorship of two principals, his wife and himself, in the same year. He taught at the University of San Carlos, 1951-76.

Espina went on architectural observation tours in the United States, Europe, Asia, and the Middle East, 1976-89. Active in community affairs, he served in Cebu City’s Parks and Playground Commission, 1970-71; Planning and Development Board, 1975-85; and Cultural and Historical Affairs Commission, from 1980. He has been active in the Philippine Institute of Architects (PIA), 1951-77, serving as its Cebu chapter president in 1961, and the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP), 1976-80.

Espina has to his credit numerous projects, particularly in Cebu: government buildings, housing complexes, universities, seminaries, churches, banks, hospitals, hotels, movie houses, gymnasiums, industrial complexes, commercial buildings, and residences. He was also involved in the restoration of the Basilica del Santo Niño in Cebu.

The partnership that Cristobal and his wife established has flourished as an important architectural firm in Cebu. In the 1980s, the firm established a Manila office. Omar Maxwell Espina, Fina Daphne Espina, and Joseph Michael Espina manage the Cebu office, while Cristopher Stonewall Espina and Mary Ann Arañas-Espina the Manila branch. Continuing the partnership’s legacy, the firm has been involved in diverse architectural disciplines, like architecture, engineering, urban and regional planning, landscape architecture, and interior design. It created the site development plan of Sacred Heart School (Ateneo de Cebu) in Mandaue City and the University of San Carlos College of Architecture and Fine Arts in collaboration with architects Maria Lizeta Uy and Sergio Raagas Jr. It did the landscape for Fort Bonifacio, Lakeshore, Subic Holiday Villas, and the Medical City. The firm has also designed private residences among its many projects.

Espina was honored as a fellow of the PIA in 1967 and the UAP in 1976. In 1983, he received an Apolinario Mabini Award in Manila as “Architect/Builder of the Year.” In 1991, he was presented with a Gold Medal of Merit by the PIA in Manila.  Written by Resil B. Mojares, with notes from René B. Javellana

Honrado Fernandez (Honrado Ramoso Fernandez), also known as Hony Fernandez, was a painter, sculptor, and architect. He was born in Cabanatuan City on 14 Aug 1949. He died in Laguna on 26 Apr 2005. He was the son of Nicolas Fernandez and Angelina Ramoso. He married Josephine Evangelista with whom he had two children. He finished a bachelor’s degree in architecture at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1971, a master’s degree in engineering, architectural design, at the Tokyo Institute of Technology in 1975, and a doctor’s degree in the science of art and design at the Tsukuba University in 1988. His first one-person show of sculptures and paintings was at the Asian Institute of Tourism, Quezon City, in 1983; his subsequent shows were at the Art for Architecture Gallery at Tradewinds in 1989, and at the Ayala Museum in 1990. He served as director of the Coordinating Center for Visual Arts of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1989-90. As a practicing architect, he was an executive trustee of the Center for Philippine Architecture under the United Architects of the Philippines. He was also dean of the UP College of Architecture from 1990 to 1999, and executive director of the Philippine High School for the Arts until 2005.

 

While the sculptures of his 1978-80 Gilho period focused on the supple human form, he later shifted to planometric sculpture in white, black, or colored metal strips folded and counterfolded in open compositions recalling origami. With these works, he began his Formal and Spatial Pattern series in painting, sculpture, and architecture through which he worked on various theories, principles, and methods involved in the organization of forms and spaces. In an open setting, Fernandez’s sculpture assumes the character of lines in oriental calligraphy interacting with the surrounding space. Also in regard of the figure-space theme is a series made of bands and wire mesh which are curved, twisted, or folded in order to bring out the values of plasticity and flexibility. Space interpenetrates into the figure and around it in these pieces. In later works, the metal planes are cut into basic figurative shapes, painted in various hues, and lightly treated with acid for textural interest.

 

The UP College of Architecture launched in 2006 the Honrado R. Fernandez Architectural Writing Competition held every two years to honor the memory of Fernandez. In 2007, the Jorge B. Vargas Museum in UP Diliman held an exhibition titled Form and Substance: The Works of Dean Honrado R. Fernandez.  Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz and Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Wili Fernandez (Guillermo Palanca Fernandez) was an interior designer. He was born in Manila on 3 Mar 1929. He died in Makati City on 23 Apr 1998. The son of Guillermo Fernandez, a physician, and Anna Palanca, he was married to Doreen Gamboa, essayist, teacher, and scholar. Fernandez took up architecture at the University of Santo Tomas. As a student, he excelled in architectural rendering. In 1952, he worked as art director in the Civil Affairs Office of the Department of National Defense. From 1953 to 1955 he was head of design in the Decor Arts Department of Aguinaldo’s Echague, the premier furniture store of the country at the time, which pioneered in interior design. In 1956, he established the Wili Fernandez Design Studio, of which he was head designer. In 1964, he founded Wili Fernandez and Associates Inc, of which he was president and chief designer. In 1980, he became a partner in Anjo Designs Ltd, Hong Kong. He was a founding member and past president of the Philippine Institute of Interior Designers (PIID), and later, member of its board of directors.

Fernandez designed interiors for hotels, restaurants, offices, banks, airline offices, showrooms, clubhouses, resorts, clinics, and residences. His major projects include the interiors of 18 hotels in the Philippines and in Hong Kong, Taipei, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Penang, and Bangkok, as well as the interiors of the Philippine House in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, New York, and Madrid.

While his style is basically contemporary, he uses native Filipino motifs, such as Maranao designs, and color schemes evocative of Filipino folk art. His interiors are characterized by richness, cosmopolitan sophistication, and restful urbanity.

He wrote a number of articles on interior design, such as “Design Problems in Asia” for The Asia Magazine, 1965; “Asian Hotel Design” for Asian Construction, 1973; and “Professionalism in Interior Design” for The Asian Builder, 1976.

In 1985, the PIID awarded Fernandez a Fellowship Plaque “for his contribution to the field of interior design, as architect, interior designer, and furniture designer; for having paved the way for the acceptance and recognition of interior design as a profession in this country; for having personified the true designer, practising the profession consistently and with the highest standards of taste for the past twenty years.” In 1988, the city of Manila conferred on him the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award. From Apr to Aug 2013, an exhibit on the designs of Fernandez, Art and Space: A Collection of Design Concepts by Wili Fernandez, was mounted at the De La Salle University Museum. In 2013, a book titled Wili Fernandez, Designer collected his architectural renderings as well as essays on him as a person and a professional.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Gabriel Formoso (Gabriel Papa Formoso), also known as Gabby Formoso, was an architect. He was born in Manila on 9 Apr 1915. He died on 23 Dec 1996. The son of Gregorio Formoso and Alvara Papa, he finished high school at Ateneo de Manila in 1933, then enrolled at the University of Santo Tomas School of Architecture where he graduated in 1937. Becoming a registered architect in 1939, he worked for Andres Luna de San Pedro and later for Pablo Antonio. He formed a partnership with Luis Araneta, then established his own office. From 1952 to 1988, he made 11 tours of the United States, South America, and Europe to observe trends in architecture, particularly in bank, hotel, and condominium design. Formoso, a fellow of the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP), was the founding chairman of the Kanlungan Architectural Foundation of the Philippines, organized by UAP fellows.

In more than 40 years of practice, he designed about 80 buildings and more than 150 residences. His outstanding works include the Central Bank complex, 1970, and the Metropolitan Museum, 1973, both on Roxas Blvd, Manila; the Valley Golf Club in Victoria Valley, Antipolo, Rizal, 1960; the Alabang Golf and Country Club in Alabang, Muntinlupa, 1978; the Development Academy of the Philippines in Tagaytay City, 1974; and the Club Filipino in Greenhills, San Juan, 1960. His buildings in Makati include the Pacific Star Building on Makati Ave, 1990; the Bank of America–Lepanto Building on Paseo de Roxas, 1978; the Nikko Manila Garden Hotel on EDSA, 1974; the Manila Peninsula Hotel on Ayala Ave, 1974; the Asian Institute of Management (AIM) on Paseo de Roxas, 1970; and the Doña Narcisa de Leon Building on Paseo de Roxas, 1967.

While some of Formoso’s buildings are characterized by cool elegance, others are notable for their warmth and ruggedness. The Pacific Star Building, with its towering arches and classic lines, is remarkable for its refinement and serenity. The Central Bank Buildings are a harmonious composition of massive concrete blocks relieved of their severity by continuous horizontal bands of windows. Wooden panels, rugged stonework, and bold concrete masses give the exterior of the AIM both warmth and virility. The wooden panels evoke the bandeja (traylike) panels of the bahay na bato (house of stone).

In a statement on his philosophy of design, Formoso emphasizes three points: first, architecture is a fine art committed to creating beauty; second, the social nature of architecture places a unique responsibility on the architect—that is, a building becomes part of the environment and functions in a dynamic interaction with it; and third, architecture must strive for simplicity. While his work faithfully reflects his philosophy, it is further characterized by a sensitivity to native tradition. This is especially evident in his residences, with their steep hip roofs and elegant woodwork. Formoso set a trend in the Club Filipino in Greenhills, which paid homage to the bahay na bato and affirmed the continuing relevance of certain traditional forms.

In 1977, Formoso received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila. In 1990, the UAP conferred on him its highest honor, the Likha Award and Gold Medal of Merit.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Juan Hervas (Juan Jose Hervas Arizmendi) was an architect. He was active from 1885 to early 20th century. A native of Barcelona, Spain, he was the municipal architect of Manila, 1885-93. He is credited with introducing modern Catalan architecture in the Philippines and counted as one of the two best architects of the late 19th century, the other being Felix Roxas Sr. Toward the latter part of his career, he returned to Barcelona where he opened a business.

Hervas designed numerous buildings, offices, and residences. Among these were the Manila Railroad Station at Tutuban, the Arranque and Herran markets, the Manila High School, and the old Assumption Convent on Herran St. Among the commercial buildings he designed were Estrella del Norte on Escolta, the Heacock Store Building, the Paris-Manila Building, the building occupied by the American Bazaar, the Hotel Oriente on Plaza Binondo, and the La Insular Tobacco Factory, which was in the Neo-Mudejar style. Hervas was best known for his renovation of the Ayuntamiento, for which he designed an elegant staircase, the vestibule, and the Marble Hall. The Monte de Piedad at Plaza Goiti (renovated and now known as the Roman Santos Building), designed in the Greek revivalist style, was considered his masterpiece. For this building, pillars of Carrara marble were brought in from Italy.  Written by René B. Javellana

Johnny Hubilla (Jose Maria Grajo Hubilla) is an interior designer. He was born in Manila 22 Mar 1941. The son of Lourdes Grajo and Generoso Hubilla, he is married to Ma Antonia Mañalac with whom he has three children. He studied architecture for two years at the University of Santo Tomas, then shifted to fine arts, graduating with a bachelor’s degree, major in interior design. He worked in the architectural office of Luis Araneta for two years and subsequently with Trend House Inc. He worked at the Manila Hilton Hotel for three years as assistant interior designer to Scollard Maas of Welton Becket Inc. He taught at the Philippine School of Interior Design, 1965-69. In 1973, he established his own office, Johnny G. Hubilla Interior Design Studio. He was twice president of the Philippine Institute of Interior Designers, and twice member of the board of examiners for interior design of the Professional Regulation Commission.

He has designed interiors for hotels, restaurants, showrooms, offices, department stores, and residences. He has undertaken projects in Hong Kong, Singapore, Bangkok, Taipei, and several cities in the United States, Canada, and Europe, such as the Philippine Trade House in Bangkok; the Philippine Trade Center in Toronto, Canada; the Philippine House in Mainz, Germany; the Philippine Pavilion at the World Trade Exposition in Leipzig, Germany; and the Philippine Pavilion at the World Trade Fair in Spokane, Washington, USA. His works range from the contemporary to the eclectic, the latter embracing both traditional and Filipino-Spanish styles.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text:
René B. Javellana (René Pio Barrios Javellana, SJ) is a cultural historian, writer, and educator. He was born in Manila on 11 Jul 1948. Born to Manuel Javellana from Iloilo and Lucrecia Barrios from Capiz, he obtained his bachelor’s degree in philosophy and education in 1971 and master’s degree in theology in 1981 at Ateneo de Manila University. He also took studies in biblical language in Rome in 1978, in art history at the University of the Philippines in 1982-84, and sculpture and printmaking at the Art Students’ League in New York, USA, in 1987. He obtained his doctorate in ministry in art and theology at the Pacific School of Religion in Berkeley, California, USA, in 1994, with a dissertation titled “The Art of Protest and Liberation: Philippine Political Art 1966-1993.” He entered the Society of Jesus in 1966, was ordained priest in 1976, and took his final vows in 2000.

Javellana has conducted classes on the theory, practice, and history of art at Ateneo de Manila University and the Loyola School of Theology. At Ateneo de Manila, he is associate professor in fine arts, and has served the school’s Fine Arts Program as director in 2003-09, the Cultural Heritage Series of the Ateneo de Manila University Press as series editor, and Philippine Studies as assistant editor in 1986-2003. He held the Thomas Gasson Fellowship, 2007-8, at Boston College, Massachusetts, where he was visiting professor at the Department of Fine Arts and research fellow. Also in 2007, he was visiting lecturer at the Jesuit School of Theology, Berkeley, California. As a Jesuit, he has been the archivist of the Philippine Province of the Society of Jesus since 2013 and was greatly involved in the development of Jesuit Communications, the media organization of the Jesuits in the Philippines since 2003. He has been involved with local and international cultural agencies such as the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the National Museum of the Philippines as member of the Board of Trustees in 2011-16, the Intramuros Administration as consultant for the restoration of the San Ignacio Church in 2013, the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines, and the International Committee on Monuments and Sites.

Through the years Javellana has produced an extensive oeuvre on architectural heritage that includes books such as Wood and Stone for God’s Greater Glory: Jesuit Art and Architecture in the Philippines, 1991; Great Churches of the Philippines (with Fr Pedro Galende, OSA), 1993; Fortress of Empire: Spanish Colonial Fortifications in the Philippines, 1565-1898, 1997; and In and Around Intramuros: An Interactive Guide, 2003. He was the principal writer of La Casa de Dios: Filipino-Hispanic Churches in the Philippines, 2010. All of these, including numerous articles in local and international publications, are classic sources for data, documentation, theory, and methodology. Javellana was associate area editor and major contributor to the architecture and the visual arts volumes of the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994. In the field of Philippine literature, he edited Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal (An Account of the Sacred Passion), 1988, with his introduction, annotations, and English translation of the 1882 text, and Mahal na Passion ni Jesuchristong Panginoon Natin na Tola ni Gaspar Aquino de Belen (Sacred Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse by Gaspar Aquino de Belen), 1990, as well as co-edited The Sermons of Blancas de San Jose, 1997, and Juan de Oliver’s Declaracion de la Doctrina Christiana (The Affirmation of the Christian Doctrine), 1998. Javellana has also harnessed modern media to further his cause, authoring travel websites Bahandi, a guide to Laguna’s historic towns, and Panublion, a guide to historic towns in the Visayas, and maintaining the blogs Muog: Spanish Colonial Fortifications in the Philippines and Intramuros: Historic Walled City of Manila.

Several of Javellana’s works have received awards: Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal, National Book Award for literary history from the Manila Critics Circle, 1988; Mahal na Passion, Best Book in the Vernacular, in the Catholic Mass Media Awards, 1990; Fortress of Empire, Golden Book Award from the Publishers’ Association of the Philippines and Best Book Design from the Manila Critics Circle, 1998; and Sermones of Fray Francisco Blancas de San Jose, Best Edited Book from the Manila Critics Circle, 1998. Javellana was granted an Asian Public Intellectual Fellowship by the Nippon Foundation in 2000-2001. He wrote the lyrics for “Tinapay ng Buhay,” sung to music by M.V. Francisco, SJ, at the mass officiated by Pope Francis at the Luneta on 18 Jan 2015.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

Javellana was granted an Asian Public Intellectual Fellowship by the Nippon Foundation in 2000-2001. He wrote the lyrics for “Tinapay ng Buhay,” sung to music by M.V. Francisco, SJ, at the mass officiated by Pope Francis at the Luneta on 18 Jan 2015.
Written by Regalado Trota Jose

text:
Regalado Trota Jose (Regalado Trota Jose Jr), also known as Regalado T. Jose or Ricky Jose, is an essayist and teacher. He was born in Quezon City on 2 Sep 1955. He is one of the six children of Remedios Trota and Regalado San Luis Jose, a concert pianist, music teacher, and orchestra conductor. He received his education, from elementary to postgraduate studies, at the University of the Philippines, obtaining a bachelor’s degree in anthropology in 1978 and master of arts in Philippine studies in 1991. Jose’s education expanded as well through concerts all over the country and the world with the Philippine Madrigal Singers (1974-83). He obtained a certificate in Madrid from the Spanish Ministry of Education for an introductory course on the sources of viceregal art in 2000. At present, he is a faculty member of the Cultural Heritage Studies Program of the University of Santo Tomas Graduate School and an archivist of the same university. He previously taught at the University of the Philippines Department of Art Studies in the 1990s. He served as chair of the Committees of Archives, Museums, and Monuments and Sites from 2012 to 2014, commissioner of the Subcommission on Cultural Heritage of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts from 2011 to 2013. He was a founding member and first president of the International Council on Monuments and Sites Philippines.

For almost 13 years, since 1979, Jose worked at the Ayala Museum, starting as arts researcher and eventually becoming curator two years before he resigned. During this period, he was able to further advance his studies on Philippine colonial church arts. From his documentation field trips, he expanded the museum’s Iconographic Archive, especially its collection of photos and slides of churches; started a study collection of bricks from colonial structures; and built up a store of data from field and archival sources on colonial art.

Jose has been advocating for the study, protection, and conservation of the cultural heritage of the Catholic Church in the country. He has worked on research projects, curatorial works for exhibits, lectures, and seminars for the Ayala Museum, University of the Philippines, University of Santo Tomas, Philippine National Historical Society, National Commission for Culture and the Arts, Manila Archdiocesan Commission for the Cultural Heritage of the Church, and the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) Episcopal Commission for the Cultural Heritage of the Church. His research works have provided the study of Philippine colonial church art and architecture with tools for a more scientific learning of Philippine art. His works and recommendations led to the inscription of a number of Philippine churches in the UNESCO World Heritage List and the National Cultural Treasures list of the National Museum of the Philippines .

Jose helped set up museums as well as curated a number of exhibits in the country and abroad. These include museums for the provincial government of Ilocos Norte in 1999 and the museums of the Archdiocese of San Fernando, Pampanga, in 1984; Diocese of San Fernando, La Union, in 1994; Diocese of Laoag in 1996; and Archdiocese of Nueva Segovia in 1996. Notable exhibits and special shows he helped set up include the Colonial Art Section of People and Art of the Philippines in the Museum of Cultural History, University of California at Los Angeles (with Fr Gabriel Casal in 1981); Ayala Museum’s Larawan—Philippine Portraits (with Jaime Laya in 1988) and Pamanang Pilak (with Ramon Villegas in 1989); Impreso, 400 Years of Printing in the Philippines in 1993; Palitada: Skin of the Church in 2003; Power + Faith + Image: Philippine Art in Ivory from the 16th to the 19th Century (with Ramon Villegas) in 2004; Images of Faith at the Pacific Asia Museum, Pasadena, California (with David Kamansky in 1990); the Visual Arts Section for the Igkas Arte Centennial Exhibition at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1998; and the quadricentennial exhibit on the University of Santo Tomas at the UNESCO headquarters, Paris, in 2010. The exhibitions helped refine knowledge and connoisseurship on Filipino-Hispanic art and culture.

Jose’s writings revolve around the objects of his research. The culmination of his earlier work is Simbahan : Church Art in Colonial Philippines, 1565-1898, which was published in 1991 by the Ayala Museum. His major works include Impreso: Philippine Imprints 1593-1811 published in 1993. In 1990 and 2004, he wrote two books on Philippine ivory images: Images of Faith in 1990 and Power + Faith + Image in 2004 with Ramon Villegas. He also co-wrote San Agustin: Art and History in 2000 with Fr Pedro Galende. His book Visita Iglesia Bohol: A Guide to Historic Churches was published in 2001, the four-volume Curas de Almas: A Premilinary Listing of Parishes and Parish Priests in the 19th Century Philippines in 2008, and Bagting: The Valuation of Time and Memory in Spanish Colonial Philippines in 2010.

He wrote sections on colonial art in the catalogues for the exhibits The People and Art of the Philippines, set up by University of California in Los Angeles in 1980; Die Philippinen: Perle im Östlichen Meer by the Museum für Völkerkunde in Munich, Germany, in 1985; and Images of Faith: Ivory Carvings from the Philippines by the Asia Pacific Museum in Pasadena, California, in 1990. He wrote Guidebook to the Museums of Metro Manila, 1989, and articles and essays in local and international scholarly journals and books.

His book Simbahan won the National Book Award for art from the Manila Critics Circle in 1991. Jose contributed to the book Ilocos Norte: A Travel Guidebook published in 2004 that won the National Book Award travel category in 2005. In 1999, he received the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts as one of the “100 outstanding Filipinos who have helped build the Filipino nation through art and culture during the last 100 years” through his work in art history. The Holy Angel University in Angeles City, Pampanga, conferred on him the “Order of Saint Michael the Archangel for Outstanding Contribution to Lay Catholic Education” in 2012 while the city of Manila gave him the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for historical writing in 2013.  Written by Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Edgar Allan Sembrano

text:
Winand Klassen (Winand Becker Klassen) is an architect, teacher, and scholar of architecture. He was born in Kettenkamp Municipality, Osnabruck District, Germany on 29 Jan 1930. His parents are August Klassen and Helene Becker.

When Fr Winand Klassen arrived in 1976 to teach architecture in the University of San Carlos in Cebu City, he had come well prepared for the job. As a youth, he labored in a construction site for six years. In 1951, he joined the Society of the Divine Word (SVD), studied for the priesthood in his native Germany and in the United States where he was ordained in 1963, then worked with an institution of SVD architects in Rome. As he steadily appraised the world of the architect through constant traveling around the country and through attending practitioners’s conventions, Klassen proceeded to arm his students and colleagues by writing a series of books. These were History of Western Architecture, 1980; Architecture in the Philippines, 1986, and reprinted in 2010; Architecture and Philosophy, 1990; and Architecture Gods and Mortals, 1994. All four were published by the University of San Carlos. Klassen also disseminated his views through articles in the Philippine Quarterly of Culture and Society and through talks sponsored by the Goethe-Institut.

History of Western Architecture is developed through a presentation of about 200 examples, each with a brief sketch of its historical background, architectural form, and interpreted meaning. Architecture in the Philippines is a virtual summation of all that was known then about the subject, with the added bonus of critical analyses not only of structures but of contemporary architects, architects’ associations, and architecture in Cebu. In Architecture and Philosophy, Klassen wrestles with philosophies that inform architectural thought, dialoguing not only with Thomism and active negativism but especially with phenomenology, hermeneutics, and deconstruction. These ideas are dealt with more deeply in Architecture Gods and Mortals, but this time with the express aim of moving the architect to keep on searching for meaning, thereby committing himself to build better architecture.

Collectively, the four-volume set is arguably the best textbook for Philippine architects to date. To be sure, his book on Western architecture contains far less examples than the classic A History of Architecture by Sir Banister Fletcher, revised several times and still used by many schools, including state universities. The volume on Philippine architecture was written just before the EDSA Revolt, and certainly needs to be updated. However, Klassen’s prickly critiques and informed interpretations are invaluable in forming a young architect. Though the last two books are geared toward critical and ethical thinking, still they are free from the jargon and oblique statements that would plague later authors. Alone among his colleagues, Klassen rails againt kitsch—low quality material designed to appeal to current popular taste—a plea that runs through his four books. In being well illustrated with architectural and technical drawings, elevations, plans, cross sections, and site plans, Klassen’s contributions remain unsurpassed by later works published in the Philippines.

Together with Arch Artemio S. Alcoseba, Klassen designed the church of Saint Arnold Janssen and Saint Joseph Freinademetz in the Talamban Campus of the University of San Carlos, 1984, and the San Vicente Ferrer parish church also in Cebu City, toward 1990. These structures are examples of Klassen’s melding of local values with modern lines. One of his students, Arch Melva Rodriguez Java, has carried on his ideals into the field of heritage architecture conservation. Unfortunately, Klassen’s works are hardly known beyond Cebu as they are not cited in local and foreign scholars’s bibliographies.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose

text:
Jaime Laya (Jaime del Carmen Laya) is a writer, cultural administrator, and economist. He was born in Manila 8 Jan 1939. He is the son of Juan Cabreros Laya, educator and author of the novel His Native Soil, and Silvina del Carmen, educator. The couple founded Kayumanggi Press and Inang Wika Publishing Co. He married Alice Sandoval, with whom he has four children.

Graduating with honors in business administration from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1957, he went to get a master’s degree in industrial management from Georgia Institute of Technology in 1960 and a PhD in financial management from the Stanford University Graduate School of Business in 1965. He served as professor at UP Diliman’s College of Business Administration and its dean from 1968 to 1975. Laya’s public sector involvement, especially during a crucial period of Philippine history, is extensive. Under Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, he served as budget minister in 1975-81, fifth governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas in 1981-84, and education minister in 1984-86. With other colleagues, Laya was responsible for the drafting and enactment of Presidential Decree 1616, creating the Intramuros Administration (IA). He was IA’s action officer from its creation in 1979 until 1986. In 1986, Laya established J.C. Laya and Co. Ltd, an auditing firm, later renamed Laya Mananghaya and Co., which he chaired until 2004 when he retired from the company. Under Pres Fidel Ramos, he was chair of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 1996 to 2001. Under both Presidents Ramos and Macapagal, he served as member of the board of trustees of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. He was chair or trustee of, among others, De La Salle University, St Paul University, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, Yuchengo Museum, Heart Foundation of the Philippines Inc, Fundacion Santiago, ABS-CBN Foundation Inc, Philtrust Bank, and the Cofradia de la Inmaculada Concepcion. He chairs the newly created Escuela Taller de Filipinas Foundation Inc.

Instead of outfitting the Central Bank’s new office complex at Roxas Blvd and Vito Cruz with contemporary furniture, Laya made it a showcase of Philippine heirloom pieces and paintings. The collection of paintings and precolonial gold would eventually be displayed in the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, its instructive and well-curated exhibits rivaling even those of the National Museum. As chair of the Intramuros Administration, he assembled its collection of precious colonial artworks, furnishings, and jewelry.

In 1981, under the auspices of the Intramuros Administration he republished the 1905 work of Arthur Stanley Riggs, The Filipino Drama. With Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton, he wrote Intramuros of Memory, compiling and classifying vintage photographs in IA’s collection, 1983, reissued 2011. He is an author of or contributor to a number of books, including Prusisyon: Religious Pageantry in the Philippines, 1996; Kiukok: Deconstructing Despair, 2000, with Alfredo R. Roces; Letras y Figuras: Business in Culture, Culture in Business, 2001, which won the Manila Critics Circle Award; Consuming Passions: Philippine Collectibles, 2003, with Erlinda Enriquez-Panlilio; Hidalgo Bonding: A Family Cookbook, 2006, with Adelaida Lim; and Hidden Treasures, Simple Pleasures , 2009, with Mariano C. Lao and Edilberto Bravo. He writes a column for the Manila Bulletin, "Wala Lang" (Nothing Really). Articles from Aug to Nov 2011 from this column were published as an anthology Wala Lang: 500-Word Articles on Philippine Life and Culture.

Spearheading the restoration of the Camarin de la Virgen in Santa Ana Church, 2008-10, he contributed to Santa Ana: A Historical Guide, 2010, published in conjunction with the restoration of the Camarin, as well as a chapter on the church’s patroness in Magnificat: Mama Mary’s Pilgrim Sites, 2012. Generous with his time and talent, he has contributed introductions to the works of younger and upcoming scholars.

Among his numerous awards are Ten Outstanding Young Men, 1967, and Orden de Merito Civil, rank of Commander, Encomienda de Numero, conferred by King Juan Carlos I of Spain in recognition of his role in heritage preservation, 2014.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose

Leandro V. Locsin Partners is an architectural firm located at Locsin Building, Ayala Ave corner Makati Ave, Makati City. The Leandro V. Locsin Partners was founded by Arch Leandro V. Locsin, later National Artist for architecture, and in 1955 was renamed Leandro V. Locsin and Associates. In 1978, the company’s name changed to Leandro V. Locsin and Partners, and eventually to its present name in 1997. Aside from architectural design, the company also ventures into interior design and physical planning.

Its present administrator and design consultant is Leandro “Andy” Yulo Locsin Jr. Locsin Jr finished bachelor of arts in architecture and Eastern art history at Wesleyan University in Connecticut, USA, and earned his master’s degree in architecture at the Harvard University Graduate School of Design in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in 1989. He joined his father’s company in 1991. Arch Edgar L. Ledesma Jr is the firm’s managing partner while its partners include Arch Raul R. Locsin who is also a registered interior designer, Arch Rommel C. Abad, Arch Melylyn S. Pineda, and Arch Mathew J. Varona.

The firm is known for designing theaters, such as the iconic Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1969; Folk Arts Theater, 1974; Greenbelt Cinema Square in Makati, 1982; and the Philippine Educational Theater Association Center, 2005.

The company also designed notable churches such as the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice inside the University of the Philippines Diliman campus, 1955; the Ozamiz City Cathedral in Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental, 1960; St. Andrew the Apostle Parish in Bel-Air, Makati City, 1968; Chapel of St. Alphonsus Liguori in Magallanes Village, Makati, 1970; Monastery of the Transfiguration in Malaybalay, Bukidnon, 1996; and the Montecito Chapel in Canlubang, Calamba, Laguna, 2012.

It likewise designed a number of academic structures and convention centers in the country. These edifices include the National Arts Center of the Philippines in Los Baños, Laguna, 1976; Design Center of the Philippines, 1974; Philippine Center for International Trade and Exhibitions, 1976; Philippine International Convention Center (PICC), 1976; the University of the Philippines Los Baños main library and auditorium, 1991, as well as the Dioscoro L. Umali Hall, 1965; and the Henry Sy Sr. Hall of De La Salle University on Taft Ave, Manila, 2012.

Commercial and public buildings include the Ninoy Aquino International Airport Terminal Building, 1979; Davao International Airport Terminal Building, Davao City, 1980 and 2002; Benguet Center in Mandaluyong, 1983, demolished by the SM Group in 2012; LV Locsin Building, 1987; Philippine Stock Exchange Plaza in Makati, 1995; Fast Food Center at the CCP complex, 1976; Philippine Long Distance and Telephone Company Building (Ramon Cojuangco Building) on Makati Ave, 1982; the Filipinas Life Assurance Co. Building, Mandaue City, Cebu, 1970; and the Magnolia Dairy Products plant on Aurora Blvd in Quezon City, 1969. The latter was demolished after its sale in 2008 to give way to a mix-use development.

It also drafted blueprints for hotels that are now considered architectural landmarks. These are the Intercontinental Manila, 1969; Philippine Plaza Hotel, later renamed Westin Philippine Plaza and Sofitel Hotel, 1976; Manila Hotel annex building, 1976; and the Mandarin Hotel Makati, 1976, demolished in 2015.

The firm was also commissioned to do the architectural plans for a number of commercial and private residences, beach resorts, leisure clubs, and residences in Laguna, Batangas, Bataan, Cebu, Boracay, and Palawan, including the Puerto Azul Beach club in Ternate, Cavite, and the Anvaya Cove in Morong, Bataan, 2009.

Its largest undertaking so far is the Istana Nurul Iman (Palace of the Light of Faith) in Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei, 1984. The building is touted to be the biggest residence of a head of state in the world. The structure is an integration of the Malay and Islamic architectural traditions of Brunei.

Notable restorations or renovations include the Goldenberg Mansion, 1966, Congress of the Philippines Session Hall (later National Art Gallery of the National Museum), 1972; Ang Maharlika (State Guest House) in San Miguel, Manila, 1976; Supreme Court, 1991 and 1992; Nielsen Tower in Makati, 1996; and Casa de Nipa Ancestral House in Calamba, Laguna, 2003.

It also designed the interiors of more than 50 private and public structures, including CCP’s Theater for Performing Arts in 1969; PICC in 1976; Manila Hotel in 1976; Philippine Stock Exchange Building, Makati, in 1994; De La Salle University in Canlubang, Laguna, in 2003; and ABS-CBN TV production offices in 2011.

In 2011, the company won the Cultural Center of the Philippines Architectural Design Competition for its planned new landmark structures: the Performing Arts Theater and the Artists’ Center, part of the seven-building CCP Complex master redevelopment plan.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose, with notes from Edgar Allan M. Sembrano

Gerard Lico (Gerard Rey Astilla Lico) is an architect and art historian. He was born in Quezon City on 22 Apr 1975. He is the son of Reynaldo Lico and Melinda Astilla. He married Bernadette Clemente, a medical doctor, and they have three children. He completed his tertiary and graduate studies at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman where he obtained a bachelor’s degree in architecture, a master’s degree in art history, and a doctorate in Philippine studies. He is a professor in the College of Architecture (CA), where he has also served as a research program director and head of the Studio on Architectural History, Theory and Criticism. He is the curator of the Museum of Filipino Architecture in UP and once served as UP campus architect. Over and above his academic and professional practice, he held office as head of the National Committee on Architecture and Allied Arts of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and as executive director of the Center for Filipino Architecture and Professional Development Commission of the United Architects of the Philippines. He is the consulting architect of the NCCA for the restoration of the Manila Metropolitan Theater.

Lico published Edifice Complex: Power, Myth, and Marcos State Architecture, 2003, and Arkitekturang Filipino: A History of Architecture and Urbanism in the Philippines, 2008. In Feb 2014, Lico’s video series Master Builders: Pioneers of 20th Century Philippine Architecture and Allied Arts and exhibition A Pioneer and Modernist Iconoclast: The Architectural Legacy of Pablo S. Antonio were launched on the occasion of the Art MADE Public sponsored by the Metrobank Foundation. He is a contributor to Art Deco in the Philippines, 2011, edited by Lourdes Montinola. He has also published articles popularizing architecture in the Philippine Daily Inquirer, BluPrint magazine, and Architecture Asia.

He did a series on interactive CDs: Arkitekturang Filipino: Spaces and Places in History, 2003; Through the Lens of an American Soldier, 2004; and Building Modernity: A Century of Philippine Architecture and Allied Arts, 2008. He did a video series called Audio-Visual Textbook of Philippine Architecture, 2009; Lunan: A History of the Filipino Built Environments, 2012; and Deco Decoded, 2015.

In 2001, he received the Catholic Mass Media Award for his “A Century of Philippine Design: The First Fifty Years.” For his researches in architectural history and cultural studies, he received the UP Gawad Chanselor para sa Pinakamahusay na Mananaliksik (Arts and Humanities) in 2002, 2004, and 2005, earning him a place in its Hall of Fame. He received the Ten Outstanding Young Men award in 2004. He received the titles UP Artist II in 2010, UP Artist III in 2013, and UP Artist II in 2015. In 2010, he received the UP Gawad Chanselor para sa Natatanging Guro, attesting to his excellence as a scholar and teacher.  Written by René B. Javellana

Antonio Lobato was a priest-architect. He was born in Zamora, Spain ca. 1724. He died in Tuguegarao, Cagayan on 11 Mar 1794. By the 18th century, the Dominicans had effectively evangelized Cagayan Valley and were ready to build churches of durable material. Lobato was assigned as missionary to Ituy, Nueva Vizcaya, and as vicar of Buhay (now Aritao). He then transferred to Cagayan where he was missionary to the towns of Santa Cruz de Gumpat, Aparri, and Tuguegarao.

Lobato was considered, among foreigners at the time, as the best speaker and writer of Ibanag. In this language, he wrote a versified pasyon and a grammar, and he added to the Ibanag dictionary of Fr Jose Bugarin, OP. However, most of his works were not published.

Because of the absence of suitable stone to build churches, Lobato, who was well versed in architecture, exploited the abundant clay found in the alluvial plains of the valley. He built kilns for firing bricks and slaking lime used for the church and tower of Tuguegarao. His bricks were molded into decorative elements that transformed the walls into jewels of art. He also built a bridge at Carig.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
Leandro V. Locsin (Leandro Valencia Locsin), also known as Lindy Locsin, was an architect. He is a National Artist for architecture. He was born in Silay, Negros Occidental on 15 Aug 1928. He died in Makati City on 15 Nov 1994. The eldest of Guillermo Locsin and Remedios Valencia’s seven children, Locsin was named after his paternal grandfather Leandro de la Rama Locsin, who was the first elected governor of Negros Occidental under the American regime. He was married to Cecilia Yulo. They had two children, one of whom, Leandro Jr, is an architect. After finishing high school at De La Salle College in Manila in 1947, Locsin enrolled at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music, intending to pursue music as a career, although he was even then interested in architecture. In 1949, he dropped the bachelor of music course and enrolled at the UST School of Architecture. While an architecture student, he worked as an artist-draftsman at the Ayala Corporation, which was then beginning the development of Makati. He graduated in 1953, and is one of very few major architects who did not train abroad.

Before establishing his practice, he designed stage sets for ballets and a musical. In 1954, Fr John Delaney, SJ, the University of the Philippines (UP) Catholic chaplain, commissioned him to design the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice at the UP Diliman campus. Completed in 1955, the building was remarkable for its circular plan and three-inch thick concrete-shell dome. Within the next four years he designed an apartment building, two office buildings, and nine residences—a small number that nonetheless created an impact on the architectural scene. From 1955 to 1994, Locsin produced 75 residences, 88 buildings, and a state palace. The buildings include 11 churches and chapels, 23 government buildings, 4 apartment buildings, 6 hotels, and 48 commercial buildings. While his best-known works are located in Metro Manila, he also designed buildings in Dagupan, Cabanatuan, Batangas City, Naga, Bacolod, Iloilo, Tacloban, Mandaue, Cagayan de Oro, Ozamis, and Davao City.

Locsin’s major accomplishments include the buildings at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex—the main building housing two theaters, a museum, and art galleries, 1969; the Folk Arts Theater, 1974; the Philippine Center for International Trade and Exhibitions or PHILCITE, 1976; the Philippine International Convention Center, 1976; and the Philippine Plaza Hotel, 1976. Other major works include the Hyatt Regency Hotel on Roxas Blvd, Pasay City, 1967; the Makati Stock Exchange Building, 1971, and the Ayala Museum (now replaced by another designed by his son), 1974, both on Makati Ave, Makati; the renovation of the Manila Hotel, 1976; the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Makati, 1976; the National Arts Center at Makiling, Los Baños, Laguna, 1976; and the terminal of the Manila International Airport (now Ninoy Aquino International Airport), 1979.

His largest and most spectacular work was the Istana Nurul Iman (Palace of the Light of Faith), the palace of the sultan of Brunei, which has a total floor area of 200,000 sq m, a grand reception hall accommodating 5,000, a throne room with a capacity of 2,000, and two mosques crowned by domes plated with 22-carat gold. Malayan and Islamic motifs, modern lines, and the latest building technology blend. With clean lines, strong masses, and daring structural design, Locsin’s buildings are strikingly modern and original. But touches of nostalgia, the use of traditional forms and patterns, and the sculptural character of space and structure give his work a romantic spirit. His last work was the Church of the Monastery of the Transfiguration in Malaybalay, Bukidnon.

In 1975, Locsin was commissioned by American dancer Martha Graham to design the sets for Lucifer and Adorations, which she created to mark the golden jubilee of her renowned modern dance company. Locsin and his wife co-authored Oriental Ceramics Discovered in the Philippines, 1967.

Locsin and his work are the subject of The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites, published by John Weatherhill in 1977. He is the only Filipino architect included in Contemporary Architects, edited by Muriel Emmanuel, published in 1980, and Architects of the Third World by Udo Kultermann, published in 1980. He and his work have been featured in various architectural and popular magazines. In commemoration of his second death anniversary, the Cultural Center of the Philippines mounted an exhibit on Locsin’s three major works titled The Poet of Space: Leandro V. Locsin, which ran from Nov 1996 to Feb 1997. It was also accompanied by a publication of the same title, which featured the Istana Nurul Iman, the Ayala Triangle Tower One and the Philippine Stock Exchange, and the Church of the Monastery of the Transfiguration. Architects Augusto Villalon and Rodrigo D. Perez III curated the exhibit and edited and wrote for the book.

In 1959, he received the Ten Outstanding Young Men award for architecture. In 1961, the American Institute of Architects Hawaii Chapter conferred on him the Pan-Pacific Citation for consistent excellence in design. These awards were followed by many others, among them the Rizal Centennial Award for architecture in 1962, the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1970, the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award in 1972, and the Gold Medal of Merit from the Philippine Institute of Architects in 1978. In 1980, he was elected honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects. In 1987, the United Architects of the Philippines conferred on him the Likha Award and Gold Medal. In 1992, he was awarded the Arts and Culture Prize at the third Fukuoka Asian Culture Prizes Ceremony, Fukuoka, Japan. In 1990, Locsin was named National Artist for architecture. In 1992, he was elected chair of the newly created National Commission for Culture and the Arts. In 1993, the University of Santo Tomas conferred on him an honorary doctor of humanities degree. The campus of De La Salle Canlubang, built in 2003 on land donated by his family, was named after him.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Nicanor G. Tiongson

Perez, Rodrigo D., III. 1998. “A Man of Vast Culture.” In The National Artists of the Philippines. Pasay City: Cultural Center of the Philippines and Anvil Publishing, Inc., 226-39.

Polites, Nicolas. 1977. The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin. Japan: John Weatherhill, Inc.

text:
Andres Luna de San Pedro (Andres Pardo de Tavera Luna de San Pedro) was an architect. He was born in Paris, France on 9 Sep 1887. He died in Manila on 22 Jan 1952. He was the son of the painter Juan Luna (Juan Luna de San Pedro) and Paz Pardo de Tavera. He married Grace V. McCrae. With his father and his uncle Antonio Luna, the young Luna came home to Manila in 1894. Luna’s early schooling was at Ateneo de Manila. He took art lessons under Miguel Zaragoza, then came under the tutelage of Ramon Santa Coloma and Lorenzo Guerrero. Although Luna wanted to become a painter like his father, the latter advised him to be an architect.

He studied ceramics in Japan, then returned to Manila and took the course in architecture in the International Correspondence School. The school granted him a diploma in 1911. The following year he went to Paris, France, and studied under Charles Gilardi, artist and builder; then he enrolled at the Ecole des Beaux Arts and worked in the office of Paulin, a French architect. In 1918, he was recognized as an architect diplome by the French government. He worked in the office of Emil Bertoner, a government architect. He was admitted into the Societe Centrale des Architectes Francais.

After serving as architect of the city of Manila, 1920-24, he went into private practice and trained young Filipino architects who worked under him. Luna served as president of the Philippine Institute of Architects (PIA) in its early years.

Although schooled in the academic and revivalist beaux arts style, Luna became one of the pioneers of modern design for a school in the Philippines. His work shows that he was at home with both the revivalist and modern styles, using them with impeccable taste and a flair for elegance. A photograph in the Philippine Review of Oct 1920 shows his design in the neobaroque style, which won a prize in Paris.

His works in the revivalist style include the Legarda Elementary School, built in 1922; the Alfonso Zobel house on Dewey (now Roxas) Blvd and Padre Faura; the Jacobo Zobel house, now demolished near the Malate Church; the San Vicente de Paul Chapel (now Church) on San Marcelino St, built ca 1930; and the Rafael Fernandez house on Arlegui St, remodeled in 1976 and used by Pres Corazon Aquino as her official residence.

Works in the art deco and modern styles include the Perez-Samanillo Building on the Escolta; Crystal Arcade also on the Escolta and destroyed during World War II; the Fernandez-Martinez house on Gen Solano St, San Miguel, Manila; and Saint Cecilia’s Hall of St. Scholastica’s College, also destroyed during World War II, but restored after the war. The Crystal Arcade, a commercial building housing shops and offices, is regarded as Luna’s masterpiece and considered as Manila’s most modern building before the war.

Other works of Luna mentioned in prewar publications include the Perkins house on Dewey Blvd; the Basa residence on Lepanto St, Manila; the Evangelista residence on Rizal Ave Extension, and the Sy Cong Bieng Mausoleum, built in the Chinese style at the Manila North Cemetery. The Perkins house, said to be the most beautiful in the country when it was built, won first prize in the 1925 House Beautiful Contest.

In 1902, when he was 15, one of his paintings exhibited in the Colonial Exposition in Hanoi, Indochina (now Vietnam) earned an honorable mention. In 1904, one of his entries in the Saint Louis Exposition in the United States won a silver medal. One of his works won a medal at the exhibition of the Society of Artists in Manila in 1908. At the Salon des Artistes Francais he won a prize for his design for a school of fine arts in Manila. In 1949, he became the first recipient of the Gold Medal of Merit awarded by the PIA. In 1964, he was posthumously given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

A photograph in the Philippine Review of Oct 1920 shows his design in the neobaroque style, which won a prize in Paris.

His works in the revivalist style include the Legarda Elementary School, built in 1922; the Alfonso Zobel house on Dewey (now Roxas) Blvd and Padre Faura; the Jacobo Zobel house, now demolished near the Malate Church; the San Vicente de Paul Chapel (now Church) on San Marcelino St, built ca 1930; and the Rafael Fernandez house on Arlegui St, remodeled in 1976 and used by Pres Corazon Aquino as her official residence.

Works in the art deco and modern styles include the Perez-Samanillo Building on the Escolta; Crystal Arcade also on the Escolta and destroyed during World War II; the Fernandez-Martinez house on Gen Solano St, San Miguel, Manila; and Saint Cecilia’s Hall of St. Scholastica’s College, also destroyed during World War II, but restored after the war. The Crystal Arcade, a commercial building housing shops and offices, is regarded as Luna’s masterpiece and considered as Manila’s most modern building before the war.

Other works of Luna mentioned in prewar publications include the Perkins house on Dewey Blvd; the Basa residence on Lepanto St, Manila; the Evangelista residence on Rizal Ave Extension, and the Sy Cong Bieng Mausoleum, built in the Chinese style at the Manila North Cemetery. The Perkins house, said to be the most beautiful in the country when it was built, won first prize in the 1925 House Beautiful Contest.

In 1902, when he was 15, one of his paintings exhibited in the Colonial Exposition in Hanoi, Indochina (now Vietnam) earned an honorable mention. In 1904, one of his entries in the Saint Louis Exposition in the United States won a silver medal. One of his works won a medal at the exhibition of the Society of Artists in Manila in 1908. At the Salon des Artistes Francais he won a prize for his design for a school of fine arts in Manila. In 1949, he became the first recipient of the Gold Medal of Merit awarded by the PIA. In 1964, he was posthumously given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila.
Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Alfredo Luz (Alfredo Jose Dimayuga Luz), also known as Alfredo J. Luz or AJ Luz, was an architect. He was born in Manila on 30 Dec 1922. He died in Manila on 20 Apr 1989. He and painter Arturo Luz are sons of landowners Valeriano Luz and Rosario Dimayuga of Lipa, Batangas. His mother was an interior designer. After finishing high school at Ateneo de Manila in 1940, Luz enrolled at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) School of Architecture. World War II interrupted his studies. After the war, he left for the United States and studied at the University of California (UC) Berkeley, where he received an award of distinction for one of his designs. In 1949, he graduated from UC Berkeley with a bachelor’s degree in architecture.

He returned to Manila in 1950 and, upon receiving his license, began his practice with Carlos Santos-Viola, with whom he organized the firm Luz-Santos-Viola. After the partnership ended, Luz established his own office. In 1964, he organized AJ Luz Associates, an integrated architectural and engineering firm that offered a wide range of services for domestic and international projects. In 1967, Luz migrated to Canada after selling out to his partners. The firm was renamed Arcenas and Payumo Associates. In Canada, Luz worked briefly in the Ericksen-Massey architectural firm, then for 10 years with Townley Matheson and Partners as a partner. He returned to the Philippines in 1978 and opened a new office, Ameca Total Construction System.

The major projects of AJ Luz Associates include the regional headquarters for the World Health Organization on Taft Ave, Manila, 1958; Far East Bank and Trust Company head offices in Intramuros, 1959-60; the International Rice Research Institute in Los Baños, Laguna, 1961; and the Ramon Magsaysay Building on Roxas Blvd, Manila, 1966. He also designed several buildings known by numbers: 666 T. M. Kalaw, Manila; 1414 Roxas Blvd, Manila; 1515 Roxas Blvd, Manila; and 1010 A. Mabini, Manila—all built in the 1960s. The firm’s industrial projects include buildings for the Republic Cement Corporation in Norzagaray, Bulacan, 1956; Standard Vacuum Refining Corporation in Limay, Bataan, 1959; General Milling Corporation in Mactan, Cebu, 1960; and Dole Philippines in Polomolok, South Cotabato, 1963.

Luz’s buildings are characterized by studied simplicity, reflecting an approach to design that is concerned with integrity, efficiency, and precision. “The architect’s work,” he once wrote, “places him in the triple role of artist, engineer, and social scientist. As an artist, he creates forms that will strike the proper chord in man’s heart. As an engineer, he uses the resources of the earth and… builds for permanence, making every part of his structure serve to its fullest measure. As a social scientist, he probes deeply into man’s needs and problems, and provides surroundings that will permit him to develop to the fullest extent—in comfort, harmony, and beauty.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Mañosa Brothers Architects, the sons of Manuel Mañosa Sr and film actor Maria Tronqued, Francisco, Manuel Jr, and Jose, managed an architectural firm, Mañosa Brothers and Associates, 1954-77. Their father was the first Filipino sanitary engineer, actively involved in the construction of Manila’s water system. He was assistant manager, 1931-57, then general manager of the Metropolitan Water District.

Mañosa Brothers was restructured in 1977 to respond to increasing and diverse demands by creating new autonomous firms. Mañosa-Zialcita was one such firm that became Jose T. Mañosa & Associates, Architects and Planners. The Mañosa firm’s projects included residences, offices, schools, hospitals, industrial buildings, new communities, and urban redevelopment. Among the more notable of these are the Sierra Lake Resorts and the Hidden Valley Springs Resort, both in Laguna; the Maya-Maya Resort in Batangas; the Makiling Conference Center in Laguna; Colegio de San Agustin in Makati; the restoration of the Guadalupe ruins, Makati; the Andres Soriano Memorial Hospital and Bislig Bay Lumber Company in Surigao del Sur; the Sulo Restaurant at the Makati Commercial Center; and the San Miguel Corporation Head Office in Mandaluyong City.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Francisco Mañosa (Francisco Tronqued Mañosa), also known as Bobby Mañosa, was an architect. He is a National Artist for architecture. b. Manila 12 Feb 1931. d. Manila 20 Feb 2019. He was the son of Manuel Mañosa Sr and film actor Maria Tronqued. His brothers Manuel Jr and Jose are also architects. He was married to Denise Araneta-Singh. They have three children. Mañosa graduated with a bachelor of science in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas. From 1954 to 1976, he was one of the partners in Mañosa Brothers and Associates. In 1976, he established his own office, Francisco Mañosa and Partners.

His notable works include the Tahanang Pilipino at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex on Roxas Blvd; the Shrine of Our Lady Queen of Peace at the corner of EDSA and Ortigas Ave; the Mary Immaculate Parish Church in Moonwalk Subdivision, Las Piñas, Rizal; the restoration of the historic Las Piñas Church, famous for its bamboo organ; the stations of the Metrorail Transit System or Light Rail Transit in Manila; the development of the Quezon Memorial Circle in Quezon City; and the development, restoration, and landscaping of Corregidor Island.

Mañosa has actively promoted the use of native architectural forms and indigenous materials, such as bamboo and thatch, in the creation of a distinctively Filipino architecture. The Tahanang Pilipino, a luxurious guest house also known as the Coconut Palace, features a double roof inspired by the salakot, and swing-out windows derived from the bahay kubo (nipa hut). Bamboo, rattan, capiz or oyster shell, and native textiles combined with marble, hardwood, and metal to produce a unique building and to highlight the arts and crafts of the country.

The Mary Immaculate Parish Church is a tentlike roof of palm leaves hung by steel cables from concrete pylons. Dove-shaped lamps made of Capiz hover in circular formation under the ceiling. The stations of the Metrorail Transit have steep hip roofs similar to those of rural and mountain houses.

In 1982, the city of Manila conferred the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award on Mañosa. In 1989, the United Architects of the Philippines conferred on him its Gold Medal of Merit. He was named National Artist for architecture in 2018.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, updated by Libertine S. Dela Cruz

Jose Mañosa (Jose Tronqued Mañosa) is an architect. He was born in Manila on 3 Feb 1933. He is the son of Manuel Mañosa Sr and film actor Maria Tronqued. His brothers Francisco and Manuel Jr are also architects. He is married to Margarita Syquia. They have four children. An architecture graduate of Mapua Institute of Technology, Mañosa is the consulting architect of San Miguel Corporation (SMC). He is also the consulting architect of the Philippine Communication Satellite Corporation and Eastern Telecommunication Philippines Inc. He served as consulting architect of the Ministry of Transportation and Communication, 1980-85.

His best-known work is the SMC Head Office in the Ortigas complex in Mandaluyong City. It is one of the outstanding buildings of the contemporary period. Mañosa has designed buildings for SMC in Makati, Pasig, Quezon City, and Valenzuela; Tagaytay; Canlubang, Laguna; San Fernando, Pampanga; Baguio City; Mandaue, Cebu; Bacolod City; and Davao City.

His works include office buildings, school buildings, industrial buildings, hotels, airport terminals, banks, shops and stores, restaurants, condominiums, and residences. His services have been engaged for projects in Guam, Saudi Arabia, Brunei, Singapore, as well as Guangzhou and Canton in China.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Manuel Mañosa Jr (Manuel Tronqued Mañosa Jr) is an architect. He was born in Manila on 15 Jan 1927. He is the son of Manuel Mañosa Sr and film actor Maria Tronqued and the brother of Francisco and Jose, both architects. He is married to dancer and choreographer Maria Luisa (Inday) Gaston. They have four children, three of whom—Mia Monica, Maiqui, and Mimil—are dancers. In 1949, Mañosa graduated with a bachelor of science in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas, then took advanced studies in architecture at the Ciudad Universitaria in Madrid, Spain. In 1952, he obtained a master in architecture from the Catholic University of America in Washington, DC. While in Spain he worked in several government offices engaged in housing and urban development. He taught design, housing, and planning at the Manuel Luis Quezon University School of Architecture, 1954-63. He was a senior partner in Mañosa Brothers and Associates, 1954-77. In 1976, he founded Planning Resources and Operations Systems (PROS), a multidisciplinary planning firm of which he continues to be president.

Mañosa was in charge of the renovation and rehabilitation of the San Agustin Church and Monastery in Intramuros in 1982. He co-authored the planning report on the Manila-Cavite Coastal Road Reclamation Project and a paper on architectural accessibility for the disabled. He is a fellow of the Philippine Institute of Architects, United Architects of the Philippines, and the Philippine Institute of Environmental Planners.

Mañosa’s firm, PROS, has participated in the planning of mass-housing projects for both the government and the private sector, as well as urban renewal and camp-conversion projects. These include the Bagong Nayon Housing in Antipolo, Rizal; the Bataan Workers Village and the Refugee Processing Center in Bataan; the Clark Field and Camp John Hay Conversion Plan; the Metro Manila Camps Conversion Plan; and the Intramuros Development Plan. PROS designed the EDSA Bagong Lipunan Sites and Services or BLISS Housing Project for the National Housing Authority.

Mañosa was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila in 1978.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Tomas Mapua (Tomas Bautista Mapua) was an architect. He was born in Manila on 21 Dec 1888. He died on 22 Dec 1965. He was the son of Juan Mapua and Justina Bautista. He married Rita Moya and they had three children. After Mapua’s early schooling at Ateneo de Manila and Liceo de Manila, he was enrolled at Boones Preparatory School in Berkeley, California, 1903-07. He studied at Cornell University where he obtained a bachelor’s degree in architecture in 1911. Mapua was the first registered architect in the Philippines.

He worked as a draftsman at the Bureau of Public Works, 1911-15, then resigned to go into private practice. In 1918, he returned to the bureau and was appointed supervising architect, a post he held until 1927. In this capacity, he supervised the construction of numerous government buildings in Manila and in the provinces. After leaving government service, he established the Mapua-Yuchiangco-Tiaoque Construction Works Inc, which undertook the construction of various major buildings, among them the Manila Post Office Building.

In 1925, he founded the Mapua Institute of Technology (MIT), which began as a night school for working students. The institute, which was first housed in a portion of the old La Vanguardia Building on Carriedo St, has since grown into a major engineering and architectural school. The establishment of MIT and the high standard of training it has maintained are his most significant contributions to the development of architecture and the architectural profession in the Philippines.

Mapua was the chairperson of the first Board of Examiners for Architects in the Philippines. He was one of the founders—and later president—of the Philippine Architects Society, which was later renamed Philippine Institute of Architects. He was also one of the founders of the Philippine Association of Colleges and Universities.

The buildings he designed include the De La Salle College (now University) Building on Taft Ave, the Centro Escolar University Building on Mendiola St, the Nurses Home at the Philippine General Hospital on Taft Ave, and the J. Mapua Memorial Hall in Intramuros. Among the many residences he designed was the Arsenio Locsin house and his own house, both on Taft Ave.

In 1964, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Engracio Mariano (Engracio de Leon Mariano) was an architect. He was born in Manila on 29 Mar 1916. His parents are Ceferino Mariano and Teodora de Leon. He and his wife Juanita Baltazar had two children one of whom, Francisco, is also an architect. After graduating from the University of Santo Tomas with a bachelor of science degree in architecture in 1940, Mariano worked as an architectural designer in the office of Luis Araneta. He was an architectural designer for the city of Manila, 1942-44, and assistant architect in the Port Command of the United States Army in Manila, 1945-47. He was employed as architectural designer in the offices of Gines Rivera and Carlos Arguelles and Associates, 1945-50, becoming an associate in the latter office in 1950. In 1973, he established his own office, E. L. Mariano and Associates. Aside from being a noteworthy designer, Mariano is an acknowledged master of architectural rendering. He taught architectural design, 1950-81.

In 1969, he wrote the article “This Business of Architectural Rendering.” He is a fellow of the Philippine Institute of Architects and the United Architects of the Philippines.

One of Mariano’s works as an independent practitioner is the 20-story Bank of the Philippine Islands Head Office on Ayala Ave and Paseo de Roxas, Makati. His projects for the bank include new branch buildings and offices in various parts of the country as well as the renovation of existing offices in Metro Manila.

He has designed office buildings, condominiums, commercial centers, shopping malls, a beach resort, chapels, town houses, vacation houses, and residences. Projects overseas include Singapura Sports Complex in Singapore and condominiums in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

In 1985, Mariano was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text:
Felipe M. Mendoza (Felipe Marcelo Mendoza) was an architect. He was born in Manila on 26 May 1917. He died on 28 Apr 2000. The son of Sebastian Mendoza and Damasa Marcelo, he was married to Aurora Alisangco. They had seven children. Mendoza graduated from Mapua Institute of Technology in 1938 with a degree in architecture. He taught at Mapua, 1946-65, and lectured for two years at the University of the Philippines.

Mendoza is distinguished for his commitment to raising the standards of the architectural profession. During his two terms in 1979 and 1980 as president of the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP), he worked for the formulation of a new five-year, ladder-type curriculum for the bachelor’s course in architecture, which with government approval was immediately implemented. He undertook the preparation of UAP documents on the practice of architecture, particularly the Architect’s National Code, consisting of the code of ethical conduct and the standards of professional practice, and the UAP General Conditions.

He was president of the Philippine Institute of Architects in 1965, the United Technological Organizations of the Philippines in 1965, and the Philippine Federation of Professional Associations in 1981. He actively participated in the Architects’ Regional Council Asia, a council of architectural associations from 11 Asian countries.

His major works include the Batasang Pambansa Buildings in Quezon City; the Development Academy of the Philippines Building in Pasig City; the Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation Building on Buendia, Makati, and 23 of its branches throughout the country; the Philippine Commercial and Industrial Bank Building (Antonino Building) on T. M. Kalaw, Manila; the Far Eastern University Hospital on Nicanor Reyes, Manila; the Library and the Science Center buildings of Xavier University in Cagayan de Oro; the San Jose Seminary Building in the Ateneo de Manila University campus in Quezon City; the Assumption School buildings in Antipolo, Rizal; and the Mormon Temple in Greenmeadows, Quezon City.

He designed seven new buildings for the International Rice Research Institute in Los Baños, Laguna, 1976-91. The municipal building, public market, multipurpose hall, and glorieta in San Fernando, La Union, were among his government projects. He also did projects in Guam and the United States, including the 250-room Suehiro Hotel and the Safeway Supermarket.

Nature plays an important part in Mendoza’s approach to design. He is meticulous about orientation when planning a building and makes the fullest possible use of natural light and ventilation. Through large openings and interior gardens, he brings the outdoors indoors. The use of wide eaves and balconies to protect openings gives his works a distinctly tropical character.

In 1976, Mendoza received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila. In 1982, the UAP conferred on him its highest honor, the Likha Award and Gold Medal of Merit. He was the first recipient of the award.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III
