text:
Angel E. Nakpil (Angel Ernesto Sancho Nakpil) was an architect. He was born in Manila on 20 Feb 1914. He died on 2 Nov 1980. He was the son of Enriqueta Sancho and Ramon Nakpil, who studied industrial design as a government pensionado in the United States. He first married Carmen Diaz, with whom he had two daughters. After her death, he married the writer Carmen Guerrero, then already a widow; they had three children, one of whom, Luis, is an architect. National Artist for architecture Juan F. Nakpil is his cousin. After finishing high school at De La Salle College (now University), he studied architecture at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), graduating in 1936. He did graduate work in Harvard University, where he came under the influence of Walter Gropius, founder of the Bauhaus in Germany and an exponent of the International Style, who was then a professor at Harvard. Nakpil earned a master’s degree in regional planning in 1940.

Upon returning to Manila he was engaged by the US Army Engineer’s Office. In 1941, he began working with the Land Planning Commission and was assigned to prepare a new plan for Baguio City. With the outbreak of World War II, the project was abandoned.

He served as commissioner of the City Planning Office of Manila, 1947-49. In 1949, he established his own office as architect and city planner. In 1976, he joined Gabriel P. Formoso and Partners as a senior partner. He taught at the UST School of Architecture, 1950-61, and served as its dean, 1959-61. He was a member of the Philippine Institute of Architects and was a charter member of the United Architects of the Philippines, founded in 1975. His major works include the National Press Club (NPC) Building on Magallanes Drive, Manila; the former head office of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT) on Dela Rosa St, Makati; various buildings for PLDT; the Lopez Museum Building on Lancaster St, Pasay; the Picache Building in Quiapo, Manila; the Roche Building on Pasong Tamo, Makati; and the Petrona Apartments on Taft Ave, Manila. His designs are characterized by both discipline and daring. While the cylindrical, glass-sheathed stairway of the NPC Building was daring at the time, it was in fact so designed to keep the vertical traffic of the multi-purpose building away from the normal functions of each floor. In the Petrona Apartments, the massive wall facing the street protects the rooms from glare and street noise, while windows opening to the sides of the property admit the breeze. The Lopez Museum Building is triangular in plan and has cantilevered floors.

Perceptive, articulate, and highly cultured, Nakpil wrote a number of articles—among them, “Architecture in the Philippines,” “Filipino Modern,” and “Homes for the Middle Income Group.”

In 1974, Nakpil was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text:
Juan F. Nakpil (Juan Felipe de Jesus Nakpil) was an architect. He is a National Artist for architecture. He was born in Manila on 26 May 1899. He died in Manila on 7 May 1986. He was the only son of composer Julio Nakpil and Gregoria de Jesus, the widow of Andres Bonifacio. He was married to Anita Noble, by whom he had three sons, Ariston and Francisco, both architects, and Eulogio, a civil engineer. After graduating from Manila High School in 1917, Nakpil took up engineering at the University of the Philippines (UP). Then he enrolled at the University of Kansas, where he obtained a civil engineering degree in 1922. While studying in Kansas he supported himself by playing the piano for the Filipino String Orchestra. He also studied in France, where he obtained a diploma in architecture from the Fontainebleau School of Fine Arts in 1925. The following year, 1926, he received a master’s degree in architecture from Harvard University.

Nakpil returned to Manila in 1926 and worked as assistant architect in the Bureau of Public Works. In 1928, he became a partner in the firm of architect Andres Luna de San Pedro and structural engineer Jose G. Cortes, and with them designed the Perez-Samanillo Building on the Escolta. As the designer of Puyat and Sons, 1928-31, he introduced art deco motifs into the furniture industry. In 1930, he won second prize in the Bonifacio Monument Competition. That same year he opened his own office.

He taught at Mapua Institute of Technology, 1927-31, and at the University of Santo Tomas, 1931-38. In addition, he took part in various initiatives to upgrade building standards and improve the condition of architects—for example, through the Building Code Committee of Manila. Soon after World War II he formed a partnership with his cousin Angel E. Nakpil and his brother-in-law Carlos Santos-Viola. In 1953, with his sons, he formed a partnership, Juan F. Nakpil and Sons. Both Ariston (b. 1928) and Francisco (b. 1929) had obtained a master’s degree in architecture from Cranbrook Academy, while Eulogio (b. 1931) had obtained a master’s degree in civil engineering from Yale University. The partnership was dissolved after the death of Ariston in 1981. Nakpil was one of the founders and the first president of the Philippine Architects’ Society, established in 1933, which later became the Philippine Institute of Architects.

From the start of his career and together with his sons, he designed more than 200 buildings, including office buildings, movie houses, hospitals, school buildings, churches, and residences. His first building, the Geronimo de los Reyes Building, was in the art deco style, with which he became familiar when he visited the Exposition Internationale des Arts Decoratifs in Paris in 1925. Other major works before World War II include the Capitan Pepe Building, the Quezon Institute Administration Building and Pavilions, the Manila Jockey Club, the Avenue Hotel and Theater, Quiapo Church (the nave of which has been altered), and the residence of Gen Vicente Lim on Vito Cruz, Pasay City.

The range of his style is represented in the neobaroque Quiapo Church; the art deco Nakpil-Bautista Pylon at the North Cemetery, which combined stylized flora and angular forms; and the Manila Jockey Club, done in the then-emerging International Style, notable for its minimal surface decor and for the facade’s interplay between two rounded forms: the entrance hall and the glass-enclosed circular stairwell.

His major works after the war include the Philippine Trust Building on Plaza Goiti and the Security Bank and Trust Building constructed in 1954. Nakpil undertook the reconstruction of the Rizal house in Calamba, Laguna, which was completed in 1950.

During the immediate postwar period, the buildings of Juan Nakpil and his sons, as exemplified by the UP Administration and Library Buildings, and Ever and State Theaters on Rizal Ave, at first kept to the rigors of the International Style. However, in the 1960s, an exuberant warmth began to affirm itself. The use of folded plate as a structural shell encouraged the use of diamond-shaped supports on the exterior. Within appeared a rich play of textures: pebble-washed floors, adobe screen walls, wooden stairs and screens with a natural finish. Examples of this new style were the now-demolished Rizal Theater in Makati, the Baldwin Young house in Forbes Park, the Rufino Building on Ayala Ave, and the Commercial Bank and Trust Company Building at the Quezon Blvd rotunda in Quezon City.

Nakpil received the Gold Medal of Merit in 1950 from the Philippine Institute of Architects, and was named Chevalier of the Legion of Honor in 1954. In 1968, he was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila. In 1973, he was named National Artist for architecture.  Written by Fernando N. Zialcita

article_title: National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA)
text:
National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) was created by Republic Act 7356 on 3 Apr 1992. It was preceded by the Presidential Commission on Culture and Arts, established by Executive Order 118 in 1987. The NCCA is tasked to formulate policies for the development of culture and arts; encourage artistic creation within a climate of artistic freedom; develop and promote the Filipino national culture and arts; and preserve Filipino cultural heritage.

The law stipulates the objectives of NCCA: “to formulate policies for the development of culture and the arts; implement such policies and programs in coordination with cultural agencies affiliated to it: the Cultural Center of the Philippines, the National Historical Institute (now the National Historical Commission of the Philippines), the National Museum, the National Library, the Commission on the Filipino Language, and the Records Management and Archives Office; administer the National Endowment Fund for Culture and the Arts (NEFCA); encourage artistic creation within a climate of artistic freedom; develop and promote the Filipino national culture and arts; and preserve the Filipino national culture” (NCCA, n.d.).

In particular, the NCCA seeks to encourage the continuing and balanced development of a pluralistic culture—that is, multiethnic—by the people themselves; conserve and promote the nation’s historical and cultural heritage; ensure the widest dissemination of artistic and cultural products within the country and overseas; preserve and integrate traditional culture and their various creative expressions as a dynamic part of the national cultural mainstream; and ensure that standards of excellence are pursued in programs and activities by encouraging and supporting continuing discussions and debates on Philippine culture.

The NCCA has four subcommissions. Under these subcommissions are 22 independent committees composed of artists and cultural workers considered experts in their fields, who advice the NCCA on matters of direction, policies, and programs. The Subcommission on Cultural Heritage is composed of six national committees: the National Committees on Archives, Art Galleries, Historical Research, Libraries and Information Services, Monuments and Sites, and Museums. The Subcommission on the Arts includes the National Committees on Architecture and Allied Arts, Cinema, Dance, Dramatic Arts, Literary Arts, Music, and Visual Arts. The National Committee on Literary Arts evaluates and funds projects that include regional and national writing workshops, literary awards, conferences, and its flagship Philippine Writers Festival project, often held during the Philippine Arts Festival on February of each year. The Subcommission on Cultural Dissemination is composed of the National Committees on Education, Communication, and Language and Translation. The Subcommission on Cultural Communities and Traditional Arts includes the National Committees on Northern Cultural Communities, Central Cultural Communities, and Southern Cultural Communities.

The NCCA is governed by a Board of Commissioners composed of 15 members—namely, the NCCA chairman and executive director; the chairpersons of the Senate Committee on Education, Arts, and Culture, the House Committee on Basic Education and Culture, the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino, and the National Historical Commission of the Philippines; the director of the National Museum and the National Library of the Philippines; the executive director of the National Archives of the Philippines; the president of the Cultural Center of the Philippines; as well as representatives from the Departments of Education and Tourism and the private sector. This Board of Commissioners is also assisted by a National Advisory Board composed of 19 national committee heads.

Its projects and activities have covered skills enhancement; research, documentation, and data banking; awards; scholarships; competitions; publications; conferences, seminars, or workshops; performances, exhibits, or festivals; international desk; and women’s concerns. Examples of supported projects for 2015 include festivals in Bokod (Benguet) and Sagada (Mountain Province); Rizal Arts Festival; 40th International Bamboo Organ Festival, Las Piñas; Cinema in the Regions; performing arts and exhibitions, like Manhid: The Pinoy Superhero of Ballet Philippines Foundation and the Salvador Bernal retrospective; and seminars, workshops, and historical conferences like the 24th Annual Manila Studies Conference and the Seminar Workshop on Waray Poetry Performance. It is also actively involved in the restoration of the heritage churches damaged during the Oct 2013 earthquake that devastated the Visayas. NCCA has a publication department, which carries some 103 titles consisting primarily of print, although CDs and e-books as media of dissemination have been introduced. Some printed works are monographs and journals, like Bulawan, Ani, and Espasyo, which are published periodically.  Written by NCCA and Rosalinda Galang, updated by Glenn Diaz

article_title: National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP)
text:
The National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP), formerly known as the National Historical Institute (NHI), traces its ancestry to the Philippine Historical Research and Markers Committee (PHRMC), which was established by American governor-general Frank J. Murphy through Executive Order 451 in 1933 to identify, designate, and mark historic sites in the country. The PHRMC introduced the cast iron plaque with black background and white letters, which has remained as the type of historical marker used to the present. The PHRMC was replaced by the Philippine Historical Committee (PHC) during the Commonwealth period, but the subsequent Japanese occupation in 1941 terminated its activities.

After the war, PHC spearheaded the restoration of the Rizal Shrine in Calamba, Laguna, acquired several Rizaliana memorabilia, and marked more than 400 historic sites. Other historical agencies that coexisted with PHC are the Jose Rizal National Centennial Commission and the National Heroes Commission (NHC). The National Historical Commission was established in 1965 through Republic Act 4368, which abolished the PHC and the NHC, with the newly formed commission assuming their functions. However, the passage of Presidential Decree No. 1 in 1972 saw the reorganization of the National Historical Commission into the National Historical Institute.

With the enactment of Republic Act 10086 in 2010, the NHI was renamed National Historical Commission of the Philippines. As a commission, it has upgraded its status and become co-partners of other government historical and cultural bodies like the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

In 2011, the NHCP initiated its five-year NHCP Shrine Development Plan, which aimed to popularize the life and achievements of Filipino national heroes through the structural and curatorial redevelopment of shrine museums using the latest interactive exhibits, holograms, and computer-based technologies.

The NHCP has also expanded the marking of sites by declaring Dapitan a Heritage Zone in 2011. It also recognized Iloilo’s business district as Heritage Zone in 2014. A Heritage Zone is not just a single building or structure but a group of buildings, open sites like plazas, bridges, and streets of historical and cultural significance and considered part of the national patrimony.

The NHCP is mandated by Republic Act 10086, “Strengthening Peoples’ Nationalism through Philippine History Act,” to be “the primary government agency responsible for history and the authority to determine all factual matters relating to official Philippine history.” Accordingly, it is tasked to conduct and support all kinds of research relating to Philippine national and local history; develop educational materials in various media; implement historical educational activities for the popularization of Philippine history; disseminate information regarding Philippine historical events, dates, places, and personages; undertake and prescribe the manner of restoration, conservation, and protection of the country’s historical movable and immovable objects; manage, maintain, and administer national shrines, monuments, historical sites, edifices, and landmarks of significant historic-cultural value; and actively engage in the settlement or resolution of controversies or issues relative to historical personages, places, dates, and events.

To carry out its mandate, the NHCP works through four main divisions: Research, Publications, and Heraldry Division; Historic Preservation Division; Historic Sites and Education Division; and Materials Research and Conservation Division. The Historic Preservation Division maintains the National Registry of Historic Structures in the Philippines.

The NHCP has been active in undertaking reconstruction and conservation of historic and cultural sites damaged by the Oct 2013 earthquake and the Nov 2013 typhoon Yolanda, which devastated the Visayas.  Written by Bryan Anthony C. Paraiso, with notes from René B. Javellana

text:
The National Museum of the Philippines was founded in Manila in 1901 during the American colonial period and was formerly called the Insular Museum of Ethnology, National History and Commerce. Now located near the Intramuros complex, the National Museum is mandated to preserve, conserve, and protect the country’s material heritage, movable and immovable cultural properties, and engage in research dissemination and museum education programs pertinent to its collections. It also administers the different museum system offices around the country.

 

The neoclassical buildings (restored after World War II) that now house the National Museum collections were part of the American architect Daniel Burnham’s urban plan for Manila, encompassing the fields of fine arts, archaeology, ethnography, and biology. The building complex includes the Museum of Fine Arts (formerly the Senate Building), which houses the Philippine Fine Arts collection; the Museum of Anthropology (formerly the Finance Building), which displays the diversity of the Philippine ethnological material culture; the Planetarium, which is the science and technology museum of the country; and the Museum of Natural History (the retrofitted Agriculture, later Department of Tourism Building), which will house the natural science collection. As a whole, the National Museum collections stand as tangible evidence of the depth and wealth of the material culture of the Philippines.

 

The National Museum of Fine Arts is located in the historic building that housed the Philippine Senate and the House of Representatives and the 1934 Constitutional Convention. Highlights of the permanent exhibit at Hall of Masters include 19th-century paintings such as Juan Luna’s Spoliarium, 1884, and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo’s El Asesinato del Gobernador Fernando Bustamante y su Hijo (The Assassination of Governor Fernando Bustamante and Son), late 19th century. Both are painted in the academic style and signify the political conditions during the late Spanish colonial period. Other works in the gallery consist of representative works of artists from the Spanish colonial period, the American occupation, and post-World War II period. These artists include Fabian de la Rosa, Fernando Amorsolo, Jorge Pineda, and Irineo Miranda, who painted in styles ranging from the academic, romantic, to impressionist. Early modernist works consist of pieces from the likes of Victorio Edades, Diosdado Lorenzo, Vicente Manansala, Carlos V. Francisco, Hernando R. Ocampo, Cesar Legaspi, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, Ang Kiukok, Jose Joya, Fernando Zobel, and Mauro Malang Santos. The museum’s sculpture collection consists of several 17th-19th century carved religious objects, reliefs, polychromes, and an altarpiece from the Church of San Nicolas de Tolentino in Dimiao, Bohol. The sculptures of Guillermo Tolentino, Isabelo Tampinco, Graciano Nepomuceno, and Jose Rizal are also part of the sculpture collection.

 

The National Museum of Anthropology exhibits the archaeological and ethnographic collection of the National Museum in the former Finance Building. The narrative of this collection traces the lineage of the country’s prehistorical and precolonial provenance through recovered artifacts, documentation of former and extant practices, and selected pieces from the museum archives. The archaeological collections include the Manunggul jar, 890-710 BC, a late Neolithic period jar used in burial rituals signifying an ancient worldview of the afterlife; the Tabon cave skullcap, 14500 BC, considered one of the country’s earliest human remains excavated in Palawan; and representative text in the ancient system of writing called the baybayin script. The artifacts recovered from the San Diego galleon that sank in 1600 near Fortune Island, Batangas, makes up a major part of the permanent exhibition. The ethnographic collection highlights the different cultural practices of Filipino people groups based on the character of the country’s geography and social relationships articulated through diverse economic systems, lifeways, religious worldviews, language, and everyday material culture. These include examples of culturally significant objects from Northern and Southern Philippines in the form of textiles, carvings, metalcraft, and examples of traditional houses.  Written by Clod Krister Marlan V. Yambao and Cecilia S. De La Paz

text:
Manuel Noche (Manuel Maximo Lopez del Castillo Noche) is an architect and author. He was born in Manila on 13 Nov 1962. He is the youngest of three boys of Vicente M. Noche of Taal, Batangas, and Romana L. Lopez del Castillo of Tondo and San Juan del Monte, Manila. He comes from a clan of academicians and historians. His grandfather Jose C. Lopez del Castillo was a noted archivist and lawyer who discovered one of the Philippines’s oldest published books, El Libro de las Quatro Postrimerias del Hombre (The Book of the Last Things of Man). His great grandfather Epifanio A. Lopez del Castillo, a schoolmaster and founder of the Escuela Catolica in Tondo in the late 19th century had Andres Bonifacio as his student in Spanish.

Noche received his bachelor’s degree in architecture at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1986, and a masteral degree in architecture, major in environmental design and engineering, at the Bartlett School of Architecture and Planning in London, England, in 1989. Noche is the chief executive officer of ARCONIC Professional Services, a multidisciplinary architectural planning and design company, which offers a wide range of services from master planning, design, and construction documentation. He is an assistant professor in both the College of Architecture and the Graduate School of UST.

As a senior researcher in UST, he has undertaken researches and written on Spanish and American colonial architecture and engineering in the Philippines, including lighthouses, baptisteries, cemeteries, church retablos, bridges, and the Escolta. His significant publications are Lonely Sentinels of the Sea: The Spanish Colonial Lighthouses in the Philippines, 2005, and Puentes de España en las Filipinas: The Colonial Bridges in the Philippines, 2011, for which in 2012 he received the UST Albertus Magnus Award (Best Book Category). He has also contributed to various journals, magazines, and dailies, and curated exhibitions.

Noche is an active member of the Heritage Conservation Society and the International Council on Monuments and Sites. He received a Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 2008.  Written by Clarissa L. Avendaño

text:
Fernando H. Ocampo (Fernando Hizon Ocampo) was an architect. He was born in Santa Rita, Pampanga on 7 Aug 1897. He died on 10 May 1984. He was the son of Dr Basilio Ocampo and Leoncia Hizon. With his wife Lourdes Luciano, he had four children, one of whom, Fernando Jr, became an architect. Ocampo graduated with a bachelor of arts degree from Ateneo de Manila in 1914, then studied surveying at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he graduated with a civil engineering degree in 1919. After earning an architecture degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1921, he took advanced architectural studies at the American Academy in Rome in 1922. He worked in the architectural firm of Ballinger and Perrot in Philadelphia. In 1923, he began working in the architecture division of the Bureau of Public Works, and in 1926 was named assistant architect. He started private practice in 1928 and formed a partnership with Tomas Arguelles. Ocampo was one of the founders of the UST School of Fine Arts and Architecture, established in 1930, and a member of the Board of Examiners for Architects, 1929-30. In 1933, he co-founded the Philippine Architects Society, later named the Philippine Institute of Architects.

Although better known at present for having designed the reconstructed Manila Metropolitan Cathedral in 1958, Ocampo was in fact one of the pioneers of modern Filipino architecture, a contemporary of Andres Luna de San Pedro and Juan Nakpil. His early works include the Paterno Building at the foot of Santa Cruz (now MacArthur) Bridge, the Oriental Club, and the Cu Un Jieng Building on the Escolta. The Central Seminary Building at the UST campus appears traditionalist in design, but with the horizontal thrust of its balconies and its art deco ornaments, it exemplifies the modern style of the period. The residence designed by Ocampo for Benigno Aquino Sr in San Miguel, Manila, is a fine example of art deco architecture of the 1930s—with its boxlike forms, flat overhangs, porthole windows, rounded corners, and roof decks that suggest an ocean liner.

Ocampo’s works in the traditionalist mode include the Arguelles Building on Rizal Ave; the Sacred Heart Novitiate Building in Novaliches; the Admiral Apartments on Dewey (now Roxas) Blvd; the restored Cathedral of the Assumption in San Fernando, Pampanga; and the Church of Our Lady of the Most Holy Rosary in Angeles City.

In 1964, Ocampo received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text: Luciano Oliver was an architect. He was active ca. 1854-73. As a municipal architect of Manila, he was the leading practitioner in the mid-19th century. Among his works are the twin towers of the San Agustin Church in Intramuros, 1854; the neoclassical Taal Basilica, 1857-65; the facade and twin towers of Tambobong (now Malabon) Church, 1861-63; and the third floor of the Augustinian Monastery in Intramuros and its grand staircase, 1861-64. He repaired the Aduana in 1861 and the Antipolo Church in 1870, and installed a metal dome, manufactured in Paris, for the Tondo Church in 1873. He was one of the architects engaged for the reconstruction of the Manila Cathedral in 1870, whose plan exists in the Archivo Historico Nacional in Madrid. He also worked on Malacañan.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
Edith Oliveros (Edith League Oliveros) was an interior designer. She was born in Manila on 8 May 1938. She died in Manila on 14 Oct 2013. She was the daughter of Salvador Oliveros and Isabel League. A 1957 home economics graduate, cum laude, from the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), Oliveros got a master’s degree in interior design from the Drexel Institute in Philadelphia. She headed the Edith Oliveros Design Studio. She was a member of the board of directors of both the Philippine School of Interior Design and the Philippine Institute of Interior Designers. She wrote a column on interior design for the Philippine Daily Inquirer.

She designed the interiors of hotels, restaurants, clubhouses, resorts, offices, banks, showrooms, shopping centers, condominium units, and residences. Her major works include the interiors of the Admiral Hotel on Roxas Blvd, Manila; the Cebu Plaza Hotel in Cebu City; the Wack Wack Golf and Country Club in Mandaluyong; the Philippine House in Chicago, Illinois; and the Philippine House in Houston, Texas. She also designed parks, such as the Alaala Park in Pagsanjan and the town plaza of Santa Rosa, both in Laguna.

Oliveros worked in a variety of styles. Her early projects were in the International Style, characterized by the use of chromium, glass, and leather. She developed an eclectic style that combines the contemporary with the traditional and Filipino. Her works reflect the trend in architecture and other arts to create forms of expression rooted in tradition and native culture, yet in harmony with the age of high technology. In 2013, Oliveros and Raquel Baltazar-Florendo published a brief history of interior design in the Philippines titled Interior Design in the Philippines: A Retrospect of Spaces and Culture.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

text: Bartolome Palatino (Bartolome Miguel Palatino) was a buider and sculptor. He was born in Paete, Laguna on 1787. He died after 1853. Palatino came from a prominent artistic family of Paete, Laguna, being the nephew of Canuto Madriñan, a sculptor. Palatino is best known for his work on the Morong Church, for which he built a baroque facade with a protruding central section to carry the belfry. Palatino encouraged many talented carvers to turn to the carving of religious images from furniture and toys. He was 66 years old when he worked on the Morong Church.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
William Parsons (William Edward Parsons) was an architect. He was born in Akron, Ohio, USA on 19 Jun 1872. He died in 1939. He studied at Yale University where he earned an arts degree in 1895, then at Columbia University for a master’s degree in architecture, graduating in 1897. At Yale, one of his classmates was Francis Burton Harrison, who became governor-general of the Philippines. He received the McKim fellowship, which allowed him to enroll at the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris, France, 1898-1901. Returning to his home country, he worked in the architectural office of John Galen Howard in New York.

On his return to the United States from his survey trip in the Philippines, Daniel H. Burnham began to search for an architect who would supervise the implementation of his plans for Manila and Baguio. Impressed with Parsons’s credentials, Burnham chose him to be the Philippine government’s consulting architect. Arriving in Manila on 17 Nov 1905, Parsons organized the American and Filipino staff of the architectural office of the Bureau of Public Works. Under his contract with the government, Parsons would be paid 6,000 US dollars a year. To augment this income, he was allowed to engage in private practice.

Parsons’s work included implementing Burnham’s plans for Manila and Baguio, preparing city plans for Cebu and Zamboanga, planning provincial government centers, and designing as well as supervising the design of buildings for Manila and various parts of the country. His authority was vast, allowing him to supervise designs of all buildings and parks from the national to the municipal level. Deploring the policies of President Wilson and Gov-Gen Harrison, which aimed to prepare the Philippines for early independence, Parsons resigned from his position in 1914. On returning to the United States, he joined the Chicago Office of Edward H. Bennet, a former associate of Burnham.

Parsons’s first building was the psychiatric ward at San Lazaro Hospital, 1907; the British Manila Club, 1908; Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA) Building and Brent Episcopal Church in Baguio, and the Army-Navy Club, all in 1909. His major buildings include the Philippine General Hospital, 1910; Elks Club, 1911; Manila Hotel, 1912; and the Normal School and its women’s dormitory, both in 1914. He also designed the provincial government buildings of Albay and Pampanga, both in 1907; Laguna and Capiz, both in 1908; and Tarlac, 1909. Throughout the Philippines, he also designed schoolhouses and markets like Paco, 1912.

Toward the end of his assignment in the Philippines, Parsons designed the first buildings of the University of the Philippines (UP), 1913—in particular, the University Hall on Taft Ave and Padre Faura St. One of his enduring legacies is his work on other schools. He designed Tondo Intermediate School, 1909, which was replicated for the Cebu High School, 1914. He was also responsible for planning the Gabaldon Schools, whose prototypic plans were published by the Bureau of Education in 1912, Bulletin No. 37 School Buildings and Grounds. His other works, although lesser known, were the Manila City Aquarium, 1912, and the Bilibid Prison Hospital and Gateway, Muntinlupa, 1907. The Cebu Aduana or Custom House, 1911, and the Tarlac Provincial Prison, 1913, are attributed to him. Other works were the Tondo Fire Station, 1912; the Cottage of the Singalong Experimental Station, 1906; the Gatehouse of the Reservoir of the New Waterworks System, 1907; the Sewer Pumping Stations of Manila, 1908; the UP College of Surgery and Medicine, 1910; the Communicable Disease Ward at San Lazaro Hospital, 1913; the Philippine School of Arts and Trade, 1914; and his own house facing Manila Bay.

Parsons’s early works in the Philippines can be characterized as modern, being simplified versions of 19th-century Spanish-Filipino architecture. One factor that contributed to his early style was the use of reinforced concrete, which, with its plain, clean surfaces, and clean edges, made buildings look lighter. In his later works, mainly for UP, Parsons turned to the neoclassic, thereby establishing the style for future government buildings.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

 

Source

Lico, Gerard. 2008. Arkitekturang Filipino: A History of Architecture and Urbanism in the Philippines. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

text:
Sergio Peñasales (Sergio Villar Peñasales) is an architect and landscape architect. He was born in Iloilo City on 10 Jun 1935. The son of Silvestre Peñasales and Consuelo Villar, he graduated with a degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas in 1957. He obtained a master’s degree in landscape architecture from the College of Environmental Design, University of California (UC) Berkeley, 1963. He worked as job captain in the office of Angel E. Nakpil, 1956-60. He was designer-planner in the firm Royston, Hanamoto, Mayes and Beck, landscape architects, 1962-64. In 1964, he established his own office in Iloilo City. He taught at the Department of Architecture, College of Technology, University of Iloilo, 1966-71, and has been a guest lecturer in various institutions. He taught at the University of San Agustin, Iloilo, 1995-98.


Peñasales has written articles on architecture, landscape architecture, and conservation of the environment for Iloilo and Manila publications. He is a member of the Philippine Institute of Architects, the Philippine Association of Landscape Architects, and the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP). He is a trustee of the Iloilo Cultural and Research Foundation. He was a member of the Iloilo City Planning and Development Board, 1966-78. He was a member of the board of examiners for landscape architects of the Professional Regulation Commission, 1983-86. In 1985, he became a fellow of the UAP.


His major projects as an architect include the Museo Iloilo, Iloilo City; Tinucuan Chapel, Passi, Iloilo; and the Barbaza Church, Barbaza, Antique. As a landscape architect, his projects include the University Mall, University of Iloilo; Iloilo Memorial Park, Balantang, Iloilo City; and Amphitheatre Green and Man in His Environment, both in Oton, Iloilo. He has prepared master plans for the development of the town plazas in Molo, Jaro, and La Paz in Iloilo.

Peñasales received Alma Mater Award from Iloilo School of Arts and Trades in 1975 and an award for environmental development from the University Santo Tomas Alumni Association in 1993.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Dolly Q. Perez (Dolores Pido Quimbo-Perez) is a landscape architect. She was born in Manila on 15 Sep 1936. The daughter of Col Juan Quimbo and Remedios Pido, she is the wife of Enrique D. Perez, a lawyer and corporate executive. Perez graduated from the University of Santo Tomas with a bachelor of science in architecture in 1957 and from the University of California (UC) Berkeley with a master’s degree in landscape architecture in 1962. She worked in the landscape architectural firms of Geraldine Knight Scott in Berkeley, Robert Babcock in Oakland, and John Vogley in San Francisco, California, 1958-62. She served as landscape architect for the National Parks Development Committee, 1963-66. In 1966, she established her office Dolly Q. Perez and Associates. This was expanded in 1984 to Total Designs Atelier Inc. She taught at the Department of Landscape Architecture, University of the Philippines (UP), 1978-87, and served as chair of the department, 1983-85. She is a fellow of the Philippine Association of Landscape Architects, and was president of the association in 1985 and 1986.

Perez’s projects include parks and playgrounds, industrial and commercial sites, memorial parks and monuments, and residences. She has been commissioned for projects in Hong Kong, Singapore, and Guam. Among her major works are the landscaping of Silay Park in Negros Occidental; the Children’s Park in UP Diliman; the Taal Vista Lodge in Tagaytay; the Meralco Compound in Pasig; the Dambana ng Kagitingan in Mount Samat, Bataan; the Libingan ng mga Bayani in Fort Bonifacio, Makati; the Manila Polo Club in Makati; the Mirador Shrine in Baguio City; and the Gateway Business Park in Cavite. She wrote a weekly column on landscaping for the Manila Chronicle, 1966-68; the Manila Times, 1968-70; and the Daily Express, 1977-79.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

text:
Rodrigo D. Perez III (Rodrigo David Perez III), also known as Dom Bernardo Ma., OSB or Fr Bobby Perez, was an essayist, set and lighting designer, and teacher. He was born in Manila on 2 Jun 1933. He died in Manila on 19 Nov 2011. He was the son of lawyer and government official Rodrigo D. Perez Jr and journalist Enriqueta David. He graduated from San Beda High School in 1949. He obtained his bachelor’s degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas (UST). While in college, Perez wrote for several major Manila newspapers and magazines and published comments on architecture and the arts. From 1956 to 1963, he worked at the Board of Travel and Tourist Industry as a staff writer, then as director of research and publications, technical assistant to the commissioner of tourism, and deputy commissioner for research and development.

In 1963, he entered the Abbey of Our Lady of Montserrat in Manila as postulant. He pronounced his simple vows as a Benedictine in 1965 and his solemn profession in 1968. He was ordained priest in 1969, after completing his philosophical studies at San Beda College in 1966 and theological studies at the Loyola House of Studies School of Theology in Ateneo de Manila University. Only two years after ordination, Perez was appointed rector of San Beda College in 1971. He held the position until 1974, then again in 1977-83 when he was appointed prior delegate of the Abbey. He served his third and longest term as rector from 1986 to 2001. This term coincided with San Beda’s centennial celebrated in school year 2000-2001. At the end of the centennial, Perez retired as rector of San Beda College.

Perez began writing articles on the arts and architecture in 1951. His articles appeared in Sunday Times Magazine, Progress (Manila Times Yearbook ), Comment, Japan Architect, American Journal of Architects, and Mobilways. As a freelance writer, he wrote reviews and articles for the Philippine Herald, Manila Times, Sunday Times Magazine, Kislap, Philippine Graphic, Manila Chronicle, Free World, and Philippine Free Press.

In 1957, he served as stage manager and lighting designer of the Philippine Culture Commission to Southeast Asia headed by Francisca Reyes-Aquino. In the same year, he designed the sets of the first production of Felipe Padilla de Leon’s opera, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not). He was also the stage manager and lighting designer in the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company’s first international tour in 1958, and technical director in the same company’s first professional tour in 1959 and 1960.

Perez believed that there is such a thing as Philippine architecture and that it is unique. His article “Nipa Hut and Modern Architecture” was written in 1953. He wrote a series of articles for the Sunday Times Magazine on architects Pablo Ocampo, Angel Nakpil, Cesar Concio, and Carlos Arguelles, naming this series “Architects of a Generation.” With Rosario Encarnacion and Julian Dacanay, he co-authored the book Folk Architecture, published by GCF Books in 1989. He was one of three writers of Balai Vernacular, published by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1992. For the CCP’s Tuklas Sining series, he wrote the monographs Arkitektura: An Essay on Philippine Architecture, 1989; Arkitektura II: Philippine Ethnic Architecture, 1992; and Arkitektura IV: The American Colonial and Contemporary Traditions in Philippine Architecture, 1993. He directed and scripted the accompanying videos to these monographs, and directed as well Arkitektura III: The Spanish Influence on Philippine Architecture, 1992. He served as editor of the architecture volume of the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994.

He received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 2008.   Written by Rosalinda Galang, with notes from René B. Javellana

He served as editor of the architecture volume of the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994.
He received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 2008.
Written by Rosalinda Galang, with notes from René B. Javellana

Edgar Ramirez (Edgardo P. Ramirez) was an interior designer. He was born in Meycauayan, Bulacan on 21 Feb 1932. He died in Meycauayan, Bulacan on 29 Jun 2005. He graduated from the University of Santo Tomas in 1953 with a bachelor’s degree in architecture. He worked at L. R. Aguinaldo and Company Inc as interior designer and display director, 1952-57. Later he established his own firm, Edgar Ramirez Inc, which is engaged in interior design and furniture manufacturing and exporting. One of the founders of the Philippine Institute of Interior Designers (PIID), he is a member of the Chamber of Furniture Industry of the Philippines.

Ramirez was commissioned to design some of the rooms of Malacañan during the terms of Pres Ramon Magsaysay and Pres Carlos Garcia. His projects include interiors of offices, banks, department stores, and residences. His major works include the interiors of the Philippine Embassy and the Palace Hotel in Beijing, China; the Defense Department, the National Bank of Abu Dhabi, the Arab Monetary Fund, the palace of Sheik Tahnoun, the palace of Crown Prince Sheif Kalifa, and the Amini Court, all in the United Arab Emirates; and the Philippine Bank of California in San Francisco, California. Ramirez headed the team of interior designers who renovated the Juan Luna Hall of the National Museum in 1990.

For his numerous accomplishments, the PIID conferred on Ramirez its Hall of Fame Award in Interior Design.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

Jorge Ramos (Jorge Yatco Ramos) was an architect, urban planner, and interior designer. He was born in Manila on 22 Feb 1936. He died in Makati City on 21 Nov 2015. Son of Faustino Ramos and Remedios Yatco, he was married to Remedios Ferrer. He graduated with a degree of bachelor of science in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas in 1957. He became a delegate to the United Nations Seminar on Planning and Housing in 1958. He trained as an architect under the US Exchange Program with Kemp, Bunch & Jackson–Architects in Jacksonville, Florida, from 1960 to 1963. He worked at the firm Antonio C. Kayanan City Planners in San Juan, Puerto Rico, from Mar to Dec 1964. He had a partnership agreement with Parsons-Brinkerhoff of New York in 1984 for projects in Asia.

In 1975-85, Ramos was commissioned to plan and design the Philippine Heart Center for Asia, Children’s Hospital, Lung Center, Kidney Center, and the 1,000-bed Philippine General Hospital. For this he was commended for introducing improved efficiency services and for accommodating visual therapy, spiritual healing, and alternative medicine in architectural spaces. He was appointed as architectural design adviser to Madam Jehan Sadat of Egypt for the design of the Wafa Al Ahmal Hospital in Cairo, 1976. In 1979, he designed and built the Mosque in Quiapo, Manila, with the ambassadors of Egypt and Libya to the Philippines acting as technical advisers.

He designed Puerto Azul, Cavite; Fort Ilocandia, Ilocos Norte; the People’s Library and the Santo Niño Shrine in Tacloban, Leyte; and the convention centers in Baguio City and Zamboanga. He was assigned the remodeling of Malacañan Palace and the renovation of certain historical landmarks in the Ilocos region.

Ramos worked to improve the living conditions in the depressed areas by building low-cost housing, primary care clinics, and public markets. He worked together with Kajima Corporation of Japan on a new expanded master plan for Metro Manila, to be known as Lungsod Silangan (Eastern City).

He has served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of Santo Tomas since 1983. He is a member of the Philippine Institute of Architects and the American Institute of Architects.

The president of his own firm, JYR and Partners, Ramos is involved in land development, architecture and interior design with offices in New York and Manila and projects in Asia, Central and South America, concentrating in urban renewal and development; medical facilities, housing, vertical and horizontal infrastructure; universities and educational facilities; environmental preservation; and tourism projects.

During his term as member of the Board of Trustees of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1979-85, he was awarded by the city of Los Angeles for promoting the exchange of cultural presentations between their respective cultural centers. He was named Architect of the Year in Manila in 1980. His design for the Government Services and Insurance System Building, with the technical collaboration of the Architects Collaborative of Boston, Massachusetts, won him the Passive Solar Design Award at the National Solar Design Competition at the Energy World’s Fair in Knoxville, Tennessee, in 1982. The following year, he was given the Owens Corning Design Award in New York and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila. He was awarded a Gold Medal for Architectural Excellence by the Santo Tomas Alumni Association in 14 Mar 2001.

He maintains the Jorge Y. Ramos Scholarship Fund for Architecture.   Written by Willa R. Solomon and Nicholas F. Ramos

text:
Felix Roxas (Felix Arroyo Roxas Sr) was an architect. He was born ca. 1820. He died ca. 1890. He was the third of 16 children of Antonio Roxas and Lucina Arroyo. He was married to Concepcion Fernandez with whom he had two children, Lucina and Felix Jr. In 1840 Roxas left for Calcutta, India, and then for England where he lived for more than 10 years. He also stayed in France and Spain, where he studied at the Real Academia de Notables Artes de San Fernando, Madrid. He returned to the Philippines in 1854. In 1866, he was appointed interim head of the Public Works Office.

Roxas was responsible for the enlargement and reconstruction of the parish church of Bacoor, Cavite, and for the new Santo Domingo Church in Intramuros, built after the 1863 earthquake, completed in 1867, and repaired in 1887. He designed the Dominican church in the neo-Gothic style, which was popular in England ca. 1750, but was just gaining popularity in the Philippines in the 19th century. He modified the neo-Gothic by creating a semicircular apse with an ambulatory. In 1877, he designed the Jesuit church of San Ignacio in Intramuros using elements borrowed from the Italian Renaissance, especially in the use of the arcaded colonnade and the enhancing arches, cornices, and columns with dark color, which contrasted with bare plaster walls. He also designed residences including that of Rafael Enriquez in 1867, which became the Escuela de Bellas Artes, precursor of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts, 1905. This residence at Quiapo was systematically taken apart and reassembled at the Casas de Acuzar in Bagac, Bataan. He also built the residences of Carmen Roxas and the Paterno, Yriarte, and Rincon families. He died before the completion of the San Ignacio Church, his last major work.  Written by  René B. Javellana

Roque Ruaño was a builder. He was born in Palencia, Spain on 16 Aug 1877. He died on 1 Aug 1935. Admitted into the Dominican order in 1897, he arrived in Manila in 1903 and taught at the Colegio de San Vicente, 1903-4; and at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. Deeply interested in geology and architecture, he enrolled at the then newly established College of Engineering of the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1908 and received his licentiate in 1912. He was rector of Letran, 1927-30. He attended several international conferences on prehistory and archaeology, 1926-33. After passing the government examination, he started the plans and designs for the Dominican house in Baguio, 1913-15. He also designed the Dominican College in Lingayen, the crucero (transept) in the Church of Our Lady of Manaoag in Manaoag, Pangasinan; Santa Catalina College in Santa Rita, Pampanga; and the Hospital of the Sacred Heart and the Santa Teresita Church in Yokohama, Japan.

Ruaño was commissioned by the UST to design the new campus in Sampaloc, outside the Intramuros walls. By Jan 1920, he had completed his plans for the main structure. Construction started in 1922 and ended in 1927. His designs were guided by his belief that earthquakes would set small independent towers in motion, but the structures would be small enough not to crack. Thus he built the UST Main Building as 24 independent structures connected by soft material, and placed so closely together that only careful examination would reveal the spaces between them.  Written by Malou Maniquis

text:
Carlos Santos-Viola (Carlos Antonio Santos-Viola) was an architect. He was born in San Miguel, Bulacan on 9 Apr 1912. He died in Quezon City on 31 Jul 1994. One of the six children of Melecio de Guzman Santos and Miguela Magpitang Antonio, his siblings included Miguela, Cezar, Adriana, Cleotilde, and Jorge. He married Caridad Nakpil, architect Juan Nakpil’s youngest sister. He and Caridad had five children: Rosario, Milagros, Paz, Lourdes, and Carlos Jr. He grew up in a bahay na bato (stone house) in San Miguel, whose basic form he later reinterpreted in the private residences that he designed. From San Miguel Elementary School, he moved to Ateneo de Manila to finish his high school in 1930. In Ateneo, he joined the school band and was active in playing basketball. He also played the saxophone and enjoyed lawn tennis throughout his life. He was one of the first graduates of the College of Architecture of the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1935. His professors were outstanding architects and engineers such as Tomas Arguelles, Tomas Mapua, Fernando Ocampo, Andres Luna de San Pedro, and Juan Nakpil. He placed 10th in the board examinations for architects in 1938. He worked as an assistant architect for Wurdemann & Beckett, building the Jai Alai court and gallery on Taft Ave, Manila, and in the office of Juan Nakpil as a draftsman. He became an associate architect in Juan Nakpil’s office in 1946 until 1950, when he set up his own office. Alfredo Luz was his partner for some time. From 1949 to 1981, he taught at the UST College of Architecture.

Santos-Viola is known as the chief architect of Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) structures, but he has also designed Catholic churches, schools, private homes, and industrial buildings. The INC churches, characterized by their many vertical spires, are imaginative yet functional buildings, full of surface decoration yet generally unified in conception. The Temple Central, 1982, consists of three halls that can combine into one huge space. Its exterior exudes grandeur. In contrast to the INC churches, Santos-Viola’s Catholic churches are markedly horizontal. Among these are the Our Lady of Lourdes in Quezon City; the Franciscan churches of Singalong, Mandaluyong-Pasig, Tagaytay, and Lipa City; and the most visually satisfying, Nuestra Señora de Guia in Ermita, Manila. Some of his more important residential designs were for Hilario Zialcita, Ford Wilkins, Pablo Sarangaya, Manuel Locsin, Bienvenido Tantoco, and Jorge Vargas. Santos-Viola finished his studies when the International Style was beginning to penetrate the Philippines. Although he embraced its major tenets, he continued to employ surface ornamentation. In this he adheres to a common Filipino pattern.

In 1981, Santos-Viola received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila. He was a member of the Philippines Institute of Architects (PIA) since 1938 and its chancellor in 1989-90. In 1990, he received the Gold Medal of Merit from the PIA. In 2013, an exhibit of his works, titled Sacred Spires: Iglesia ni Cristo Architecture of Carlos Santos-Viola, was held as part of the Philippine Arts Festival.  Written by Fernando N. Zialcita

Ildefonso P. Santos (Ildefonso Paez Santos Jr), also known as IP Santos or Sir IP, was a landscape architect. He is a National Artist for architecture. He was born in Malabon, Rizal on 5 Sep 1929. He died on 29 Jan 2014. His parents were Ildefonso Santos and Asuncion Paez. His father, Ildefonso Sr, was an educator and a Tagalog poet, who wrote under the pen name Ilaw Silangan (Eastern Light). He was married to Amparo Eugenio, with whom he had four daughters. He got two bachelor’s degrees in architecture, one from the University of Santo Tomas, 1954, and another from the University of Southern California in Los Angeles (USCLA), 1956, and a master’s degree also from USCLA, 1960. He worked with Cornell, Bridgers, and Trollers, landscape architects, in Los Angeles, 1955-63. Upon returning to Manila in 1963, he established his own firm, undertaking projects in the Philippines, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Guam, Thailand, Singapore, Taipei, and Bahrain. Since 1964 he lectured at the University of the Philippines (UP). He was designated as landscape architectural consultant for the UP campus in 1965. In 1971, he introduced in UP the first Philippine undergraduate program in tropical landscape architecture. He was appointed as head of the university’s graduate program in 1986.

He was president of the Philippine Association of Landscape Architects, 1977-85, and was elected fellow in 1985. He was a member of the Board of Examiners for Landscape Architecture of the Professional Regulation Commission, 1982-1986.

Santos transformed the image of the landscape architect as a glorified gardener to an architectural profession that requires the knowledge of architecture, engineering, and aesthetics and the ability to plan irrigation, drainage, lighting, and a comprehensive topographical analysis in landscaping. Santos’s landscapes take advantage of the rich bounty of tropical foliage and plants. His projects take into account the need for shade, close-seating, conversation, and social interaction, and is sensitive to the psychological, behavioral, and social needs of the Filipinos. This gives his works a distinctive Filipino feel.

His projects include landscaping for hotels, commercial and shopping centers, banks, resorts, sports complexes, memorial parks, parks and playgrounds, office buildings, condominiums, subdivisions, and housing projects. His first major project was with the Makati Commercial Center where he introduced landscape walks, fountains, and sculptures as part of a strip mall. Among his larger projects were the Batulao Village Club in Batangas, the Caliraya Lake Resort in Laguna, the Eternal Gardens Memorial Park in Caloocan City, the Loyola Memorial Park in Manila and Parañaque, the Imus town plaza in Cavite, and the Raintree Sports Club in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. At Rizal Park in Manila, Santos did the Artists’ Village, the Garden for the Blind, the Teodoro F. Valencia Circle, the rehabilitation of the Japanese Garden, and the setting up of the Execution of Dr Jose Rizal site. He also did the landscaping for the Cultural Center of the Philippines, San Miguel Corporation Building, the defunct Nayong Filipino, Paco Park, Asian Institute of Management, all in Metro Manila; the Tagaytay Highlands Golf and Country Club, Tagaytay, Cavite; Mount Malarayat Golf and Country Club Lipa, Batangas, and Orchard Golf and Country Club, Imus, Cavite.

Santos wrote papers on landscape architecture in the Philippines and in the context of a developing country. He also accumulated an impressive library on landscape architecture with about 1,200 books, published from 1960 to 2010. His collection was formally turned over to the UP College of Architecture Library in 2013.

In 1972, the city of Manila conferred on Santos the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award. In 1979, Malacañan gave him a plaque of appreciation for his work in Nayong Filipino. In 1986, he was named Outstanding Landscape Architect by the United Garden Clubs of the Philippines and the Garden Clubs of the Philippines in 1988. In 2006, he was conferred the title National Artist for architecture.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

text:
Antonio Sedeño was a Jesuit priest, architect, and builder. He was born in San Clemente, diocese of Cuenca in 1535. He died in Cebu on 1 Sep 1595. Antonio Sedeño was 46 years old when he arrived in Manila on 17 Sep 1581. Before he joined the Jesuits on 25 Apr 1559, he worked for the duke of Feria, where he learned the principles and techniques of construction. Prior to the Philippines, Sedeño had been rector of the German College in Rome and a veteran of the Florida mission. When the third general San Francisco de Borja closed Florida, Sedeño was sent to Mexico, where he founded a college. Intending to volunteer for Japan, he could not get passage as no ship was sailing. While waiting for the next ship, he received the order from Borja’s successor, Everard Mercurian, to head a mission to the Philippines. He left for the Philippines with Fr Alonso Sanchez, Bro Nicolas Gallardo, and Gaspar Suarez de Toledo. Suarez died on board the ship. Sedeño’s original directive was not to establish a permanent mission but to reconnoiter and report to Rome.

During the trip across the Pacific, he befriended Domingo de Salazar, OP, who was sent to Manila to be its first bishop. This friendship would benefit the development of colonial architecture. In Aug 1583, after a fire consumed Manila, then a humble collection of thatch, bamboo, and timber houses, Salazar asked Sedeño to rebuild the bishop’s residence using more permanent material. On an earlier exploratory trip up the Pasig River, the bishop came upon the adobe outcrops of Guadalupe. Quarrying the stones in Guadalupe, slaking lime from oyster shells, and hewing tropical hardwood, a team of workers, drawn from the Chinese artisans and workers in Manila, was directed by Sedeño. After completing the bishop’s residence, Gov-Gen Santiago de Vera asked Sedeño to build a fortification for Manila. He built Nuestra Señora de Guia in 1587, a tower designed, said its critics, in the medieval style. In 1595, when Gov-Gen Luis Perez de Dasmariñas began replacing the palisade around Manila with stonewalls, the tower was integrated into the city’s defenses.

In 1590, Sedeño began his most ambitious project, a church for the Jesuits in Intramuros. Named after Santa Ana, the mother of the Virgin Mary, the church was almost complete in 1595. That same year, Sedeño was appointed vice-provincial of the Jesuits in the Philippines and a royal decree designated islands and provinces to the different orders.

Sedeño did not complete the year. Traveling by boat to Cebu, where he had asked Pedro Chirino to establish a central house for the Visayas, he was caught in a storm and arrived in Cebu quite ill. He died in the house Chirino had prepared, a gift of Lt Henao, a benefactor of the Jesuits.  Written by René B. Javellana

After completing the bishop’s residence, Gov-Gen Santiago de Vera asked Sedeño to build a fortification for Manila. He built Nuestra Señora de Guia in 1587, a tower designed, said its critics, in the medieval style. In 1595, when Gov-Gen Luis Perez de Dasmariñas began replacing the palisade around Manila with stonewalls, the tower was integrated into the city’s defenses.

In 1590, Sedeño began his most ambitious project, a church for the Jesuits in Intramuros. Named after Santa Ana, the mother of the Virgin Mary, the church was almost complete in 1595. That same year, Sedeño was appointed vice-provincial of the Jesuits in the Philippines and a royal decree designated islands and provinces to the different orders.

Sedeño did not complete the year. Traveling by boat to Cebu, where he had asked Pedro Chirino to establish a central house for the Visayas, he was caught in a storm and arrived in Cebu quite ill. He died in the house Chirino had prepared, a gift of Lt Henao, a benefactor of the Jesuits.
Written by René B. Javellana

text:
Antonio S. Sindiong (Antonio Sevilla Sindiong) was an architect. He was born on 13 Jun 1922. He died in Makati City on 19 Feb 1996. His parents were Casiano Sindiong and Maximina Sevilla. In 1946, he graduated with a bachelor’s degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas (UST). He was a member of the faculty of the UST School of Architecture, 1952-59. He was senior managing partner of Sindiong, Ocampo and Garcia, Architects and Engineers, 1973-84. In 1985, he established the firm Antonio S. Sindiong and Associates. Sindiong was president of the Philippine Institute of Architects (PIA), 1960-62, and was named fellow in 1984. He served as chairperson of the Board of Examiners for Architects of the Professional Regulation Commission, 1966-71. He is an honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects.

With the abrogation of the 30-meter limit on the height of buildings, Sindiong became a pioneer in designing high-rise buildings in the country. His major works include the 43-story Pacific Plaza Condominium, the 28-story Ritz Towers, the 22-story Metrobank Plaza, and the 20-story La Metropole Condominium, all in Makati. The 20-story Cebu Plaza Hotel, designed by him, is the tallest in Cebu City. The six-story SM Megamall on Epifanio de los Santos Ave in Mandaluyong City, is more than half a kilometer in length and has a total floor area of 330,000 sq m. Sindiong’s previous shopping mall projects include the Harrison Plaza Shopping Center, Manila; the Ali Mall II and the New Farmers Plaza Shopping Center, both in Cubao, Quezon City. Projects overseas include the East Pakistan Rice Research Institute in Bangladesh; the Kebayoran Housing Project in Indonesia; and the Arabian Villas in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

Sindiong’s more notable works are marked by an urbane elegance resulting from design that is both imaginative and disciplined. The contrast of colors and textures—dark-tinted glass against white concrete—and the angular movement of planes give the Ritz Towers an air of playful sophistication. The tightly drawn fabric of rose-colored glass on the Pacific Plaza Building sets it apart from Makati’s concrete-clad structures.

In 1989, the PIA awarded Sindiong the Gold Medal of Merit. In the same year he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

text:
Antonio M. Toledo (Antonio Mañalac Toledo) was an architect. He was born in Santa Cruz, Laguna on 11 Jun 1889. He died on 13 Jul 1972. The son of Jose Toledo and Cayetana Mañalac, he grew up in Cavite. He was married to Pura Emile, and after her death, to Josefina Soler. While studying at Cavite High School, Toledo passed the government examination for pensionados. He was sent to the United States where he completed his secondary schooling. He studied at the Brooklyn Institute of Technology, 1905-6, then took a course in architecture at the Ohio State University, 1906-10, but spent a year, 1908-9, at Cornell University. In Columbus, Ohio, he worked for the firm Howell and Thomas.

Returning to the Philippines in 1911, he was employed at the Bureau of Public Works under William Parsons. He rose through the ranks and in 1928 became consulting architect, the position he held until his retirement from government service in 1954.

In 1947, Toledo was a member of the architects and engineers mission that toured the United States and South America to prepare for the planning of the Capitol buildings and the University of the Philippines (UP) campus in Diliman, Quezon City. The mission also included Juan Arellano, Juan Nakpil, Cesar Concio, and city planner Antonio Kayanan.

Toledo was one of the first professors at the Mapua Institute of Technology when it opened in 1925; after his retirement from government service he continued teaching there until 1967. He was named fellow of the Philippine Institute of Architect (PIA) in 1952.

With Parsons, Toledo designed the women’s dormitory of the Philippine Normal School. After Parsons left the bureau in 1914, Toledo took charge of designing the buildings for the UP Padre Faura campus, among them the College of Medicine Annex and the University Library. His other major works include the Leyte Capitol, built in the 1920s; the buildings of the Department of Agriculture and Commerce (later Tourism) and the Department of Finance, built in 1940; and the City Hall of Manila, built in 1941. Other provincial government buildings in many parts of the country were also designed by him.

Toledo faithfully adhered to the neoclassic style, of which he was a master. The twin buildings on what is popularly called the Agrifina Circle (after the Agriculture and Finance Buildings) count among the noblest edifices of Manila, with their impressive proportions and refined details. The buildings have been turned over to the National Museum of the Philippines. The former Finance Building is now the Museum of Anthropology, and the Agriculture Building is being refurbished and upgraded to become the Museum of Natural History.

He received the PIA’s Gold Medal of Merit in 1961.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Abelardo Tolentino Jr (Abelardo Magno Tolentino Jr) is an architect. H was born in Manila on 31 Jan 1966. Tolentino is the eldest of the five children of Abelardo Pinpin Tolentino and Milagros Esquivel Magno. He is married to Angela Villanueva Viloria, an interior designer by profession. He went to Pasig Catholic School for his primary and secondary educations and graduated with a degree of bachelor of science in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas in 1987. He took short courses in project management from the University of Hong Kong in 1995, and business development for architects, high-rise building design, and financial management for architects from Harvard University in 1998.


He worked for nine years in Hong Kong with prestigious architectural firms as senior architect at John Lei Architects Ltd and as associate architect with HOK Asia Pacific. When he came back to the country in 1998, he served as managing director of the Philippine subsidiary of Robert Matthew Johnson Marshall (RMJM), a United Kingdom-based architectural firm. When RMJM pulled out its operations in the Philippines in 2003, Tolentino acquired the firm and renamed it as Aidea, which according to him means “from ideas to reality.” Aidea is an all-Filipino design firm that believes that Filipino architects need not leave the country to produce world-class designs. His faith in the Filipino architect’s talent being at par with the best creative minds in Asia, the United Kingdom, and the United States is showcased in the design of the buildings in the contemporary International Style his firm was commissioned to do.


Aidea is a multidesign firm doing architecture, master planning, interior design, landscape, and environmental graphic design. Aidea developed into one of the leading architectural practices in the country and was consistently ranked among the Top 100 Biggest Practices worldwide by Building Design World Architecture, a London architectural communications company. With its global recognition in architectural design, Aidea became one of the few Filipino firms working on international projects. To date, his projects include Procter & Gamble headquarters in West Europe (Geneva, Madrid, Paris, Rome, Kiev, and Moscow) and in the Philippines (Canlubang, Laguna); City of Millenia, Guangzhou, 2001; One Museum Park West, Chicago, Illinois, 2005; and modern buildings in the commercial business districts of Makati, Fort Bonifacio, and other parts of Manila (including Serendra, 1998; The Columns, 2001; UP-Ayala Technohub, 2006; Greenbelt, Convergys, Nuvali, Globe Telecoms Corporate Headquarters, High Street South in Fort Bonifacio, One Global Place, Ascott Residences, 2008; Park Terraces, Senta, People Support, Arya Residences, 2009; Calyx Residences, 2010; One World Place, 2011; Garden Towers, 2012; Polakay Resort and Solaris Towers).


His design projects won the following awards: Avida Towers Centera, Development of the Year, Myproperty.ph Real Estate Awards, 2012; Arya Residences, Best Residential Development, South East Asia Property Awards, 2012; One World Place, Best Office Development, International Property Awards, 2013; Arya Residences, Best Luxury Condominium and Best Residential Architectural Design, Philippine Property Awards, 2013; and Avida Towers 9th Ave, BGC Best Mid-Range Condominium, Philippine Property Awards, 2013. Tolentino’s architectural firm was also awarded BCI (Business Continuity Institute) Asia Top 10 Architectural Firms 2005, 2008, 2011, and 2013. Further to this, Aidea won grand prizes in international virtual competitions for their museum designs for Qatar and London in the prestigious Build Qatar Live and Build London Live design competitions among architectural companies.


In recognition of his dedication to the architecture profession, Tolentino received the Ernst and Young Innovation Entrepreneur of the Year Award, 2007, for “applying innovative approaches, business solutions, and technologies that resulted in improved business processes and company growth”; the Thomasian Outstanding Alumni Award, 2008, from the University of Santo Tomas; the Quadricentennial Award for Exemplary Service to the University of Santo Tomas, 2012; and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts Ani ng Dangal for Architecture and Allied Arts, 2013.  Written by Norma I. Alarcon

text:
Ma. Cristina Turalba (Maria Cristina Valero-Turalba) is an architect and environmental planner. She was born in Bangued, Abra on 31 Oct 1943. She is married to architect and real estate developer Antonio A. Turalba Sr with whom she has four children. She received her bachelor’s degree in architecture in 1965, masters in environmental planning in 1974, and PhD units for urban and regional planning, all from the University of the Philippines (UP). She also holds post-masteral degrees in housing from the United Nations Center for Human Settlements; Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium; and Parahyangan Catholic University, Bandung, Indonesia, in 1992.

Her career as an architect was mainly influenced by her engineer father; architect uncle, National Artist and Likha awardee Leandro V. Locsin; former dean of the UP College of Architecture Aurelio T. Juguilon; and landscape architect and National Artist Ildefonso P. Santos. She began her interest in photography, research, and documentation in the late 1970s when she traveled from the farthest north in Batanes to down south in Bongao, Tawi-Tawi.

Turalba has been a professor at the UP College of Architecture since 1977. She is the principal architect of Turalba and Associates and the vice-chair of Active Group Inc, which holds a number of companies on construction, real estate, and properties. She is the founding director and president of Mount Malarayat Golf and Country Club, a multi-awarded project known for its architecture and planning.

Turalba was executive director of the Sentro ng Arkitekturang Filipino, 2000-2006, and of the College of Fellows, 2000-2012, both under the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP); head, National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) Committee on Architecture and Allied Arts, 2004-7; and member of the Board Trustees at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 2010-14. She implemented the NCCA-UAP Documentation of Philippine Heritage Structures and Cultural Sites, a project initiated by architect Augusto Villalon for the UAP Sentro ng Arkitekturang Filipino. This project led to the publication of two digital books comprising 12 volumes in 2004. Other publications Turalba initiated with other writers and architects are Mavid A Vatan, 2004, a compendium of documents on Batanes for the 2004-7 nomination bid for inscription as a UNESCO World Heritage Site; Philippine Heritage Architecture before 1521 to the 1970s, 2005, which inspired architect Gerard Lico, her former student, to write and publish Arkitekturang Filipino: A History of Architecture and Urbanism in the Philippines in 2008; and Audio Visual Textbook of Philippine Architecture, published by the NCCA in 2008.  Written by Clarissa L. Avendaño
