text:
The United Architects of the Philippines (UAP) was established in 1974 and since then has been the only professional organization of architects in the country. Like all other architectural organizations, it was established by architects in order to foster unity and cooperation among themselves, thresh out common problems in the profession, uplift the standards of architectural education, and work for the development and upgrading of the profession and the welfare of its practitioners.

During the Spanish era, there were no schools of architecture in the Philippines. Filipinos had to learn the skill of erecting architectural structures from a master builder who preceded him in the craft. In the last decade of the 19th century, the Spanish government opened the first formal school for master builders, the Escuela Practica de Artes y Oficios de Manila.

Under a civil government established by the Americans in 1901, highways, bridges, schools, hospitals, and government buildings transformed the Philippine landscape. In 1902, many graduates of the Escuela bonded with the civil engineers and surveyors in the country to found the first professional organization of architects and allied professions, the Academia de Arquitectura y Agrimensura de Filipinas. A year after, the academy changed its name to Academia de Ingenieria, Arquitectura, y Agrimensura de Filipinas (AIAAF).

In 1911, the engineers withdrew to form their own professional organization, but not before the AIAAF had struggled for the passage of an engineers’s and architects’s law. Act No. 2985, the first enabling law for the practice of the separate professions of engineering and architecture, was enacted later, in 1921. The first batch of Filipino architects was registered on the basis of this act.

In view of the growing number of architects, the Philippine Architects Society was organized on the initiative of Juan F. Nakpil. The first officers of the society were Juan F. Nakpil, president; Tomas Mapua, vice president; Harold H. Keys, secretary-treasurer; and Sidney D. Rowlands and Fernando H. Ocampo, directors. Among its early accomplishments were the draft of its constitution and by-laws, the rules of charges and professional fees, and the code of ethics of the society. One of the aims of the society was to seek the passage of a law by the National Assembly that would protect the architectural profession.

In 1938, the society was renamed Philippine Institute of Architects and Planners and, subsequently, Philippine Institute of Architects (PIA). In 1946, the PIA held its first annual convention. In 1950, about 15 members left the institute and formed the League of Philippine Architects (LPA). It was led by some eminent architects at the time: Pablo S. Antonio, Antonio V. Bañas, Pablo D. Panlilio, Jose L. Reynoso, and Elias L. Ruiz. They elected the much younger Jose V. Herrera as the league’s first president. The schism gave rise to two architects’s organizations vying for the membership of the 350 registered architects at the time. (By 1962 LPA membership had grown to 600 when there were about 2,200 registered architects.) In 1955, the Boards of the Institute and the League met to discuss the merger of the organizations, but with no result. In 1957, the PIA was admitted as an affiliate organization of the Union Internationale des Architectes (UIA). The PIA College of Fellows was created in 1972.

Architects in the government service formed their own association in 1958 and named it Association of Philippine Government Architects (APGA). In 1965, the PIA, LPA, and APGA passed resolutions approving the Architect’s National Code and the Architects’ Services and Schedule of Fees, which had been prepared by the PIA. Negotiations for the merger of the three organizations continued, but still fruitless. An attempt to have an umbrella organization to unify the three organizations was made by LPA and APGA by organizing the Council of Filipino Architects (CFA), but it was not recognized by PIA. However, it authored what resulted in Presidential Proclamation 934 Series of 1971, designating the second week of December as Nationwide Architecture Week.

Presidential Decree 223, was issued by Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1973. Under this decree, the Professional Regulation Commission (PRC) was authorized to regulate all professions and to accredit only one organization for each profession. Pursuant to this, the three architectural organizations voluntarily integrated into the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP). In 1974, the Boards of PIA, LPA, and APGA approved the constitution and by-laws of the UAP. PRC certified the accreditation of UAP as the only accredited professional organization for architects in the Philippines, with PRC Certificate of Accreditation No. 001 on 12 May 1975.

The UAP aims to promote the highest standards of ethical conduct and excellence in the practice and service of the profession as well as upliftment of the standards of architectural education. The UAP is also committed to unify all registered architects of the Philippines through cooperation and coordination with allied professions, trade and industry, both local and international; participation in national development programs; and cooperation with the Board of Architecture and other government agencies. It is willing to render any lawful and appropriate assistance to any of its members.

During the meeting of the Union Internationale des Architectes (UIA) in Hawaii in Jun 1982, the UIA Bureau concluded that according to laws of the Philippines, the UAP is the only organization with the right to represent the Filipino architects in the Philippines and internationally, particularly in the UIA. In the UIA Council at Santiago, Chile, in Apr 1983, a certification to this effect was issued to UAP.

The UAP is one of the founding member-institutes of the Architects Regional Council Asia. Established in 1979, it is composed of the architects’s organizations of Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Thailand, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, India, and the Philippines. It was later joined by Country Institutes of Macau, China, Korea, Lao, Japan, Nepal, Mongolia, and Vietnam. In 1986, the Asian Congress Student Jamboree was launched, giving the would-be architects representing member-countries a chance to experience the benefits of an international conference. The UAP is also a lifetime member of the Eastern Regional Organization for Planning and Human Settlements (EAROPH).

In 1997, from the savings of its previous national presidents and contributions of members, the UAP was able to purchase a lot and initiate the construction of its own seven-story headquarters and offices in Quezon City, completed as of May 2014.

The UAP is a four-time recipient of the PRC citation as “Most Outstanding Accredited Professional Organization of the Year” (2002, 2007, 2008, and 2011). It also received the EAROPH Golden Jubilee Award in recognition of its substantial contribution to the advancement of planning, development, and management of human settlements in the Philippines. It is the first accredited professional organization to receive the Father Neri Satur Award for Environmental Heroism, 2009. It was commended by the National Economic and Development Authority–Philippine National Service Coordinating Agency as one of the “Outstanding Volunteers” in Region IV and by the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority as a valuable partner in its Urban Renewal Program. The Metrobank Foundation also honored the UAP as a Partner in Empowerment, Advocacy, and Commitment to Excellence or PEACE.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from Maria Elena C. Cayanan

Pursuant to this, the three architectural organizations voluntarily integrated into the United Architects of the Philippines (UAP). In 1974, the Boards of PIA, LPA, and APGA approved the constitution and by-laws of the UAP. PRC certified the accreditation of UAP as the only accredited professional organization for architects in the Philippines, with PRC Certificate of Accreditation No. 001 on 12 May 1975.

The UAP aims to promote the highest standards of ethical conduct and excellence in the practice and service of the profession as well as upliftment of the standards of architectural education. The UAP is also committed to unify all registered architects of the Philippines through cooperation and coordination with allied professions, trade and industry, both local and international; participation in national development programs; and cooperation with the Board of Architecture and other government agencies. It is willing to render any lawful and appropriate assistance to any of its members.

During the meeting of the Union Internationale des Architectes (UIA) in Hawaii in Jun 1982, the UIA Bureau concluded that according to laws of the Philippines, the UAP is the only organization with the right to represent the Filipino architects in the Philippines and internationally, particularly in the UIA. In the UIA Council at Santiago, Chile, in Apr 1983, a certification to this effect was issued to UAP.

The UAP is one of the founding member-institutes of the Architects Regional Council Asia. Established in 1979, it is composed of the architects’s organizations of Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Thailand, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, India, and the Philippines. It was later joined by Country Institutes of Macau, China, Korea, Lao, Japan, Nepal, Mongolia, and Vietnam. In 1986, the Asian Congress Student Jamboree was launched, giving the would-be architects representing member-countries a chance to experience the benefits of an international conference. The UAP is also a lifetime member of the Eastern Regional Organization for Planning and Human Settlements (EAROPH).

In 1997, from the savings of its previous national presidents and contributions of members, the UAP was able to purchase a lot and initiate the construction of its own seven-story headquarters and offices in Quezon City, completed as of May 2014.

The UAP is a four-time recipient of the PRC citation as “Most Outstanding Accredited Professional Organization of the Year” (2002, 2007, 2008, and 2011). It also received the EAROPH Golden Jubilee Award in recognition of its substantial contribution to the advancement of planning, development, and management of human settlements in the Philippines. It is the first accredited professional organization to receive the Father Neri Satur Award for Environmental Heroism, 2009. It was commended by the National Economic and Development Authority–Philippine National Service Coordinating Agency as one of the “Outstanding Volunteers” in Region IV and by the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority as a valuable partner in its Urban Renewal Program. The Metrobank Foundation also honored the UAP as a Partner in Empowerment, Advocacy, and Commitment to Excellence or PEACE.
Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from Maria Elena C. Cayanan

Augusto F. Villalon (Augusto Fabella Villalon), also known as Toti Villalon, was an architect and essayist. He was born in Manila on 31 May 1945. He died in Makati City on 5 May 2018. Villalon’s father, Augusto P. Villalon, belongs to a Cebuano family whose ancestral home is on a mountaintop in Cebu’s Guadalupe district, overlooking uptown Cebu and the Cebu Capitol. His mother, Evelyn Fabella, is the daughter of Dr Jose Fabella who was the first secretary of health and public welfare during the Commonwealth era and member of the first board of Gota de Leche. Villalon was born in Manila but spent his early years in Cebu. He finished high school at De La Salle College in Manila in 1962 and briefly attended Ateneo de Manila University in 1963. He went to the United States where he graduated with a bachelor’s degree in sociology and art history from the University of Notre Dame in 1966. Then, he went to Yale University where he obtained a master’s degree in architecture in 1970. Fashion designer Patis F. Pamintuan-Tesoro is his first cousin.

Returning to the Philippines after his studies, he was among the organizers of the Design Center Philippines before opening his own A. Villalon Associates, a Manila-based firm specializing in architectural projects in the Philippines and abroad, heritage conservation, and cultural tourism planning. He built his own residence and office to embody principles drawn from heritage architecture adapted to the tropics. His advocacy of architecture in harmony with the environment has been his signature. Embodying this spirit is his project Monterrazas de Cebu, a hilltop green subdivision, a first in Cebu. He has completed a number of residences, beach resorts, and commercial buildings. He has worked on museums, restored notable heritage structures in the Philippines, and completed a considerable amount of heritage and cultural tourism projects in the Philippines and overseas, having worked in France, Indonesia, Malaysia, India, Nepal, Honduras, and Ecuador.

Villalon chaired the Heritage Conservation Society in Manila. He was UNESCO commissioner for the Philippines, chairman of the International Council on Monuments and Sites (ICOMOS) Philippine National Committee, and member of the international Executive Committee of ICOMOS, and in 2014 was the only Filipino heritage professional to be elevated to the select honorary membership category of ICOMOS. He was director of the Center for Filipino Architecture of the United Architects of the Philippines. He chaired the Subcommission on Cultural Heritage of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and is a member of the National Museum’s Board of Trustees.

As UNESCO commissioner, he pushed for the inclusion of five Philippine sites in the World Heritage List, among them the Baroque Churches of the Philippines and the Rice Terraces of the Philippine Cordilleras. He was restoration architect for the Gota de Leche, founded by philanthropist Teodoro A. Yangco, who commissioned Juan and Arcadio Arellano to design the building in 1912. Restoration was completed in 2003.

Since 1991, he was on the editorial board of Design and Architecture magazine and wrote a weekly column on architecture and heritage for the Manila Chronicle and in 1993 for the Philippine Daily Inquirer. These articles were the basis for his book Lugar: Essays on Philippine Heritage and Architecture, 2001, which won the National Book Award and the Alfonso T. Ongpin Prize for Best Book on Art in 2002.

Villalon received UNESCO Asia-Pacific Heritage Conservation Award, for the restoration of Gota de Leche, 2003, and of the Far Eastern University Campus, 2005. That same year he received the University of Notre Dame Distinguished and Exemplary Asian Pacific Alumni Award. Far Eastern University awarded him a doctorate in humanities, honoris causa, 2009. He received the Outstanding La Sallian Award, 2009. He was honored with the Diwa ng Lahi award from the city of Manila, 2011. In 2012, the Ministry of Culture of France made him Chevalier de l’Ordre des Arts et des Lettres (Knight of the Order of Arts and Letters), for achievements in architecture and heritage conservation in the Philippines and internationally. He received the Dangal ng Hiraya Lifetime Achievement Award for Heritage Conservation from the NCCA in 2015.  Written by René B. Javellana

Rogelio Villarosa (Rogelio Garcia Villarosa) is an architect. He was born in Bulacan on 23 Nov 1933. He is the son of Eladio Villarosa and Eugenia Garcia. He graduated with a bachelor’s degree in architecture from the Mapua Institute of Technology in 1954 and topped the 1954 examinations for architects. He worked with the Philippine Institute of Architects Collaborative, 1957-59, as job captain for the preparation of working drawings for national government buildings on Constitution Hill, Quezon City. He served as project manager, 1959-61, for Hexagon Associated Architects, which designed the National Library Building on T. M. Kalaw St, Manila. He was senior associate in the firm Gabriel P. Formoso and Associates, 1962-72. In 1972, he established his own firm and in 1985 formed the partnership R. Villarosa-Architects.

His major projects include the 20-story, 450-room EDSA Shangri-La Hotel and EDSA Plaza on Epifanio de los Santos Ave, Mandaluyong City; the Tektite Towers, composed of two 33-story buildings, on Tektite Road, Pasig City; the Alexandra, with its 11 buildings and 360 residential units, in Pasig; the King’s Court II on Pasong Tamo, Makati; the Silahis International Hotel on Roxas Blvd, Manila; the National Bookstore Superbranch at the Araneta Center, Cubao, Quezon City; the Puerto Azul Clubhouse in Puerto Azul, Ternate, Cavite; the Makati Sports Club, Makati; and the Philippine Columbian Clubhouse, Paco, Manila. In 20 years of practice he has designed over 120 residences.

In the Silahis International Hotel, Villarosa introduced curved-glass bay windows and the exterior bubble elevator. While employing traditional forms, such as the hip roof in the Philippine Columbian Clubhouse, Villarosa has also experimented with postmodern design, such as in King’s Court II Building which is a box with mirror-glass walls encased in marble arches of revivalist style, described by Lico (2008) as pioneer in postmodern design.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

 

Source

Lico, Gerard. 2008. Arkitekturang Filipino: A History of Architecture and Urbanism in the Philippines. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

text:
Jose Ma. Zaragoza (Jose Maria Velez Zaragoza) was an architect. He is a National Artist for architecture. He was born in Manila on 6 Dec 1912. He died on 26 Nov 1994. He was the son of Elias Zaragoza, an electrical and mechanical engineer, and Rosario Velez. His grandfather Jose Zaragoza was the owner and editor of La Ilustracion Filipina. Two granduncles were distinguished artists, the painter Miguel Zaragoza and the architect Felix Roxas. His wife, Pilar Rosello, is an interior designer; their son Ramon is an architect. Zaragoza finished high school at San Beda, and then studied architecture at the University of Santo Tomas where he obtained his bachelor’s degree in 1936, with highest honors. He holds a diploma in liturgical art and architecture from the International Institute of Liturgical Art in Rome, and a diploma in comprehensive planning from the Hilversum Technical Research Center in the Netherlands. Zaragoza was an honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects. He was also a fellow of the Philippine Institute of Architects (PIA).

Since 1938, Zaragoza has designed 36 office buildings; 5 public buildings; 15 airport terminal offices; 4 hotels; 2 hospitals; 45 churches, chapels, and religious centers; 5 low-cost and middle-income housing projects; 15 middle-income condominiums; and over 270 residences.

His major projects include the Meralco Building in Pasig; Our Lady of the Holy Rosary in Tala, Novaliches; Santo Domingo Church and Convent in Quezon City; Villa San Miguel, Mandaluyong; Pius XII Catholic Center, Manila; Saint John Bosco Parish Church in Pasay Road, Makati; Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Shrine in Sucat, Parañaque; the Philippine Airlines Building on Ayala Ave, Makati; the Philippine Banking Corporation Building at Port Area, Manila; the Union Church in Makati, built 1975, now demolished; Virra Mall, Greenhills, built 1975, demolished 2005; and the Bataan Power Plant of the National Power Corporation. As a member of Hexagon Associated Architects, he was one of those who designed the National Library on T. M. Kalaw, Manila. Low-cost housing projects designed by him include the Saint Joseph the Worker housing project in Pasig and the Tala Leprosarium Housing in Novaliches.

The Meralco Building, a 15-story office building, is slightly curved to give it more stability and to avoid the boxlike appearance of rectangular buildings and “train effect” of straight corridors. Tapering vertical sunbreakers enhance the gentle curve of the concave facade. The 1,000-seat Meralco Theater was designed for musical and theatrical presentations, as well as for international conferences. The most famous building by Zaragoza is the present Santo Domingo Church and Convent, which follows the plan of the church-tower-convento (parish house) complex of the colonial period. While the building embodies the simplicity of modern design, such features as arches give it a traditional touch. One of the largest in the country, the church is the national shrine of Nuestra Señora del Santisimo Rosario, also called La Naval.

In 1960, Zaragoza was invited to be guest architect to participate in designing Brasilia, Brazil’s new capital, by eminent Brazilian architects Oscar Niemeyer and Lucio Costa. In 1973, Zaragoza was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila. In 1977, he received the PIA’s Gold Medal of Merit. He was posthumously named National Artist for architecture in 2014.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana

Ramon Ma. Zaragoza (Ramon Ma. Rosello Zaragoza) is a restoration architect, town planner, and essayist. He was born on 12 Aug 1945. His parents are National Artist for architecture Jose Ma. Zaragoza and Pilar Rosello. Ramon Ma. Zaragoza comes from a family of architects and engineers. The Zaragoza’s Philippine lineage traces to Rafael Zaragoza who worked in Nueva Ecija in the tobacco industry of the 19th century. He had two children, Jose and Miguel. Jose married Rosa Roxas of Quiapo, whose son Elias is Ramon’s grandfather. Elias was an engineer who graduated from Yale University in 1906. Elias married Rosario Velez y Infante, thus associating the family with Guagua, Pampanga. He studied at the University of Santo Tomas (UST).

Ramon studied at De La Salle, completing his elementary years in 1959 and his secondary years in 1963. He obtained a bachelor of science in architecture from UST in 1967. He went to Spain and studied at the Escuela Tecnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid, where he took a postgraduate course in town planning and urban renewal from 1967 to 1968. During this same period, he also studied at the Instituto de Cultura Hispanica, Madrid, where he studied Spanish art. On 5 Jan 1970, he passed the board examination for architecture.

Ramon worked closely with his father but came to be known for his restoration works and advocacy expressed through a number of books that he wrote. As an advocate of heritage conservation, he succeeded his father in working on the restoration of Intramuros. From 1980 to 1990, he worked on the walls of Intramuros, its baluarte or bastions, fausse-braye, moats, and drawbridges. He also worked on Fort Santiago’s gate, bridge, and moat and the Plaza de Armas. He also worked on the landscaping and monumental lighting of this historic city. He has also been actively involved in the restoration of heritage structures, like the Shrine of Baldomero Aguinaldo at Binakayan, Cavite; Ermita de San Nicolas de Tolentino, West Rembo, Makati; San Agustin Church, Intramuros; and Santa Ana Church, Santa Ana, Pampanga. In 1993, he authored a master plan for Vigan, which recommended that families bear responsibility for the maintenance and restoration of their heritage houses, rather than depend on foreign funding. He recommended that the historic district of Vigan, along Crisologo St be closed off to traffic, warehouses transferred elsewhere, and old residences be reused for tourism as inns, restaurants, and stores. He moved for the dredging of the Mestizo and Govantes Rivers, the removal of illegal fishpens, and the reopening of the Vigan port and the Vigan airport.

His advocacy for heritage conservation took on a personal turn when he restored a house in Vigan, originally owned by the Encarnacion family. He purchased the house in 1998. In the restoration, some items from the Zaragoza house in Quiapo, like capiz windows, knocker and iron items were incorporated in the restored Vigan house. The house is L-shaped in plan and dated to the 1790s. The house has an inner patio, a unique feature among the Vigan houses. The house was blessed and dedicated to the Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buenviaje, hence the name Villa Paz, and the patio dedicated to the Nuestra Señora del Pilar in honor of Ramon’s mother (Zaragoza 2004, 220-75). The house is also known as Museo Zaragoza. In 2005, he restored the altar of the Shrine of the Miraculous Medal in Sucat, Parañaque, which his father Jose had designed in 1980.

He is the author of Old Manila, 1990, which had a Japanese edition; Lost Era, 1994; La Ilustracion Filipina: 1891-1894, 1992; The Philippines Images of the Past, 1993; and Zaragoza: The Art of Restoration, 2005. Ateneo de Manila University’s Budhi: A Journal of Ideas and Culture published his works Ciudad Fernandina, Ilocos Sur, 2004, and Guagua to Quiapo, 2006 as monographs. He also published Philippine Historical Illustrations, Filipino Expressions, Tribal Splendor, Vigan: The Lost Jewel, Villa Paz-Real Zaragoza-Vigan, Ilocos Sur, 70th Year of the Philippine Institute of Architects, and Fiesta sa Quiapo (Fiesta at Quiapo).

He received the Araw ng Maynila Award in 1997 in the field of arts and culture, the De La Salle University Alumni award for architectural excellence in 2002, the 70 Distinguished Men of Service award of the Philippine Institute of Architects in 2008 (PIA), and the PIA Gold Medal of Merit for restoration, conservation, and town planning in 2008. In 2012, he received the Gawad Gintong Likha for Restoration at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by René B. Javellana
